Groucho silent, unwitting pawn in court battle 

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. (AF) - 
Groucho Marx, besot by tho ills and tho fuzziness of old age, doesn’t know that ho and his millions are being fought 
(hor in court and is unaware of his brother’s death last week. 
Nat Perrin, named last Friday as 
Grouche s tem p o rary con serv ato r, said his 86-year-old charge is embar- 
Senate okays cut in taxes 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
WASHINGTON - The Senate juggled billions of dollars Fri­ day and sent to the House m ea­ sures that would cut taxes for 47 million couples or individuals and create jobs for 3oo,ooo un­ employed persons. 
The Senate passed by a wide margin a stripped-down tax bill, once the heart of President Carter’s economic stimu­ lus program, that would mean an an­ nual tax reduction averaging $121 for 
47 million tax returns. 
The measure, approved 73 to 7, pro­ vides that 92 per cent of the benefits would go to fam ilies or individuals w ith incomes under $2o,oo(1 — provided they use the standard deduction and not itemize their returns. 
For the individual taxpayer, the most im po rtant provision sets the standard deduction at $2,2oo for a sin­ gle person and $3,2oo for married cou­ ples and heads of households. This is a permanent provision. 
The Senate also approved, by a 71 to 
14 vote. C arter’s $4 billion public works plan intended to stimulate the economy and reduce unemployment by giving local governments money lo build schools, hospitals, bridges and other projects. 
The House takes up the bill Tuesday and Carter is expected to sign it soon 
See TAX CUT, Page JIA 
Signs healthy for econom y 

WASHINGTON (AP) - An adminis­ tration economist said Friday a strong showing by leading economic indica­ tors, led by an increase in new orders for consumer products and materials. was an encouraging sign for the future growth of the economy. 
The March index of the indicators was iii) 1.4 per cent, registering the highest gain in 29 months, according lo figures released by the C om m erce 
Department. 
The indicators index, consisting of 12 separate economic statistics, is d e­ signed to forecast trends for the na­ tion’s economy.

Red tape hits prisoner swap 

NEW YORK TIMES SERVICE 
WASHINGTON - Potential constitutional difficulties with a five-month-old treaty that pro­ vides for an ex ch an ge of prisoners between the United 

States and I^Iexico are threaten­ ing to delay further its ratifica­ tion by the Senate and to cause a m a ssiv e legal tangle in U.S. courts if the treaty ever takes effect. 

Justice D epartm ent lawyers, who have toiled since late last year to draft legislation needed to implement the treaty’s provisions, now say they be­ lieve they have resolved the thorniest of the questions raised by the pact, which would deny returning A m eri­ cans a chance to challenge the legality 
TWQB moves to block Hill’s suit on aquifer 

By DICK MERKEL 

CHIEF, EXPRESS NEW S CAPITOL BUREAU 
AUSTIN - The T exas Sn- preme Court was asked Friday to block Atty. Gen. John Hill’s lawsuit against the Texas Water 
Quality Board over the contro­ versial Edwards Underground 
Aquifer Protection Order. 

The TWQB filed its petition for a writ of mandamus with the high court shortly before noon. 

TWQB is asking the Supreme Court to rule on the legality of Hill’s suing a state agency. 
Under normal circum stances, the attorney g e n e ra l is charged with representing state agencies in legal matters. 
II is highly unusual, but not without precedent, for the attorney general to sue an agency lie is normally expected to defend. 
If the high court finds in favor of the 
TWQB, the agency is then asking for the writ ordering Hill to drop the suit. 
Friday’s action is the latest chapter in a highly unusual story which began on March 3.

.------------------------------—---- - 

On that date, the TWQB amended its long-standing Edwards order into se­ ven separate orders governing Bexar, 
Comal, Hays, Kendall, Medina, Uvalde and Kinney counties. 
Prior to that, a single order has controlled development, land use and building standards in the recharge zone which lies in all or part of the seven counties. 
Since the aquifer is San Antonio’s sole source of water, the TWQB action was bitterly opposed by the city and 
Bexar County. 
They were joined in the opposition by the Alamo Area Council of Govern­ ments, the Aquifer Protection Assn. and several m em b ers of the Bexar 
County legislative delegation. 
Opposition was also voiced by representatives of Kendall, Medina, 
Hays and Comal counties. 
Throughout, the attorney general’s office questioned the constitutionality of the TWQB’s action in splitting the 
Edwards order into seven separate parts. 
On March 9, Hill filed suit against the TWQB in state district court. The suit charged the aquifer is a single geological formation which cannot be divided by geographical lines. 
The suit also contended the separate orders set different standards in each of the counties and are therefore discriminatory. 
It also termed the TWQB’s action

M A J. GEN W A R R E N E. M YERS of the 9oth U.S. A rm y 
Reserve Com m and in San Antonio presents a belated 
Bronze Star to Joe Rodriguez. 
Bronze Star Medal 33 years late reaching San Antonian 

It took nearly 33 years, but Joe 
G. Rodriguez finally received the Bronze Star Medal he earned in the 1944 Normandy invasion. 

Rodriguez was formally presented the medal this.month at the 9oth U.S. 
Army Reserve Command in San An­ tonio. 
Retired 

Rodriguez, who retired in San An­ tonio, had been presented the Purple 
Heart years ago for his participation in th6 Normandy invasion. 

Somewhere along the way, however, the Bronze Star was forgotten. 

Rodriguez’ wife Dorothy and his son 
Paul Joseph decided to do something about it. They contacted the proper 

 authorities and eventually the medal arrived. 
Rodriguez was a member of the 9oth 

Infantry Division during the war. 
After the war, he worked in St. Louis before retiring iii San Antonio. 

 of their Mexican convictions in the 
U.S. courts. 
But the draft will still have to be approved by the House and Senate Ju ­ diciary Com m ittees, and some civil rights lawyers believe that further modification of the treaty itself may be required by the Senate Foreign Rela­ tions Committee before it becomes law. 
Treaty 
The treaty, the first of its sort ever struck between the United States and 
Mexico, was signed by representatives of the two countries last Thanksgiving and ratified by the Mexican legislature a few days later. 
But U.S. Senate aides say that hear­ ings by the Foreign Relations Com­ mittee on the ratification issue alone probably cannot be held before June at the earliest, because of the crowded congressional calendar. 
Although the treaty calls for Ameri­ cans who are returned to the United 
States to finish serving their sentences in federal p rison s, those who have served more than a third of the alloted tim e will be e lig ib le under federal guidelines for parole. 
John Hill, the attorney general of 
Texas, said last week that the draft legislation had becom e ensnarled within the federal Office of Manage­ ment and Budget. But Hill was quoted in San Antonio as saying that he had been a ssu red by officials in 
Washington that it was possible for the entire package, treaty, legislation and all, to clear the C o ngress by Sep­ tember. 
In interviews with reporters and in letters sent to friends and families in the United States, many of the Ameri can prisoners have alleged that they; were arrested and searched in Mexico in a manner that would have violated

A contest of raw courage 

PORT O’CONNOR (AP) - Howard 
Lewis, a local commercial fisherman and self-appointed oyster connoisseur, will put his taste buds on the line! 
Saturday. 
Lewis has bragged he can tell the) difference between raw oysters taken from San Antonio Bay and those arti­ ficially salted. 
Oysters taken from waters close to the mouths of rivers often are salted! artificially. 
Lewis was challenged by Robert 
Sanders, a Seadrift fisherman, and 
Lewis agreed to try to prove his point 
Saturday. 
He will have to correctly identify 29j of the 31) oysters that will be served to| him in plastic cups. 
If he does, he will get a prize — three! gallons of raw oysters.

Looking for a job? Maybe the 
Express and News can help. 

During May, job seek ers — from housewives and students to the disabled — are eligible to run a free “Job wanted” notice in the classified ads. 

At least 335,ooo people could see that ad. 

If you’re looking for a job, either 

 mail in your want ad or come to the classified counter in the lobby of the 
Express/News building, 
Avenue E and Third Street, any weekday from 8:3o a.m. to 4:3o p.m. 

Your ad will run three days under “Situations wanted” in the regular classified columns of the 
Express and News, along with the 
Express-News’ weekly papers — the N orthside, W estside and 

Southside Suns. 

Watch for the “ Need A Job?” coupon in the Sunday Express and 
News and mail it in fast. 

It’s our move to reduce unem­ ployment. 

Sorry, we cannot accept any of these free classified ads over the phone.

ALL MAJOR CREDIT CARDS HONORED 

Choice is dead wrong 

A litter help from the city 

They had to call off the annual week-long community clean-up three days early in 
Manhattan, Kan., be­ cause of mounting complaints that the city trucks hauling away the trash were dropping too much litter. 
Before the event was brought to a quick end, 
Alvin Johnson, the as­ sistant director of the 
Riley County Police 
Department, threa­ tened to give the city drivers tickets for lit­ tering. 
“ I couldn’t see how I could allow city trucks to go by but stop private citizens and the contractors,” Johnson said. 

Gov. Doiph Briscoe has appointed a dead man to serve a three- year term on the State 
Health Advisory Com­ mittee. 

Briscoe's office con­ firmed Friday that the governor “ routinely” reappointed Dr. Mayn­ ard S. Hart of El Paso lo another three-year 

 term on the 
35-43 member committee. 

“ We were notified about it (Hart’s death) some time after the ap­ pointments were sub­ mitted,” said a shee­ pish George Lowrance, 
Briscoe’s administra­ tive assistant for ap­ pointments. 

 reappointment,” added 
Lowrance, who didn’t say how the governor’s office learned of the mistake. 

Briscoe’s office maintains that the governor personally makes such appoint­ ments to state agencies and committees. 

“ It was just a routine 
“ I don’t recall this 

Bea makes 

 ever happening be­ fore,” said Lowrance. 

The governor plans to appoint Dr. Richard 
Jewell of El Paso, a former associate of 
Hart, to fill Hart’s va­ cancy, Lowrance said. 

Indian leader to have 

 exception su rg e ry 

Bea Arthur, who plays “ Maude” on tele­ vision has, so far, steadfastly turned down all requests to do com­ mercials. 

Now, however, she’s made an exception and has plunged heavily — writing the copy and reading it, too — into a radio commercial for the new Broadway mu­ sical “ I Love My Wife.” 
Her husband, 
Gene 
Saks, directed the musical. 
BEA ARTHUR 
Mormons make comeback 

After more than 13o years, a Mormon is back running the vil­ lage of Nauvoo, 111. 

The village of the 
Mississippi River has was established by 
Mormons seeking a ha­ ven from religious persecution. 

But 
Joseph Smith and Jr., the Mormon founder, and his brother, were killed by a mob near Nauvoo in 
1844. 

Two years later the 
Mormons, led by 
Brigham Young, fled across the Mississippi to Utah. About 2o Mor- 

 since drifted back to 
Nauvoo and now Walter 
Pearce, a 44-year-old 
Mormon, has been elected mayor of the 

 it was his second try for the office and after his yictorv, Pearce said: “ We’re so happy 
(religion) wasn’t an mon families have village of 1,ooo people. issue. 
Estate chewed up 

Half of the $oo.3 million estate left by Philip K. Wrigley, the owner of the Chicago Cubs and the Wrigley 
Chewing Gum Co. who died April 12 at the age of 62, will go to his widow', 
Helen Wrigley. 
The rest will be divided among 

 his son, William; his daughters, 
Ada W. Schreiner of Port Orchard, 
Wash., and Dorothy W. Chauncey, of Scottsdale, Ariz.; IO grandchil­ dren and the University of Southern 
California. 

Doctors in New Delhi said 
Thursday that 
Jayaprakash Narayan, the leader of the move­ ment that toppled the government of 
Indira 
Gandhi in last month’s elections, will fly to the 
United 
States this weekend for surgery lo facilitate his use of the dialysis machine that substitutes for his failed kidneys. 
The 74-year-old Nar­ ayan will be operated on at the Washington; 
University School of 
Medicine in Seattle. 
Narayan was jailed along with other dis­ senters when Prim e 
Minister 
Gandhi proclaimed a state of emergency in June 
1975. After being held for five months he was released because of poor health. 

First Lady 

Kosalynn 
Carter plunged right back into a busy schedule Friday after undergoing sur­ gery Thursday for the removal of a noncan­ cerous lump from her breast.

WASHINGTON 
- 
Chief Justice Warren 
Burger is deeply indebt­ ed to his old friend, ex- 
Attorney General John 
Mitchell, for his Supreme 
Court job. 
Yet Burger has refused to disqualify himself from Mitchell’s appeal of his Watergate cover-up conviction, now pending before the high court. 
The white-maned 
Burger has been trying to persuade reluctant fellow' justices to hear the ap­ peals of Mitchell and ex-White House aides 
H.R. Haldeman and John 
Ehrlichman, National 
Public Radio reported last week. 
The report, which our sources confirmed, said that Justice W illiam 
Rehnquist voluntarily stepped down from the case because of his past friendship with Mitchell. 
Also close 
But Burger and M it­ chell also were personal­ ly close, high ex-Justice 
Department sources told us. 
In fact, they said, it was the pipe-smoking at­ torney general who recommended Burger to 
President Nixon in 1969. 
This charge was bol- 

Jack 
! 
Anderson 

 stered by no less than 
Mitchell’s wife, the late loquacious Martha. She told friends that her hus­ band had tapped Burger for the nation’s highest judicial post. 
At a 
May, 
197o, gathering in New York attended by both Burger and Martha, free-lance photographer Fred Ward casually asked Martha whether she knew 
Burger. 
“ Who do you think put him where he is?” 
Martha said. Ward, then on assignment for Look magazine, relayed the incident to 
Winzola 
McLendon, a close friend of Martha and a writer for Look. 
McLendon, alone with 
Martha in the powder 

 room, asked: “ What did you mean by that remark to Fred? Did John put him in there?” 
According to the notes 
McLendon made at the time, Martha replied: 
“ John is the one who put him on the Supreme 
Court.” 
Martha later told 
McLendon that the two men often gabbed on the telephone until Mitchell left the Justice Depart­ ment to run Nixon’s 1972 campaign. But a Su­ preme Court spokesman said Burger spoke only infrequently with Mit- 

Burger’s voice reportedly appears briefly on the suppressed 
White House tapes in a conversation with Nixon 
Although Burger or­ dered Nixon lo release certain other tapes in 
1974, he has not removed himself from the contin* uing battle over whether 
Nixon or the government should get custody of all the tapes. 
Both McLendon and 
Ward coi.firm their por­ tions of the May, 197o, conversation. 
Although the Justice 
Department could ask 

This charge was bolsterefl by no less than Mitchell9s wife, the late loquacious Martha. She told friends that her husband had tapped Burger for the na- tion's highest judicial post 

 che 11 from 1969 to 1972, and then only on official business. 
Only once did Burger talk by phone with 
Mitchell at home, the spokesman said. 
The Watergate cover­ up trial is not the only one in which Burger’s participation has been questioned. 

 to disqualify a department 
Burger himself, spokesman said such questions are always left up to the justices. 

A spokesman for 
Burger said he had no intention of disqualifying himself. Mitchell could not be reached for com­ ment. 
Boy saved from fire 

By CECIL CLIFT 
A 5-year-old boy nar­ rowly escaped death when flames swept through the apartment house where he was sleeping Friday night. 
The youth reportedly received second and third-degree burns. 
The victim, 
Erie 
James Kopp, under the guardianship of Mrs. Ly­ dia Klonek of 3o3 E. 

Courtland Place, was in satisfactory condition at 
Brooke Army Medical 
Center following the in­ cident. 

Daughter 

Mrs. 
Klonek’s daughter, Joanne Klon­ ek, 17, said there were six people in their up­ stairs apartment when smoke began seeping up-

 wards from a downstairs apartment. 

Five of the six man­ aged to find their way out even though the stairwell was ablaze, she said. 
Two of the younger children jumped out the window into the arms of their mother, who had run to the building after being summoned from work nearby, Miss Klon­ ek said. 
The rest either fought their way down the stairs or climbed down ladders provided by firemen. 
“ But we forgot Erie,” she said. The boy was asleep in an adjoining apartment used by the family. 

Miss Klonek said the smoke awakened the youth and he managed to walk to a front window into the arms of Fireman 
Patrick Koerber. 
After the two climbed down the ladder, EMS technicians administered oxygen to the youth be­ fore transporting him to the hospital. 
None of the other resi­ dents of the eight-apartment complex were seriously injured, officers said. 
Arson investigators said the fire originated in a downstairs apartment. 
Cause of the $17,ooo blaze was under investigation early Saturday. 

Meeting set on reading 

The Alamo Reading 
Council and Incarnate 
Word College will co­ sponsor the tenth annual reading conference from 
8 a.m. to noon Saturday. 

The conference will be in Incarnate Word Col­ lege’s Marian Hall and is 

 open to all teachers or prospective teachers of reading. 

The conference fee is 
$3 for non-members of the 
Alamo 
Reading 
Council. For further information telephone 
Sister Theophtfhe Power of IWC at 8281261. 

Kelly gets funding 

SPF GAL TO THE EXPRESS NEWb 
WASHINGTON — Kelly AFB was authorized $4 million for lighting and energy efficiency systems by the U.S. Senate, 
Sen. John Tower said Friday. 
The funds were authorized by the Senate Armed Services 
Committee panel. Tower said. 
The package for Kelly and other area military installa­ tions will go to the House for appropriations action, he said. 
The funds were designated for a $2.3 million landing strip lighting system and a $1.7 mil­ lion monitoring system to im­ prove efficiency at Kelly. 
Other funds were approved by the panel for the following installations in Texas: 
B e rg stro m AFB, A ustin, 
$874,o(1o for an energy effi­ ciency system; Kingsville Na­ val Station, $55o,ooo for insula­ tion and storm windows, and 
Corpus Christi Air Station, $7 iiiiIlion for industrial waste treatment.

Pinckney’s moving on 

'Unfortunately, at the age o f 3 7 , I hare probably baff as exciting jobs as I trill ever hare ’ 

By BILL MINTZ 

John M. Pinckney III has been a U.S. 
Marine Corps officer, a budget officer in the Nixon White House and an assistant U.S. Attorney in San Antonio. 
In one way or another, he has been under fire for the 15 years since he graduated from the University of Tex­ as at Austin. 
But Monday he starts a new job and probably a more quiet life when he joins the San Antonio law firm of 
Matthews, Nowlin, Macfarlane and 
Barrett. 
“ Unfortunately, a* the age of 37, I have probably had as exciting jobs as I will ever have,” Pinckney said Friday, his last day as first assistant to U.S. 
Atty. John E. Clark. 
Clashes 
Pinckney and Clark often clashed with Chief U.S. Dist. Judge Adrian A. 
Spears. 
Judge Spears has frequently criti­ cized C lark’s adm inistration for de­ cisions on prosecutions and on Clark's 

 w ithdrawal from the omnibus program for discovery in criminal cases. 
But the conflicts have not damaged the effectiveness of the federal prose­ cutors’ office here. 
“ To the contrary, the conflicts have served to establish the independence of this office,” Pinckney said. 
Pinckney said federal judges have come to see the judicial branch as su­ preme in the federal system of checks and balances between the judicial, executive and legislative branches. 
‘Not so' 
“ T h at isn ’t so ,” he said. “ The judges are called on to reconcile dif­ ferences between the executive and legislative, but that doesn’t make the judiciary supreme. 
“ I think they come to that view be­ cause of the life tenure. I saw the same thing in senior Marine Corps officers 

 and counselors to the president — they think they have to answer to no one. 
“ Thank goodness they don’t have life tenure,” he added. 
Since the U.S. attorn ey ’s post is considered a political plum, prosecu­ tions or the lack of prosecution is often attacked as politically motivated. 
“ There has never been any political p re ssu re thro ug h my s u p e rio rs ,” 
Pinckney said. “ Of course, I have read about people who are trying to in­ fluence prosecution.” 
No comment 
Pinckney wouldn’t talk about the most publicized case in the U.S. 
Courthouse, the federal prosecution of 
C a s tro v ille ^ fo rm er police chief, 
Frank Hayes, on criminal civil rights charges. 
Pinckney drew up the initial recom­ mendation to the U.S. Justice Depart­ 

 ment to close the case after Hayes was convicted of aggravated assault in state court. 
His decision was based on a 1859 decision against dual prosecutions which was in effect when Pinckney reviewed the case. 
But that policy was changed by the new U.S. Attorney General, Griffin 
Bell, before the decision to prosecute was made. 
Variety 

Pinckney said he may be called in as a w itness if H ayes’ attorneys push their allegation that Bell’s decision was political. 
P in c k n e y 's work has included prosecution of illegal aliens, dru g pushers, doctors, bankers and lawyers. 
“ I ve tried to make every decision like I was on the courthouse steps with the attorney general looking over my shoulder,” he said. 
He said he wanted to think each de­ cision could stand up to scrutiny by his superiors and the public. 

CHILDREN join Friday their m others on the picket line to protest cutbacks in day care funding by the state Senate st a f f p h o t o by t ark y t a r s u s 

By SARA MARTINEZ 

Archbishop Francis J. Furey 
Friday urged all San Antonians to support the Right to Life 
Committee by participating in its May 7 fund-raising walka- thon. 

“ I encourage all our citizens to sup­ port this effort to protect the lives of the unborn, future citizens of our great country.” Archbishop Furey said. 
The Rev. Robert Holbrook, coordin­ a to r of Baptists for Life, and Beth 
Pfrom er. Texas State coordinator of the National Youth Pro-Life Coalition also endorsed the walkathon. 
T he Right to Life C o m m itte e ’s 
1o-mile walkathon, to point up the re­ lationship between being a mother and respecting the life of a child, starts at ll) a.m. at Ruleto Drive and IH41o. 
Day care cuts protested 

By DAVID MCLEMORE 
EXPRESS-NEWS MEDICAL WRITER 

About 3oo parents and children 
Friday protested State Senate cutbacks in funds for day care centers. 
The protesters, ranging in age from 
3 to 6o years, carried signs reading, 
“ Give my future a chance” and 
“ Where will I go?” 
The protest was held at the Healy- 
Murphy Child Care Center, 122 Nolan 
St., to call attention to the reduction of 
$2 million from state allocations to child care centers. 
Laura Ashkenaze of the Coordinated 
Child Care Council said current fund­ ing for centers is now $31.5 million. 

7 guess they don't care about the needs o f our children. That hurts.' 

The senate has recommended the fi­ gure be cut back to $3o million for the next two years. 
“ The House recom m en ded $32 million for 1978 and $34 million for 
1979,” she said. “ This is the level of funding we need to continue opera­ tion.” 
Mrs. Ashkenaze said about 2o day care centers in San Antonio would be affected by the loss if the senate re­ commendations are accepted. 
“ Of the 1,2oo children enrolled in day­ care centers here, we would have to 

 drop about 2oo because of lack of funds,” she said. 
“ These are children of low-income families, mostly working mothers or people involved in job-training pro­ grams. 
“ Having day care for their children helps them get off the wefare rolls and get jobs to become self-sufficient.” 
Consuete Rocha, d irecto r of the 
Wesley Day Care Center, said, “These people have respect for the legislators, but they have lo speak up for their children. 

“ The children can't vote, but they need the good services provided by assisted day care centers.” 
The 2o centers here are federally funded to provide inexpensive or free care to those qualified. The state funds are matching giants which allow fe­ deral participation. 
One mother of two, said she would have to leave her children at home or quit her job if she couldn't place them in the center during the day while she was at work. 
“ I wish the senators would place themselves in our position,” she said. 
“ But they are up high and don’t need day care services. 
“ I guess they don’t care about the needs of our children. That hurts.” 

“Since abortion on demand has been the law of the land, millions of unborn babies Have been aborted every year,” 
Archbishop Furey said. 
“ Their right to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness has gone down the drain.” 
The archbishop said two things have been forgotten about the U.S. Supreme 
Court ruling on abortion: it knocked out the existing Texas abortion laws and it was by majority, not unanimous. 
“ While the Roman Catholic hier­ archy has been in the vanguard against abortion, we are by no means alone in this fight,” he said. 
Mistake 
“ It would be a big mistake to sup­ pose this is a Roman Catholic struggle. 
We are against abortion because it is anti-God and anti-American.” 
Archbishop Furey said right to life supporters were working hard to get an amendment to the U.S. Constitution which would nullify the Suprem e 
Court’s ruling. 
“ But this will take a long tim e,” 
Archbishop Furey said. “ To be very frank, it won’t come in my lifetime but it’s the only way it can be done in the final analysis.” 
In the m eantim e, the archbishop said they were trying to bring to the atten tio n of fellow A m ericans the moral aspect. 
“ Abortion may be legal by American law, bul it is illegal as far as God is concerned,” he concluded.

Council takes tour of 
S.A. highs and lows 

By JIM WOOD 
City Council members got a first hand look Friday at where the city has been and where it needs to go. 
They got a w arning from City 
Mgr. Tom Huebner that a m ajor problem facing them is how to maintain park and recreation areas financed with one-shot fed eral money. 
The occasion was a dav-long bus tour of the city. It was arranged by 
Mayor Lila Cockrell and Huebner to acquaint newly elected m em bers 

 with some of their official areas of responsibility. 
It proved a refresher for the older hands. 
Council members, accompanied by wives and husbands, saw heaps of junked ears along Somerset Road and apartm ents sloping off their foundations in Pecan Valley. 
They visited the immaculate East 
Side Multi-Service Center in Lin­ coln 
Park, where older people played dominoes and young ones played in the nursery. 

They drove by the Rilling Road 
Sewage T reatm en t P lant where odors are so bad some wondered how the city gets away with it. 
(Council has appropriated money for an experim ental program to eliminate the smell.) 

Before it was over they had been to the north, south, east and west and heard co m m en ts about loo many stray dogs and too many bill­ boards. 

New slogan is pushed for S.A. 

“ Free Enterprise. It lets you be somebody.” 
That phrase w ill soon become part of San Antonio’s image to the rest of the nation if Edward 
V’. Cheviot has anything to say about it. 
Cheviot, chairm an of the 
Greater San Antonio Chamber of C om m erce’s Free E n te r­ prise Council introduced the phrase — on bumper stickers and in radio and television commercials — at a Friday luncheon attended by several hundred local businessmen. 
The campaign, organized by 

 a local advertising agency, is designed to awaken a strong public awareness of the posi­ tive aspects of the free enter­ prise system. 
The media portion will begin 
June I and the concept will be re-em phasized by sem inars and symposiums at local high schools and colleges later this spring. 
Support for the entire effort was requested of the business­ men. not in money but in atti­ tude, devotion of time and con­ tributions of advertising space in their firms.

Commissioners to debate 

 t 
% taxing of church hospitals 

By DEBORAH WESER 
The possibility of putting church-affiliated hospitals on the tax rolls will be on Wednes­ day’s Commissioners Court agenda for debate. 
Tax Assessor-collector Ben Shaw — w ho has said he’s already looking into the move — will be invited to attend the session, according to County Judge 
Blair Reeves. 
Reeves, in an impromptu move Fri­ day. decided on the special debate afte r a b rief exchange with other 
^members of Commissioners Court. 
The idea of revoking tax-exem pt status for church-related hospitals 

The change in taxing status o f those church-related hospitals could hike tax revenues fo r the county by about $ 2 o o ,o o o this y e a r, Stolhandske observed after some (puck arithm etic 

 claiming charity exemptions won en­ d orsem ent from both Coms. A. J. 
Ploch and Tom -Stolhandske. 

Offering a note of caution, however,. was Com. A lbert B u stam ante. He urged more examination of the subject before any step is taken. 
Shaw, as tax assessor-collector, has the power to grant or revoke exempt status, Bustamante also pointed out. 

Commissioners Court, in its capacity as the county’s Board of Equalization, however, is empowered to review that status, Reeves responded. 
The change in taxing status of those church-related hospitals could hike tax revenues for the county by about 
$2oo,ooo this year, Stolhandske ob­ served after some quick arithmetic. 
The idea of revoking exemption for the facilities has been raised before at 

C om m ission ers Court but not d is­ cussed in any great detail. 
T his tim e the recom m endation comes from the Bexar County Hospital 
District Board of Managers through its chairman, Dr. Harvey Hornet. 
Hornet announced earlier in the week that a formal recommendation will be transmitted to Commissioners Court. 
The hospital district managers spe­ cifically refer to such church-related h osp itals as Santa Rosa Medical 
Center, Baptist M em orial Hospital 
System, Southwest Methodist Hospital and Lutheran Hospital. 
Charity 
Their tax exempt status is based on their provision of charitable services to the community. 
At the time. Hornet said concern with this issue stems from the fact the district must scramble for funds but is left with indigent patients unable to pay their bills.

Carter pushes warrant for tap 

WASHINGTON (A P ) 
— President C arter w ill propose le g isla tio n requiring court warrants for all wiretaps and bugs used to g a th e r in te l­ ligence about fo reig n spies, adm inistration of­ ficials said Friday. 
They said Carter’s bill will afford more protec­ tion of 
A m e ric a n s ' privacy rig h ts th an a sim ilar bill that was of­ fered by the F o rd a d ­ ministration but failed to win c o n g re ssio n a l a p ­ proval. 
They said Carter is the first President to a b a n ­ don the claim of inherent power to conduct foreign intellig en ce ta p s and bugs without warrants. 
Time to explain 
The adm inistration of­ ficials discussed the bill. to be proposed next week, on the condition that they not be identified. They said they w ant tim e to explain the m e a su re to m e m b ers of C o n g ress before the public a n ­ nouncement next week 
Under c u r r e n t law, there are two k inds of electronic surveillance. 
One kind r e q u ir e s the 
FBI to get approval from a federal judge for taps and bugs used to gather evidence about domestic crimes. These taps and bugs are used most often in investigations of o r­ ganized c rim e , particularly gambling. 
The new proposal does not directly affect this kind of spying. 
The other type of elec­ tronic s u rv e illa n c e is used by the FBI. the CIA and the National Security 
Agency to g ath er intel­ ligence about foreign spies.

Bar Assn., here as part of the bar group’s observance of la w Day. Each San Antonio school district received copies of the book, which deals with the role of the U.S. Su­ preme Court in American life.

Offshore oil well wins again 

COMPILED FROM WIRE SERVICES 
STAVANGER, Norway - A Texan-led team failed again Friday to cap the out-of­ control Ekofisk offshore oil well, defeated by the immense force of oil being pushed up from beneath the sea at a speed faster than sound. 
S p ecial c la m p s d e ­ sig n e d to n a rro w the stre a m of oil gave way before a four-ton stopper could be m a n e u v e re d o v er the g u s h in g w ell­ head, which has sprayed more than 7 million gal­ lons of oil into the North 
Sea since it blew out a weeks ago. 
The Texans, m eeting later on a barge anchored off the well rig, discussed possible new a tte m p ts 
Saturday with their boss, 
Red Adair, the world’e leading blowout expert, who flew from Houston to su p e rv is e the p ro ce ed ­ ings. 
It marked the fourth failure to cap the geyser, w hich h as s p r e a d a 
7o-bv-4o-mile oil slick.

'17 K elly veterans reunited 

F our m em b ers of an aerial squadron stationed at Kelly Field 6o years ago during World War I cam e back to Kelly AFB 
Friday. 
It could be their last reunion. 
The v e te ra n s , all in their 8os. are am ong tin? last 16 survivors of the 
26o-member 351st Aero 
S q u a d ro n at K elly in 
1917-18. 
The old-timers — John 
G. Oeehsner of El Paso, 
J. B. .Sinclair of Gasport, 
Ind.; Fred Alderman of 
Pinedale, Wyo., and Ed­ ward Brough of St. He!-: ena, Ore.—were engaged in airplane maintenance training as enlisted men with the Signal C orps squadron at Kelly six de­ cades ago. 
For about 25 years they have had almost-annual reunions at various sites around the nation. Last year the get-together was at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. 
With their advancing age, they believe this might be the final time they will be able to meet. 

Trips 

T h is y e a r ’s reu n io n started T hursday at the 
T ra v e L o d g e at C o u rth ­ ouse S q u a re and will con tin u e with inform al g a t h e r in g s th e re u n til 
S u n d ay , w ith s e v e ra l tr ip s p la n n e d to K elly and to other local scenic and historical sites. 

At Kelly, the four men and eight accom panying re la tiv e s a n d frie n d s w ere g r e e te d by M aj. 
Gen. John R. Kelly J r., 
San Antonio Air Logistics- 
C e n te r C o m m a n d e r. 

Gen. 
Kelly showed them a pictorial display depicting activities on the base from its found­ ing in 1917 through World 
War ll to modern times. 
He also detailed plans for the observance of Kelly’s 
6oth anniversary on May 
.7. 
Following a discussion with Gen. Kelly in which they r e m in is c e d ab o u t their experiences al Kel­ ly F ield d u r in g W orld 
War I, the oldtimers, se­ veral in w h e e lc h a irs . were taken on a tour of the large logistics center.

Strategy meeting set to halt boat hijackings 

 son Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS-—Soturdoy April 3o 1977 
H 
Page * 5-A 

M O BILE, 
Ala. 
(A P)—Law officers from live states and federal 
(Minier agents plan to meet in Mobile May 2o to draw up a “ game plan” to combat an apparent 
Cise in boat hijackings in 
Hie Gulf of Mexico. 
W illiam B. Garner, acting chief of the 
Alabama Marine Police, said 
Friday 
“ there have been too many dis­ 

 appearances to have all been accidents." 
Last fall and early this year two luxury yachts. 
The Pirate’s Lady from 
New Orleans and The 
Flying Dutchman from 
Montgomery, Ala., van­ ished without a trace alter departing Apala­ chicola, Fla..on cruises in the Gulf. Authorities say it s likely both were hijacked. 

Garner said the meet­ ing probably wont produce anything new on those two cases, but he said it could establish a coordinated program to discourage hijackings in the future. 
“ Subsequent to the most recent incidents, there has been recogni­ tion of the fact that there was no coordination of investigative efforts," he

N-plant lax in security 

CORDOVA, III. (A P) — One of the nation’s largest nuclear power plants was left nearly unguarded dur­ ing a time when federal officials requested intensified security precautions because of an expected terrorist attack, a newspaper says. 
Although Commonwealth Edison, operator of tin* plant, issued public assurances that the plant was under extra-heavy guard, its guards had in fact w alked out in a labor dispute, according to a copy­ righted story in The Daily Dispatch of Moline, 
The newspaper said it learned about the walkout 
Wednesday night from former guards at the plant. 
Officials of the electric company confirmed the story 
Thursday. 
The Quad Cities plant here, built in 1972 along the 
Mississippi River in northwestern Illinois, is one of the nation’s largest, generating 1.6 million kilowatts of electricity. 
The federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission alert­ ed officials at nuclear plants throughout the nation in 
May 1976 to the possibility of a terrorist attack during the Memorial Day weekend. 
Officials of 
Commonwealth 
Edison and lowa-Illinots Gas and Electric Co., which owns 25 per cent of the plant, issued statements at the time saying that guards had been added lo tlit* security force and that exotic electronic devices would protect the plant from any terrorist threat. 
The attack never materialized but a dozen guards walked off the job. The guards were employes of 
Pinkerton’s, a private security and detective firm. 
A former plant security official said the electronic security devices were nearly useless on the day of the walkout because steam and wet weather caused the alarms “ to go off one after another," the newspaper said. 
The ispatch reported in earlier stories that the 
F B I was investigating allegations by former guards that security and safety procedures at the Cordova generating plant were lax. 
Failure of the guards to report for work left a Pin­ kerton captain and a guard borrowed from another 
Commonwealth Edison plant at Morris as the only security personnel on duty, the newspaper said.

W ASHIN GTO N (A P ) 
— Teamsters President 
Frank E. Fitzsimmons and three other long-time trustees of the union’s seandal-scarred CentraI 
States pension fund re­ signed Friday, the Labor 
Department announced. 
Hie resignations were part of an agreement with the government, which promised in return to drop plans for a law­ suit and to restore the fund s tax exemption. 
Labor Secretary Ray 
M arshall said he was pleased by the resigna­ tions. He called it “ a further indication that the fund is entering a new era of its operations.'’ 
Marshall said. “ It now appears likely that li­ tigation over the fund's procedures for asset management will not be necessary.’’ However, the secretary added that this still depended on whether the complete agreement is carried out. 
Since 1975 
The government has been investigating the fund since 1975 because of allegations that its as­ sets were mismanaged and that it maintained ties to organized crime. 
In his letter of resigna­ tion addressed to the board. 
Fitzsimmons 

 defended the turui s operation. He made no mention of the Labor 
Department investiga­ tion. saying only that the 
1974 federal pension reform law made it im­ possible for him to pre­ side over both the opera­ tion of the fund and the union. 
Resigning in addition to Fitzsimmons were un­ ion official Roy Williams and management repre­ sentatives John Spieker- man and Andrew 
G 
Massa. They were the last remaining trustees whose terms of office began before Oct. 26, 
1976. Their replacements have not been appointed. 
Fitzsimmons said his responsibilities to the fund have been fulfilled with the restoration of the fund's tax-exempt ion by the Internal Revenue 
Service and the selection of an outside asset man­ ager. 

The agreement, worked out last month among trustees for the 
$1.4 billion pension fund, the 
Labor 
Department and the IRS, called for the fund to turn over control of its assets to outsiders. On April 14, the trustees agreed to transfer control of the fund’s securities to 
Crocker National Bank of 
San Francisco.

Research goes to pot 

BRO W NSVILLE, (A P) 
— A New Je rse y man was given a 
1o-year probated sentence F r i­ day for possession of marijuana after telling the judge he participated in t he venture lo research material for a book. 

William Arthur Foley. 
5o, was arrested by South 
Padre Island police on 
Jan. 24 in a raft contain­ ing 3oo pounds of the il­ legal weed. Police also seized Ox bottles of ha­ shish oil valued at 
$15o,ooo, eight LDS tab­ lets and some uniden­ tified pills. A second man on the raft escaped.

SHOP M O NDA Y THRU SATURDAY IO A.M. ’TIL 9 P.M. 
J 

WASHINGTON (A P) - Independent oilmen are halfway home in their ef­ forts to regain a $3o m illion tax advantage they lost in 1976. 
The Senate on Friday passed a tax bill which includes repeal of the 13 per cent minimum tax levied on certain intangible drilling costs in 1976. The provision was inserted in the bill by the Senate Thursday at the request of 
Sen. Lloyd Bentsen. D-Tex. The bill now goes to a conference committee. 
Bentsen, like many Texas legisla­ tors. thinks the independent drillers are the most effective people in the energy production industry when it comes to presenting their case to Con­ gress. 
“ They’ll bring their tax returns right into your office and show you exactly where it's hurting them ,’' 
Bentsen said. 

The independents started lobbying in force this year when their tax accoun­ tants gave thorn the bad news about the impact of the 1976 law on income taxes. Some said they would have to reduce exploratory drilling by as much as 3o per cent, Bentsen said. 

They were especially annoyed that corporations were not subject to the same provision. They said it gave the major oil companies unfair advantages in the search for oil. When President 
Carter said he favored eliminating that advantage, Bentsen acted, without waiting for Carter to send his legisla­ tion to Congress. 

The intangibles drilling deduction is a complicated provision. Basically, it is an accelerated depreciation privilege for oil drilling investment.

G R E A T E R SAN ANTONIO 

Rains roll into state 

ASSO C IATED PRESS 
Booming thunderstorms sprinkled with at least one tornado rolled across a vast section of West and 
Central Texas and the South Plains Friday after­ noon. dampening most Texans's outlook for a nice weekend. 
A funnel cloud was sighted five miles northeast of 
Chillocothe in Wilbarger County. 
Rainfall rates ranged from a quarter inch to a half inch per hour in North Central Texas along a line from San Angelo to San Saba, with Brownwood receiving a lot of rain. One Brownwood radio station told the National Weather Service that 3V2 inches fell in four hours. 
In a 24-hour period that ended Friday morning, 
2.35 inches of rain fell at Tahoka near Lubbock. 
Outside the storm areas, winds were from the south to southeast ut five to 15 miles an hour. A stationary front located in the Panhandle caused winds to be from the northeast.

Son Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S— Saturday April 3o 1977 
Nuclear material escort proposed 

NEW YOUK TIMES SERVICE 

SALZBURG, Austria — 
An American expert on nuclear policies called 
Friday for the creation of an international escort service for uranium and other sensitive materials to prevent diversion or hijacking. 
The expert, Paul Le- venthal, referred to the reported disappearance of 2oo tons of uranium ore w hile it was being shipped from Belgium to1 
Italy in a West German vessel eight years ago. 
The cargo is believed to have reached Israel. 
Leventhal, a former counsel to the U.S. Sen­ ate Government Opera­ tions C om m ittee, ad­ dressed a Conference for a Non-Nuclear Future that began here Friday. 
Counterbalance 

The gathering, attend­ ed by alm ost IOO scien­ tists, environmentalists and antinuclear activists from 21 countries, is meant to counterbalance a large two-week confer­ ence sponsored by the 
International 
Atomic 
Energy Agency, a United 
Nations body, that will start in Salzburg Mon­ day 

Discussing the uranium shipment that vanished in 1968, Leventhal said intelligence services o f several nations had investigated the case, but eventually closed their files 
"without positively locating the hi­ jacked uranium/' 

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S— Saturday April 3o 1977 

Leading officials of the 
United Nations agency, which has headquarters in Vienna, and top ex­ perts from the United 
States, the Soviet Union and other m em ber countries will be here for the forthcoming Interna­ tional Conference on Nu­ clear Power and its Fuel 
Cycle. 
D iscussing the uran­ ium shipment that van­ ished in 1968, Leventhal said intelligence services of several nations had in­ vestigated the case, but eventually closed their files “without positively locating the hijacked ur­ anium.” 
In an interview the 
American expert said he had received “ primary information” on the 19«R uranium incident from a source outside the United 
States. He noted that 
Euratom , the nuclear agency of the European 

 community, had been re­ sponsible for the uran­ ium shipment, but that effective controls had apparently been lacking. 
Collusion 
Leventhal said he had no evidence pointing to possible collusion among 
Belgium, Italy and Israel or two of the three in the 
1968 uranium theft. He suggested the Brussels headquarters of Euratom must possess more facts. 
The American expert also declared it was less im portant to which country the uranium ore went in 1968 than to make sure diversions could not recur today since proce­ dures for shipping uran­ ium have not changed since 1968 and advanced technologies would make it possible soon — or had made it possible already 
—■ to extract weapons grade plutonium from 

 relatively small amounts of uranium in clandestine 
“ garage reprocessing” operations. 
A European expert who wanted to remain anony­ mous asserted here that the 2oo tons of uranium ore, presumably from the 
Congo, in the 1968 inci­ dent had been “sold and bought on the high seas three tim es.” 
In F riday’s address, 
Leventhal urged that the; 
7o inspectors of the Vien- j na agency, who were su- J pervising the safeguards system, be better trained and “less subject to inti­ m idation by host cou n tries” than at present. 
The effectiveness of the 
United Nations agency’s safeguards system will be discussed during the forthcom ing Salzburg conference. 
Elvis’ pact may be sold 
NASHVILLE, Tenn 
(AP) — After 22 years, 
FJvis P resley and his manager reportedly are splitting up. 
Friday’s 
N ashville 
Banner quoted sources saying Col. Tom Parker has offered to sell his contract with Presley.

EXPRESS NEWS 
EDITORIALS 

W illiam J. R eddell 

E d ito r o f E d ito ria l P a g e 

C harles O . Kilpatrick 

E d ito r a n d Pub lisher 

G eorge Carmack 
Associate Editor 

Pone I. Burt 

M a n a g in g E d ito r 

Gas storage bill 

 would aid consum er 

If Sen. Bill Moore of Bryan doesn’t understand it, some others may need further ex­ planation, too. 

Moore led the charge to turn back legislation to allow Lo-Va- ca Gathering Co., and any others sim ilarly situated, to acquire underground space in which to store natural gas. 

Lo-Vaca serves Moore’s arca, as it does most of a wide South 
Texas gas-using region. Moore told the Senate this week that he w ouldn’t do anything to help 
Lo-Vaca. 

His constituents should see whether he will do something to help them. 

Gas storage, which Lo-Vaca lacks, would allow the company to buy gas at the most-advanta­ geous times and store it for use during critical times. Storage would also make less likely cur­ tailment to the users. Storage would allow' better use of take- or-pay provisions in contracts, which use would give customers the best price available. Storage gives flexibility in the market that lack of storage prevents. 

The other point that Sen. 
Moore overlooks is that Lo-Vaca is about to be cast adrift from the Coastal States Gas Corp. 
Under settlem ent term s that appear likely to be adopted, that company will be merged with other Coastal States companies into what is now being called 
New Company, and that com ­ pany will serve Sen. Moore’s constituents. 

Storage will give those con­ stituents the best break possi­ ble. Lack of storage will pena­ lize them in terms of both price and availability of gas with more threat of curtailment. 

The legislation would allow condemnation of space (aban­ doned oil fields) with appro­ priate payment for the rights. 
The legislation protects the sur­ face rights of owners and even allows for drilling above or be­ low the storage space. 

It further requires Lo-Vaca to purchase by negotiation at least 
(IO per cent of a site before con­ demnation could be used. 

Well-to-user gas supply is too inflexible for consumers’ good. 

It’s a good country that lets 
Mxon tell his side o f story 

We doubt that Richard Nixon is naive enough to believe he will have the last word on Wa­ tergate. 

Nixon should tell his side of the story, even though he should know that it will be subject to evaluation of others. Among those others, it was announced this week, will be the Watergate 
Special 
Prosecutor 
Leon 
Jaworski. 

Jaworski said he “ absolutely will” challenge the former pre­ sident if Nixon fails to come to grips factually with his role in 
Watergate. 

It is probable that there are no surprises left in the telling of an event unique in American history — the forced resignation of a president. It is probable 

 that interviewer David Frost will be more successful than the 
House Committee on the Judi­ ciary or the Watergate Special 
Prosecutor in getting Nixon to concede what the tapes told 
Jaworski and, eventually, the committee. 
We feel good about the country, however, because Nix­ on can have national television to tell his story. We can recall the era of the 195os when per­ sons unfairly attacked as being 
Communists couldn’t get a hearing — fair or otherwise. 
And Nixon is getting paid rather well for privilege. 
We also feel good about the level of accountability 
W atergate forced upon a go­ vernm ent, in several areas, which had become careless about.that essential function. 

Let free enterprise try 

On-again, off-again planning for a new hotel in San Antonio is* disconcerting. 

City Council has offered gen­ erous help in several forms on’ the strong suggestion that in­ vestors were ready to build. It may well be time to let free en­ terprise have its head — with its own money and on its own land 
— like other hotels that have been built here. 
The business potential for 

 hotel service can be evaluated through the Convention Bur­ eau ’s bookings and recent trends in tourism and conven­ tion business. The 1973 econo­ mic studies in the 
River 
Corridor study can form the base from which up-dated studies can be made. 

The city has done its share with the continuing help being limited to encouragement to in­ vestors ready to talk business. 

The Presidents tt'aht, we must allroake 
SsariPiQeS using fuel. 

O 

Double dippers 

Sir: As yet, no one with service during our recent wars and police actions overseas and as a civil service board official has explained the effects of “double-dipping.” 

At present there are more than 
15o,ooo military retirees who used veteran preference plus 5 or IO extra percentage points added to their civil service exams to obtain civil service jobs and re-enter government service, receiving full pay and fringe benefits on their new jobs while also receiving tax-paid pensions, medical and dental care, discount foods, clothing, mer­ chandise, and other tax-paid life time benefits for themselves and their de­ pendents. Their cost-of-living benefits apply to pensions and job salaries. All other retirees re-entering government service have their pensions, etc., de­ ducted from the pay, etc., of their new jobs. 

As of April I. 1977, the average U.S. officer retiree’s pension is $16,139 a' year and his tax-paid benefits increase that by from IO per cent to 2o per cent, all for just 2o years service. Enlisted personnel average approximately- 
$6,ooo a year with added tax-paid benefits, th e records indicate few' of the 1,o96,184 retirees as of June 3o, 
1976, are career combat personnel. 

Double-dippers often arrange sever­ al months in advance of their retire­ ment to keep their old military jobs open for six months after retirement, at which point it is converted to civi­ lian type, and they re-enter govern­ ment service by selection of an old buddy still on active duty or by a double-dipping friend who does the interviewing and selecting. There are numerous ways to contravent the merit system, too many for this space. 

Many internal civil service promo­ tion plans provide extra credit for any type of military service and some use the actual years, etc. Career civil service employes with 15 to 25 years service and outstanding performance records are unable to advance because of double-dipper selection by the 
“ buddy” or similar systems, in re- ductions-in-forcc, double-dippers are the “ untouchables” while others with 
25 or 3o years service are fired. 

Thousands of double-dippers have used their military service credit to qualify for civil service retirement to obtain higher pensions from the Civil 
Service Retirement System without reimbursing the CSRS for all service as regular career civil service person­ nel are required to from their pay. By giving up a lower pension for a higher one, the double-dipper retires as a civilian employe yet retains military retiree benefits plus civil service re­ tiree benefits. Thousands go lo work for states, counties and municipal governments, also tax-paid, and Tex­ as, California and Florida lead the nation is double-, triple- and even quadruple-dippers from tax-paid funds. 

Unless Congress gets a grip on the 
“dipping” and related abuses along with the pension proliferation, greedy pensioners among military retirees will help cause a taxpayer revolt or 
“dip” taxpayers into bankruptcy.

TO THE EDITOR

A ntonio, TX 7 8 2 9 7 . 

W riter clarifies his sentence 

Dear Sir: In retrospect it seems necessary to clarify a sentence in my letter (Glad opinion on sex not shared) in which reference was made to priests and nuns. The key word in the sentence is “ honestly” and could be disregard­ ed by some. Nuns and priests were referred to because they arc probably the only professionals whose vocation requires abstinence from sex. 
My letter should also have stated that those who feel it necessary to tell people of their moral purity don’t have the basic human qualities to be accepted as workers in the programs involving priests and nuns. These dedicated people, also Salvation Army people, get personally involved in salvaging those residents of all our cities who have been discarded and shunned by our society. How many of us, including those self-proclaimed morally pure, have compassion for an unknown down-and-outer? 
Hopefully, those who feel compelled to write letters of righteous wrath about my previous letter will be mol­ lified by this one. 
W . McCracken 

Berry's 
World 

Lawrence Davis 
‘CTnou, Harold* having to drive a small car won t be all 
THAT bad!’ 
Sailors want old clothes back 

WASHINGTON 
It has to be one of the great ironies in the social history of the United 
States. 
Back in 1971, when bellbottoni trousers were the sartorieal rage am ong civilians and dungarees represented the national youth uni­ form, the Navy abandoned both. 
Now, after six unhappy years with a shoddy coat-and-tie combination that former Chief of Naval Opera­ tions Elmo R. Zumwalt selected to replace the 2oo-year-old traditional sailor suit, the enlisted rank and file of the Navy have voted overwhelm­ ingly to turn back the clock. 
Testimony 

Adm. J. L. Holloway III, Zumwalt's successor, has testified personally to the depth of the sailors' feelings on this issue and has committed the 
Navy in principle to bring back 
“bells,” as the old uniform is known on the lower decks. 
This decision, which has increased 

Holloway’s already strong popularity with his enlisted men, Is at least in part a proof of the power of the press. 

Back last summer, aware of the smoldering issue, Navy Times, the independent weekly widely read among sailors and Marines, decided to run a poll on old-style sailor suits vs. 
Zumwalt-model coat-and-tie 
“ square rigs.” 
Surprise 
Navy Times has now disclosed — somewhat even to its o w t i surprise — that at least 8o,ooo sailors out of a 
524,ooo-man Navy want the sailor suit back. 
Both that response and the verdict were overwhelming: 87 per cent of those jmlled favored the traditional rig. Entire ships’ companies sent in bundled-up unanimous votes. 
While the Navy Times landslide — which at its height swamped com­ puters called in to handle the votes — was unanswerable, the Navy likewise undertook a parallel poll using 

Col. 
Robert I). 
Bein! Jr. 

 scientific opinion-sampling tech­ niques. 
The results of the official survey ran within one pereentage-point of the Navy Times findings. 
The underlying issues of the sai- lor-suit controversy present a bland of subjective feelings on both sides and hardheaded questions of cost and utilitarianism. 
Zumwalt said the old rig was “de­ meaning” and that it was offensive to sailors “to dress like children.” 
On the other hand, the Navy Times results indicate that sailors want to look like sailors and the girls, sweethearts and wives alike agree. 
There was and is no argument as lo relative cost. In 1971 dollars, when 

 the decision was made, the oldtime uniform cost an enlisted man $21.5o; the new model costed out at $1o8. The fancy new cap, with removable covers, exceeded $1o; the little old white hat was 75 cents. 
The new square rig proved to be hotter and more constricting than bellbottoms and jumpers and took up excessive added space aboard al­ ready overcrowded ships. 
Its white shirts (unlike a white jumper) couldn’t be laundered in a bucket, while the costly cap — many of which got blown overboard the first day at sea — wilted in the first rain-squall. 
By contrast, you could wash the old white hat in a bucket of sea water. 

Advantage 
One little known advantage of the old sailor suit — which today’s Na­ vy men fondly rem em ber as they struggle with the new model — is that it didn’t have to be pressed. 
If folded correctly, both trousers and juniper were designed to be 

 rolled into compact bundles, thrown into the bottom of a seabag and worn for inspection a year, a hemisphere, or another cruise away. 
In contrast, the Zumwalt model requires dry cleaning and pressing for every wear. can’t be rolled into anything but a ball. won’t stow in a seabag and requires steam-irons and ironing boards iii every com part­ ment. 
Communists 

If. as bas been maintained by all parties, the cosmetic notion of image is and was central to the decision, it is interesting to see the approach ta­ ken on the same question by the only image-makers with higher horse­ power than Madison Avenue, the 
Communists. 
In the Soviet Navy, which now has the world’s richest, best and most ships, the sailors wear short haircuts, dress jumpers, bellbottoms and old- time Navy “ flat hats.” 
And the Russian girls ashore just lap it up. 

A greem ent with writer Heard 

Sir: I am happy to learn that C.C. 
Heard and I have hit upon a common ground of agreement (Letters, April 
27>. And there is more. 

I, too, do not want the Panama Canal given away, after the money and lives we poured into its creation. 
Also credit goes to us through the marvelous work of Col. Geo. W. 
Goethals that made that yellow fever infested land liveable. 
Mr. Heard and I share an apprecia­ tion of the columns of Steve Dunleavy, who is tucked in the back of that otherwise gossip publication, “ The 
Star,” He is an excellent writer. I wonder how many miss his articles 
{since not everyone thrives on the pre­ dominating contents of that magazine. 

Of course I especially approved of his columns of April 17 and 24. Stran­ gely I had mailed my letter on the persecution of Richard Nixon to the 
Express in April then read the Dun­ leavy viewpoint on the same subject two days later. His explanations for the attempted bugging of Watergate and 
McGovern’s friendliness toward Cas­ tro are worthy of a front page. 

I ain not alone in thinking that 
Dunleavy’s articles are misplaced. He deserves a more fitting setting in Sun­ day’s Express-News. 
I, too, like Ronald Reagan, as does 
Mr. Heard, bul I believe that the fact that President Carter is a nuclear physicist gives him knowledge that may serve us well, as we deal with the 
Russians in the coming years. I like 
Jimmy Carter’s dedication lo what he believes is right. No one man has all the answers. 
Beulah P. Sherrill 

Nuclear debate separates friends 

WASHINGTON - In the first historic chapter of the atomic age — from Hiroshima at the end of World War II through the worst part of the Cold War — nuclear power divided the Unit­ ed States from its enemies and adversaries, but now it seems to be dividing us as well from our friends. 
We seem to be at odds with many nations that are fundamental to our hope of creating a more stable world order in the last quarter of the century, and precisely over the dilemma of how­ to develop nuclear power for peaceful purposes and at the same time restrain its development as an instrument of war. 
These nations include, among others. West Germany, France, and to a lesser extent Britain in Western 
Europe; Yugoslavia at a critical point in its transition in Eastern Europe; 
Israel and Iran in the Middle East; 
China in East Asia; India and Pakistan in South Asia, and Brazil in Latin 
America. 
Not at issue 
This week’s news out of Washington and Bonn illustrates what is and what is not at issue. 
What is not at issue is the need to develop nuclear power as one impor­ tant substitute for the high-priced and dwindling resources of oil and gas, w hose reserves lie mainly in one of the most unstable and unpredictable poli­ tical areas of the world. 
What is at issue is how this is to be done. 
The Carter administration has of­ fered to cooperate with other nations in the development of nuclear power that 
•cannot easily be diverted into the pro­ duction of nuclear weapons. 
It wants stiff international agree­ ments to avoid the spread of such weapons and has asked Congress for authority to impose hard penalties on nations that violate agreements for the control of nuclear arms. 
Other problems 
President Carter has other prob­ lems. 
His decision to hold up work on this country’s own fasl-breeder nuclear reactors — the most productive but dangerous type — has also provoked the opposition of this country’s major nuclear technology producers. 
For example, Robert E. Kirby, chairman of Westinghouse Electric 
Corp., which has designed the nation’s first large-scale indust rial fast breeder plant in Tennessee, told his share­ holders this week that in his opinion it was “most unwise” for Carter to opt out of the breeder reactor race since, he said, breeder reactors promise en­ ergy resources equal to at least three times those represented by all Middle 
East oil reserves. 
At the same time, the United States is being accused by Brazil and other developing countries of wanting to hold nuclear weapons itself and deny them lo others; to rely on slow nuclear reactors, but to deny fast nuclear breeders to other nations that are try­ ing to catch up to the modern world. 
Brazil not alone 
And Brazil is not alone. China will not sign the treaty forbidding the spread or prior use of nuclear wea­ pons, and neither will Israel. 
Sometimes in the life of a nation, they say, they must be free to use any weapon at their command, and they add, when the argument is pushed to the extremity, that the United States ought to understand this after Hiro­ shima. 
This is a hard but rather unfair pro­ position to put to Carter. 
Ile is not trying to stop the develop­ ment of nuclear industrial power; he is trying to gel control of the military arms race. 
Ile is not really opting out of the competition with Germany, France, 
Britain and others for the “major fu­ ture industry” of fasl-breeder reac­ tors. 
Too dangerous 
He is merely saying that this race is' too dangerous without much more stringent controls and trying lo set an example of self-denying restraint which he hopes the other major nu­ clear powers will eventually follow. 
So far. there is no evidence that they will, though Chancellor Schmidt indi­ cated that if all others would agree, he would, too. 
This could be a useful discussion at next week’s summit meeting of the leaders of the industrial world in Lon­ don. 
The pronouncements on atomic po­ licy of the past few days and weeks sound ominous, but fortunately, there is a long lag between pronouncements and production. 
Three years 
It will be at least three years before the first elem ents of the German fast-breeder technology can be put in place in Brazil, and between eight and lh years before the whole system will be in production. 
By that time, Chancellor Schmidt, 
President Giseard d ’Estaing of 
France, and even Jimmy Carter will ' probably all be gone from office; and then they may be judged, not by whether they won the reactor race but by whether they brought the nuclear arms race under control. 

Cool9 calm Lila blazed her own trail to success 

As cool, calm and collected as the deodorant commercial pro­ m ises, Lila Cockrell was ready to blaze a trail into the mayor’s office years before she did. 
“ In the late 196o's, I certainly would have entertained the thought of being m ayor,’’ says Mrs. Cockrell from her spacious City Hall office. 
“ But, I didn’t think it would be pos­ sible for a w om an.” 
Between the late 196o's and 1975, however, winds shifted and attitudes changed. Women across the country were slowly getting themselves elected to judgeships, to m ayor’s offices. 
“ It encouraged m e that it was not an im p o s s ib le d r e a m for m e to be m ay o r,” explains the 55-year-old wo­ man, who just em erged from a turbu­ lent re-election ca m p a ig n with the sweet taste of victory. 
Unlikely 

At first glance the middle-aged wo­ man is an unlikely candidate for trail blazer. 
She looks too proper — dressed in her tasteful m a tr o n ’s clothes. But, you’ll notice she doesn’t wear m any pastels. H er tastes in colors run stronger. And, it doesn’t take long to sense the other stren g th s in her. Lila 
C ockrell knows w h at s h e ’s doing. 
W'hen she began her 1975 term in office. San Antonio was the largest U.S. city ever lo elect a w om an m ayor. It still is. 

 cloud her face. She can handle indivi­ duals the same way. 
She’s cooperative about information. 
She tries to give w hat’s requested. But, by no means is the m ayor long-winded. 
She’s not one for elaborating. 
At times there seem s to be a shyness in her brown eyes, in her laugh. It’s not som ething you expect in a person of power. 
“ Som etim es people th in k I’m too distant, reserved and that bothers me. 
I'm not that way . . . I don’t feel I hold back,” the mayor says leaning quietly on her half-circle desk.

. . . I want to try to maintain my relation­ ship with a person even if we disagree on an issue

Cockrell acquired a re p u ta ­ tion for deciphering m u m b o ju m b o al­ most instantaneously. 
O ther stories circu lated about her w eren ’t as flattering. They said she was too com posed, too much like a program m ed computer. 
Cool 
She is cool. She politely handles the crow ds and row dies at City Council m eetings without letting an emotion 

 part of her personality. But, she also tries consciously not to over-react. 

“ The main thing is not to take things personally . . . I want to try to maintain my relationship with a person even if we disagree on an issue. 

“ Also, I g u es s i f s s o m e th in g I learned from debate,” she continues.

Bus riders get a break 

San Antonio Transit System trustees gave the go-ahead Friday to two pilot program s for bus riders. 
One will be aim ed at handicapped people — the other at governm ent employes. 
The handicapped program will iden­ tify where riders with mobility im ­ p airm en ts are located. From this, potential routes will'be developed. 
The government employe program is designed to determ ine if those working 

 in the federal courthouse and at City 
Water Board, which is nearby, will use an express bus. 
It will run betw een W onderland 
Shopping City and the governm ent complex, starting in mid-May. 
Trustees also heard a report from 
Tom Fuller, general m anager, that riders increased 3 per cent last month over the sam e month a y ear ago. 
F uller also advised revenues are running $99,ooo ahead of projections.

TAX CUT 

Continued from Page IA a f te rw a rd . P a s s a g e by the H ouse would make it the first part of C arter’s econom ic stim u lu s package to clear 
Congress. 
Still awaiting action are a separate 
$4.1 billion public service jobs bill and a revenue-sharing m easure. 
The m ajor difference in the Senate version of the tax bill is it contains no provision for the 
$5o-per-person rebate that Carter originally asked as the centerpiece of his plan to pump up the economy. 
After the House passed the bill con­ taining the rebates, Carter changed his m ind, saying the econom y had im ­ proved so much that the $1o.4 billion wort Ii of rebates no longer w as needed. 
The Senate simply snipped out the re ­ bate clause and the House was expect­ ed to conform. 
June I cut 
Withholding rates would be cut June 
I to reflect the increases in the stan ­ dard deduction. 
Although the re b a te s are m issing from the Senate bill, it generally is agreed that the tax cuts costing $24 billion over two years will have some beneficial effect on the economy. 
In addition to the increased standard deduction for individuals, the bill ex­ te n d s th ro u g h 1978 th re e e x is tin g benefits: 
• A $35-per-person tax credit first approved in 1975. 
• The earned-income credit of up to 
$4oo for poor working families. 
• Reduced corporate tax rates. 
Business incentive 

T h e bill in c lu d e s in c re a s e d tux breaks to give business an incentive for hiring new workers and purchasing 

 new equipment in an effort to fight the recession. 
Also in the bill are a one-year delay in a 1976 law that virtually eliminates the tax-free status of sick pay; a $25o tax credit — subtracted directly from taxes owed — for persons who keep a dependent over 65 years of age in their home and a feature that would allow 
96 per cent of all taxpayers to compute their taxes by using new, simplified tax tables. 

Increases 

The bill didn t contain good news for everyone. An estim ated $1.7 million ta x p a y e rs — m ainly sin g le persons earning more than $13,75o a year — would face a tax increase averaging 
$5o b e c a u s e of the c h a n g e in the standard deduction. 
The governm ent began the public w o rk s jobs p r o g ra m la st y e a r by spending $2 billion on local projects, but it got $24 billion in applications from local governments. 
V irtually all of this y e a r 's money w ill be spent on existing applications. 
B ig c itie s c o m p la in e d that last y e a r ’s pro g ram set as id e too much money for areas that had no real un­ employment problem. As a result the new legislation distributes 65 per cent of the funds on the basis of the number of unemployed in each state. The other 
35 per cent is given to states which have had unemployment rates over 6.5 p er cent. In March, the national un­ employment rate was 7.3 per cent, but it varied sharply from state to stab1. 
Also added lo the bill was a prov ision that Carter cannot drop any water or dam projects unless he gets congres­ sional approval.

“ I was always drawn to that sort of thing.” 
Throughout high school and college, sh e w as w orking with an d g e ttin g e le c te d to offices in p o litic a l and church oriented organizations. 
Serious interests for a young woman. 
But, she is careful to point out — lest you get the wrong idea — that she is not all work and no play. 
She won a number of trophies for her intram ural sports activities — “ I hit a m ean Ping-Pong ball. 
“ I liked the social life. I liked dates and p arties.” So did the girls she grew up with. 
But, they planned to focus on social life and civic work after college. She wanted something more. 
Career 
“ I rem em b er when I was ll years old, I was thinking about a career. I wanted to be a lawyer or a minister. At that tim e there were no women minis­ te rs ,” she says and then laughs. “ And there were few women law yers.” 
In college she was planning to be a 
YWCA director. That changed when sh e m a r r ie d 
Sid an d had two daughters. 
But, she still managed to carry on her political and church work. 
“ I saw myself first of all as a wo­ m an. I was very happily m a rrie d . I tried to be a good mother and I tried to see that my activities d id n 't disturb m y happy home. 
As it turned out, Mrs. Cockrell says her activities added a dimension to her home. 
“ lf a w om an has p o ten tial to do things and doesn’t do them . . . it's fru stratin g for her and it spills over into everything else.” 
Mrs. Cockrell used her potential as a wife-m other-worker combo. 
Nursery 
At one point she organizea a nursery co-op for League of Women Voters — so women with children could attend. 
T h e y ’d all bring their ch ild ren and m eet ut her home. 
“ W'e’d chip in a quarter to pay for the babysitter,” the m ayor says. 
She served twice as president of the 
L eague of Women Voters before she was first elected to the City Council in 
1963. 
Until this year’s race when she ran as an independent, she had always run on the Good Government League tick­ et. 
“ I was glad to be able to win as an independent,” she says. She also says th is y e a r ’s cam paign ag a in st b u sin­ essm an John Monfrey was her rough­ 

 est one yet. She dqpsn’t want to talk much about it. 
CBS-TV, the New York Tim es, the 
W7all S tre et Jo u rn al, the nation fol­ lowed her campaign. 
She said a Wall Street Jo u rn al re­ p o rte r w as a bit shocked w hen he called City Hall to find her and was told she was out grocery shopping. 
The m ayor was seemingly am used by the reporter’s reaction. “ Certainly I want to be mayor. But, I still want to be myself.” 
Why h as th is 55-year-old w om an been successful? 
She pauses. The brown eyes behind the owlish glasses aren’t revealing. “ I 

If a woman has poten­ tial to do things and doesn't do them . . . it's frustrating fo r her and it spills over into every­ thing else 

 don’t want to talk too much about it. 
The r e a s o n s a r e p e rso n a l. I have strong religious feelings.” 
She pauses again. “ If we are open and allow it, God uses us.” 
“ But, I ’m not trying to use religion,” she cautions. She doesn’t want her be­ liefs misunderstood. 
When 1979 rolls around will she run again? 
“ I think there are some people who live one term in office wondering about the next office. I, frankly, would rather do my job now.”

Incom e tax simplification demonstrated 

WASHINGTON (AP) — Here are examples of how filing a federal incone tax return would be simplified under a bill passed by the Senate on Friday. 
One example is for a $15,UUo-a-year family of four that takes the standard deduction, the other for the sam e family with $4,o9o of itemized deductions. 
The net tax in the first ex a m p le is based on the higher standard deduction approved by the Senate. 
Standard Deduction 
CURRENT LAW 
1. Write down adjusted gross income ($15,ooo). 
2. Compute standard deduction, which is 16 percent of income but not less than $2,1oo nor more than $2,8oo 
($2,4oo). 
3. Subtract deduction from income ($12,6oo). 
4. Multiply exemptions by $75o ($3,ooo). 
5. Subtract that from line 3 ($9,6oo). 
6. Find tax iii tax table ($1,727). 
7. Compute general lax credit by m ultiplying the num ber of exemptions by $35 or by taking 2 per cent of line 5, up to SISO (SISO). 
8. Subtract general credit from line 6 to get net tax 
($1,547). 
PROPOSED LAW 
1. Writedown adjusted gross income ($15,ooo). 
2. Find tax iii tax table ($1,375). 
Itemized Deductions 
CURRENT LAW 
1. Writedown adjusted gross income ($15,ooo). 
2. Writedown itemized deductions ($4,ooo). 
3. Subtract deductions from income (SI 1.ooo). 
4. Multiply exemptions by $75o ($3,ooo). 
5. Subtract that Irom line 3 ($8,ooo). 
6. Find lax in tax table ($1,375. 
7. Compute general tax credit by m ultiplying the num ber of exemptions by $35 or taking 2 per cent of lines, up lo $18o ($16o). 
8. Subtract general credit from line 6 lo get net tax 
($1,215). 
PROPOSED LAW 
1. W rite down adjusted gross income ($15,ooo). 
2. W rite down itemized deductions ($4,ooo). 
3. W rite down new standard deduction for couples 
($3,2oo). 
4. S u b tra c t line 3 from lin e 2 to get ex c es s of itemized deductions over standard deduction ($8oo). 
5. S u b tra c t line 4 from a d ju s te d g ro s s incom e 
($14,2oo). 
6. F in d tax in tux ta b le ($1,215).
