Cost-of-living raise to food stamp users 

San Antonio EXPRE5S-NEWS— Saturday April 3o 1977 
Page I 3 A 

WASHINGTON (A P) 
— Most needy persons getting government food stamps will receive a cost-of-living increase ranging from $2 to more than $8 a month begin­ ning July I, the Agricul­ ture 
Department said today. 

Officials said the boost, which will vary with the size of the household, will be the first for food stamp families in 18 months. A family of four, 

 for example, will get food stamps worth $17o a month begilining July I, compared with $186 cur­ rently, a level set on Jan. 
I of last year. 

About 17.8 million per­ sons — nearly 5.6 mil­ lion households — re­ ceived 'food stamps in 
February, the most re­ cent (JSDA tabulation showed. Federal cost of the program is currently estimated at around $5.5 billion annually. 

The present food stamp program requires that a participating family buy a certain amount of food stamps at face value in order to get free “ bonus” coupons which provide more buying power at food stores. The amount of the purchase require­ ment and the bonus varies according to fami­ ly net income. 

For example, a family of four with an adjusted net income of $19o to $21o 

 a month pays $53 to get a total of $166 in stamps, a bonus of $113 in free coupons. On July I, the same family w ill get $17o in stamps for $53, a bon­ us of $117. 
As a family's income rises, the purchase requirement goes up and the amount of bonus de­ clines. Beginning at a net income of $54o a month, for example, a four- member household will have to pay $146 to get 
$17o worth of stamps. 

Conversely, at the lower end of the income scale, the purchase requirement declines, so that at $3o a month ad­ justed income or less a four-member family will get $17o worth of stamps free of charge. 
Although the benefits vary greatly according to household size and in­ come, food stamp recipients nationally get about 
$1o worth of stamps for each $4 they spend on them. 
Masseuses tile petition 

A revised challenge to the city's massage parlor regulatory ordinance will be heard May 9 in 166th 
District Court. 
A revised petition seeking a temporary injunction lo bar enforcement of certain sections of that ordinance has been filed by three women working or seeking employment as masseuses. 
A restraint bid was turned down earlier this week by 166th District Judge Peter Michael Curry 
The focus is on a section of the ordinance requir­ ing a masseuse candidate to complete three semes­ ter hours of applied anatomy and physiology in an institution accredited by the American Physical 
Therapy Association. 
The suit was filed by Michiko F. Clark, Barbara 
Miller (both masseuses and now employed) and 
Cindy Lee Anderson, who was denied a license because she has not taken the required course. 
The course, this suit notes, is not now available in 
San Antonio.

The Federal Reserve 
Board Friday turned down a proposed merger of Bexar County National 
Bank with Texas Com­ merce Bancshares of 
Houston. 
Hilmer Fahrenthold, chairman of Bexar Coun­ ty National, and Ben F. 
Love, chairman of Texas 
Commerce, expressed regret at the board’s de­ cision in a joint state­ ment. 
“ San Antonio is one of the fastest growing me­ tropolitan areas in the 
United 
States,” the statement said. 

“ The area’s increase in population, commerce and industry places it in great need of those di­ versified and specialized hanking services stem­ ming from such a bank­ ing consolidation.” 

Bryon LeFlore, presi­ dent of BCNB, said the denial will not mean any lessening of service by 
Bexar County National to its market.

Briscoe, Hill have first campaign clash 

MIDLAND 
(AF) 
- 
Texas Atty. Gen. John 
Hill and 
Gov. 
Dolph 
Briscoe stopped shadow-boxing and began swinging at each other this week in what observers felt was their first unofficial campaign skirmish for the 1978 
Democrat ic gubernator­ ial nomimation. 
Hill, who says he will not make an official an­ il uincemeni on the race until June, threw the first punches Thursday when he termed “ irre­ sponsible'’ statements by 
Gov. Briscoe about the possibility of cutting off the supply of Texas gas to other states. 
Briscoe’s comments came during a news con­ ference iii Houston Sa­ turday when he criticized 
President 
Carter’s recently proposed energy conservation and development program. 
Partisan 
Briscoe reacted to 
Hill's comments saying the attorney general was letting “ partisan poli­ ties” interfere iii matters of great concern to Tex­ ans. 
“ I stand by everything 
I have said about the 
Carter energy policy,” the governor said. “ If those who want to knuckle under to greater federal regulations and to the federal bu­ reaucracy want to cri­ ticize me, let them have at it. I have just begun to fight to protect the econ­ omy of our state." 
(in 
Friday. 
Hill traveled to 
Midland where he told the Mid­ land County Bar As­ sociation that Briscoe's opposition to Carter’s en­ ergy program was belat­ ed.' 

He said the governor had failed to influence 

G O V . BRISCOE, left, and A tty Gen. Hill 
Have thrown the first punches in their fight for the governor’s seat 

 the composition of the team that formulated the energy plan for Carter. 
He said 13 of the 15 men on the team were federal officials, and Texas was not represented by a sin­ gle member. 
“ If Gov. Briscoe had acted then to persuade 
President Carter that 
Texas should be repre­ sented, it is more than likely that we would hav e had some of our own ex­ perts on the team,” Hill said. 
“ Gov. 
Briscoe failed to take any effec­ tive action. He sat by while the policy was be­ ing finalized by someone else in Washington.” 
Hill added:“ Participa- tion iii the decision-mak­ ing process is more than threats to cut off gas to the other states, which would entail breaking solemn contracts, an op­ tion which has been ruled unconstitutional by our court system.” 
No influence 

Hill and Briscoe, how­ ever, appeared to agree on one point - Texas of­ ficials must present a united front. 

Hill said the thing to do now is to help “ the Texas congressional delegation sell a Texas viewpoint with reasonable ar­ 

 guments and solid facts,” and called on the governor to “ invite our state’s top experts to sit in with us and develop a battle plan.” 

Briscoe also referred to a united front Thursday saying, “ it is important that the public officials of 
Texas try to present a united front to Congress and the administration ... rather than let partisan politics interfere in a matter of vital impor­ tance to the future of our state.” 
Hill, 58 and in his second term as attorney general, has been visit­ ing different cities in the state lately discussing state affairs. 
While in Dallas Thurs­ day Hill spoke before a group of Mexican-Amer- icans. Most of the ques­ tions to Hill started: “ lf you are elected governor 

H a v w o rih case d ism isse d 

SANTA ANA, Calif. (AP) — A petition by Orange 
County to take control of the estate of actress Rita 
Hayworth was dismissed Friday because she has never officially resided within the county’s jurisdic­ tion. 
Superior Court Judge Claude M. Owens ordered the dismissal without comment after Miss Hayworth’s attorney. Leonard Monroe, argued that the actress’ permanent residence remains in Beverly Hills, which is ii adjacent Los Angeles County. 
The petition for temporary conservatorship includ­ ed un affidavit from r. Jam es Miner of Hoag 
Memorial Hospital in Newport Beach which said the 
58-year-old actress was “ gravely disabled as a result of mental disorder or impairment by chronic al­ coholism.” 

Miss Hayworth had been stav ing in Newport Beach when she was admitted earlier this year at Hoag 
Memorial Hospital for undisclosed reasons. 
It was not immediately known where the actress is currently staying. 
Monroe arrived and departed from the courthouse without comment and his office declined to give any further information on Miss Hayworth. 
Conservatorship proceedings were filed by eputy 
County Counsel Richard Oviedo on behalf of county . 
Public Guardian James Hein.

Galveston has 

C ity on an Island 
San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday April 3o 1977 Page 
T -B 

 magicai quality 

Galveston is a city in its own pattern. 
It has always been — and still is — a city like no other. 
It is not only a matter of geo­ graphy — 
Though Galveston is the only large se asid e city in North 
America completely on a natur­ al island. 
It is not only a m atter of history — 
Though Galveston has 8o Texas his­ to rical m a rk e rs ran g in g from one com m em orating the home port of the 
Navy of the Republic of Texas to one m arking an oleander that is a direct 

Galveston is som ething more than geograph y 
- — history 
— the scene {>f great tragedy 
— a show­ case o f 
Victorian ele­ gance... its excitement can only be felt. 

 descendant of the first oleander plant­ ed on G alveston Island. That w as in 
1841. 
It is not only that Galveston was the site of the worst disaster ever to hit the 
United States. 
At least 6,ooo lives were lost in the great Galveston storm of Sept. 8, 19oo. 
Comeback 
Or that Galveston is the only city in 
Am erica that cam e back from such a natural disaster and built a great pro­ tective wall 17 feet high along its ocean front. It now extends IO miles. 
To further safeguard the city — it pumped mud in for more than 7 years to raise the average level of the entire city eight feet. 
It is not only that Galveston has no rival in T exas ~ and few across the country — for its grand homes built in the elaborate style of about a century ago. 
Who could look at the Bishop’s P a ­ lace and not be awed? . 
No — Galveston is something more 

 than geography — history — the scene of great tragedy — a showcase of Vic­ torian elegance. 
The excitement of Galveston can’t be analyzed. It can only be felt. 
Old magic 
Bonnie and I recently spent two days in Galveston and up and down the is­ land. It was our first visit in 13 years. 
The old m agic was still there — 
Driving along the seawall and seeing the long fishing piers and the white­ caps rolling in — 
Down on the waterfront — m arveling at the sh rim pers’ “ Mosquito Fleet” — and at dockside a great black ocean freighter with its name in bold, white letters — in Greek. 
And pausing at the site where once stood “ M aison R ouge” — the home and fort of the most dashing pirate of them all — Jean Lafitte. 
But som eth ing is tran sform in g IO sq u are blocks of G alveston and we spent much of our first morning there. 
Family dynasties 
Galveston is the home of four fam ily b u sin e ss d y n a stie s 
— 
M oody, 
Kempner, Sealy and Hutchings. 
The em p ires they built — cotton, su gar, banking, com m ission houses, insurance, railroads, ocean shipping — made Galveston a business center far beyond its size. And there were other m ajor businessm en. 
From the 185os through the 189os, 
Galveston w as the business center of 
T e x a s and in flu e n tial a c ro ss the country. 
Heart of that business center — hard by the port — was “ The Strand.” It was once known as the “ Wall Street of the Southwest.” from Galveston and a heavy equipment company was about to buy it and part of the area, the community rallied to stop the sa le . The buildin g is now owned by the Moody Foundation and among its plans is a railroad m useum . 
Peter Brink, executive director of the Historical Foundation, took Bonnie and me on a tour of The Strand. Al­ ready it is a fascinating place. 
“ In addition to foundation funds, more than $3 million in private money has been spent on Strand p ro jects,” 
Brink told us. 

Even today, The Strand has a col­ lection of iron-front business buildings almost unduplicated. 
Hendley Row is one of them. It was built in 1859 and bombarded during the 
Civil War. One of the most magnificent areas is the 23oo block of The Strand. It burned in 1869 and w as reb u ilt in 
187o-71. 
Strand falls 
In this century The Strand fell on evil days a s G alveston changed and business shifted away from the area. 

Supported by the Moody Foundation and other contributors, the Galveston 
Historical Foundation set about to res­ tore The Strand. 
O’Neil Ford of the San Antonio a r­ ch itectu ral firm of Ford, Powell & 
Carson is preparing the m aster plan. 
The Foundation’s offices are in the 
Santa Fe Building — a 1o-story shining office building that stands at the head of The Strand. It once was the depot and a m ajor headquarters for the San­ ta Fe Railroad. 
When the,railroad moved its offices 

Once named one of the IOO outstanding buildings in the U.S., Galveston’s Bishop’s Palace, left, is magnifi­ cent in architecture and interior furnishings. Above, 
Peter Brink, director of the Galveston Historical Foun­ dation, strolls along The Strand. Now being restored. 
The Strand was once known as the “ Wall Street of the 
Southwest. 

A variety of colorful re sta u ra n ts have opened. There is a fine continen­ tal restau ran t, T horne’s. N earby is 
The Strand Sm oked M eat Com pany, specializing in barbecue. Around the corner is Cafe Torrefie, an appealing little French restaurant. 
The Junior leagu e, first to restore a 
Strand building, has its offices and the 
“ 1882 Soup and Sandwich Shoppe.” 
W arner’s on the Strand is a pub. Its long bar is magnificent. It cam e from a St. Louis hotel and dates back to ISHO. 
One of the top places is the Old Strand 

E m poriu m , sellin g im ported w ines, cheeses and foods and servin g san d ­ wiches in a very unusual room. 
There are a num ber of o ffices in re sto re d b u ild in g s. 
M cLeod 
Properties, a real estate and building firm , has done an outstanding building restoration, as has Stewart Title Co. 
George Mitchell, a Houston oilm an with a Galveston background, is re s­ to rin g a b u ild in g for a la r g e restauran t, cocktail lounge, m eeting 
See GALVESTON, Page SB 

Treasured sites

MR. AND MRS. ALBERT G. MUENCHOW 
Couple wed 7o years 

Surprise party honors couple 

Mr. and Mrs. Albert G. 
Muenehbw will celebrate their 7oth wedding an­ niversary Sunday with a reception in their home. 
Hosts will be the cou­ p le’s daug hter-in-law , 
M rs. E lm e r H. Muen- chow, and th e ir three grandchildren. 
The Muenchows were married May I, 19o7, in a small Lutheran Church on Dallas Street in down­ town San Antonio. 
Mrs. Muenchow is the former Alma L. YVieters. 
Both she and her hus­ band have been residents of San Antonio since 19o2. 

They are m em bers of 
St. 
Jo h n 's 
L utheran 
Church. Mr. Muenchow is retired from Fox Tech 
High School, w here he was head custodian for many years.

Mrs. Ja m e s R. (Lola 
Mae) Rudolph, Fred L. 
Muenchow, and Mrs. 
Howard L. (L inda K.) 
M organroth, and their families. 

The couple has three great-granddaughters

By EVE LYNN SAWYER 

Handle R. Hanks surprised his wife, Annie L., with a 4oth wedding anniversary party in their home. All of the guests were from out-of-town. 

Her sisters, Mmes. A, F. Palmie, 
Modesto, Calif.; 
Richard Watson, 
Westhoff, Tex.; and Vel McKenzie, 
Pleasanton, all attended. 

His brothers and their wives on hand for the anniversary included Mr.' and Mrs.. Sidney Martin, Fort Worth; the Rev. and Mrs. Paul Savage, Al­ buquerque; and Mr. and Mrs. Willis 
M. Hanks, Kermit. 

Visitors 

Former San Antonians, 
Jack and 
Marlys Baldree now of Plano, were honored at parties that 
Sam and 
Vangie Clough gave in their home. A dinner and a brunch made it easy for former friends of the 
Baldrees to catch up with their moves. 
The visitors moved to Plano last May from Raleigh, N.C. Before that, they lived in Phoenix and Tulsa. The 

Baldrees also brought their children. 
Jim and Maria. Jim wanted to cele­ brate his birthday in San Antonio, a major reason for the trip. 
Rig 
Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Buschman have returned from Durban, South 
Africa. During their visit Mrs. Busch­ man commissioned and named a new offshore drilling rig “ Mike G. Ruther­ ford.” 
This is the first offshore oil rig to be constructed in South Africa. The water depth of the rig is 25o feet. The rated drilling depth is 2o,ooo feet. 
Sisters Kimberly and Joy McCord got together over a weekend. Kimberly is in her freshman year at San Antonio 
College studying to be a dental hygien­ ist. She’s a graduate of Jefferson. 
Joy is attending Houston Community 
College and is in the traffic department for an engineering company in the same city. Both sisters play racket ball and soccer. 
Cathy Oliveri, daughter of Lt. Col. 
(ret.) and Mrs. Louis Oliveri, has been accepted at five Ivy League schools in addition to Rice. They include Har­ vard, Radcliffe, Princeton, Yale and 
Smith. 
Her first choice is Princeton, so that’s where she will enrol). 

o*" 

Already in the mood of the annual style show spoof presented by the Women of 
St. Luke’s Episcopal Church are Mmes. 
Robert Nelson, Harry Spear and Joseph 
G. Cocke Sr., who’ll model fashions from the Green Door thrift shop. The 23rd 

I erne bean show fakes place a f noon 
M onday a f the church. Themed as a 
“ put-on-and-take-off/* the comic show points up the serious and far-reaching missionary benefits of the Green Door, operated by St. Luke's Women. 
PHOTO BV RON JONES 
Heimlich method a lifesaver 

Dear Ann: I am writing this letter in the hope it might save another life. 
Recently, when my husband and I were having lunch in a neighborhood restaurant, we noticed a woman a few tables away who seemed to be choking on her food. 
Suddenly I noticed her face was turning purple. Everyone around her was upset, but no one knew what to do to help. 
My husband jumped up, grabbed the woman under her rib cage — made a fist and punched in. He did this three times and a chunk of food that had been blocking the woman’s windpipe popped out of her mouth. 
Within a m atter of minutes, she was feeling fine. 
My husband learned this life-saving maneuver from watching Frank Fields on Channel 4 News. I think my hus­ band, Bernard, deserves a big hand, 

 don’t you? Mrs. B. Plisky, Levittown, 
New York 
Dear Mrs. P.: 
Bernard certainly does deserve a big hand, and while we’re at it, let’s give a big hand to Art 
Snider, science writer for the Chicago 
Daily News. 
He was the first person to publicize the Heimlich Lifesaving Technique in 
1975 and has undoutedlv saved several hundred people from choking to death. 
Borrowers 

Dear Ann: 
I have a problem with friends and neighbors. They borrow everything and anything I own. It’s like I’m a free Rent-All-Shop. 
Every time someone stops by to see me, I wait to see what they are going to ask for next. 
It’s gotten so bad I have to write down who borrowed what and when because I can’t rem em ber any more

N o rth S ta r Mall • I 

Tune in to biorhythms 

Use your Lenny’s Charge, 
Shoppers Charge, Master 
Charge or BankAmericard. 

Get in touch with your internal cycles! Let Kos- mos I compute the ups and downs of your daily life. 
San A ntonians will have the chance to learn about their biorhythms next week when two ex­ perts come to Frost Bros. 
Christopher Washburn and Leslee Mayes of the 
Biorhythm Research In­ stitute in A tlanta, will introduce Kosmos I, a hand-size com puter, which guides the indivi­ dual in learning to know himself. 
W ashburn and Miss 
Mayes will be in the 
Man’s World department of F r o s t’s N orth Star 
Mall Monday and in the downtown store’s Man’s 
World T uesday to de­ monstrate how Kosmos I works. 
George S. Thommen’s book, “ Is T his Your 
Day,” will be displayed with K osm os I. Thom- men is the modern mas­ ter and a u th o rity on biorhythm theory. 
Just what is biorhythm theory? 

Basically it concludes that from birth to death each person is influenced by three internal cycles: physical, emotional and intellectual. Each cycle determines how we feel every day. 
The physical cycle takes 23 d ay s to com ­ plete. It affects strength, resistance to disease, and coordination. 
The em otional cycle, lasting 28 days, rules 

 sensitivity, mood, nerves and creative ability. Me­ m ory, re g u la te d a le r t­ ness, reasoning power and logic are in the in­ tellectual cycle, a period of 33 days. 
All of these rhythm s are computed on the ba­ sis of the individual’s birth d a te as well as other pertinent dates. 
This science is used today in medicine, psy­ c hiatry, education and in du stries where beha­ vior is important to de­ pendable performance. 
In Japan Dr. Kichino- suke T a ta i, author of 
“ Biorhythm for Health 
Design,” was instrumen­ tal in reducing Japan ’s traffic accidents by ap­ plying biorhythm to the municipal transportation system. 
The K osm os I com ­ puter, also a four- function arithmetic cal­ culator, will indicate the c ritic a l as well as the successful days for each individual. 
The scien tific com ­ puter also indicates the compatibility level of any two individuals. 
F ro st’s biorhythm ex­ perts also will explain how to interpret the data that relates to family and rom antic relationships, teamwork, diet, creativi­ ty, stress, accidents, in­ juries, study, child care and future plans. 
The public is invited to visit the Man’s World to learn how' to use this guide to a fuller and safer life. 

Ann, 
Landers 

 where my stuff is. 
I have a great many friends and I want to keep them, but I need help with this problem, Ann. — Duck Soup 

Dear Ducky: Apparently you want to continue to be a “ Rent-All-Shop.” So, let’s proceed from there. 
Your best protection against losing articles permanently is to keep track of everything borrowed. Contact the borrower after a reasonable period of time and ask when he (or she) plans to return same. 
This, of course, is a time-consuming and self-denigrating procedure. Mor­ eover, it doesn’t speak very well for your friends. But obviously you are too insecure to say “ NO.” 

Dear Amt: A friend (?) who thinks she is the world’s best cook served a very nice souffle at a luncheon recent­ ly. I asked for the recipe and she gave it to me — grudgingly. 
I followed the instructions carefully 
(I’m no beginner) and it turned out to be the worst mess I ever saw'. 

I phoned her the next morning and asked if perhaps she had left something out of the recipe. 
She screamed, “ That’s an insult! 

-.being happy just window- shopping.

Now I suspect she DID leave so­ mething out. Was it wrong to call her? 
— Out IO Eggs And Lots of Cheese 

Dear Out: Souffles are delicate and capricious things. It may well have been your stove. I don’t feel you insulted her, however. She must have an awfully short fuse — poor thing.

Top Teen contest 

Enter your Top Teen today in the Express­ io ns Outstanding Teen-ager contest. 

Nomination must be made by 5 p.m. 
Wednesday, May 4. 

I he boy and girl chosen from your letters will receive a $5o U.S. Savings Bond and a recognition plaque. 

AND this year — for the first time — both will be awarded a $1,ooo college scholarship. 

The scholarships are being given by Skil- lern’s Drugs, which has 12 stores in San An­ tonio. Skiljern's also will award $1,ooo scho­ larships to three runners-up. 

Each year since 1958 the Express-News has recognized the Top Teen boy and girl who possess qualities of understanding, judgment, friendliness, scholastic ability and community and school involvement. 

Any student in grades nine through 12 in any 
Bexar County High School may be nominated. 

Any Bexar County resident may nominate the teen of his choice. The letters may come from parents, cousins, pastor, friend, boss, etc. 

Tell us those qualities which make your teen special. 

Those writing letters nominating the two 
Top Teens each will receive a $25 savings bond. 

Letters of nomination must be brought or mailed to the Women's Department of the 
Express-News, third floor of the Express- 
News, Avenue E and Third Street. 

Address letters to Outstanding Teen-ager, 
San Antonio Express-News, Box 2171, San An­ tonio, Tex. 78297. 

The teen-ager’s name, parents’ or guardians’ names and a telephone number where the teen or a member of the family can be reached during the day should be included. 

Festivals set for May Day 

On Sunday, May Day, a number of festivals will be held in various sec­ tions of our city and in our area. 

ST. STENISLAUS 
CATHOLIC CHURCH 
St. Stanislaus Catholic 
Church, second oldest 
Polish parish in the 
United States, will hold its 1oth annual home­ coming festival Sunday in the Bandera Recrea­ tion Center in Bandera. 
A beef barbeque dinner will be served beginning at 11:3o a.m. In the af­ ternoon, a dance will be held with music by 
Kountry Rhodes. 
Commemorative plates and tiles will be sold. 

ST. PATRICK S 

CHURCH 

St. Patrick’s Church will have a Maypole Day 
Festival Sunday on the church grounds. 
A barbeque chicken dinner will be served be­ ginning at ll a m. Festi­ val with food booths, games, rides and re­ freshments will continue until 9 p.m. 
Chairmen for the festi­ val are Mr. and Mrs. 
Obie Robinson. 

ST. JA M ES SCHOOL 

St. James School will hold Western Days Fes­ tival Sunday on the school grounds, begin­ 

 ning at ll a.m. 
A barbeque chicken dinner will be served. 
Entertainment will be­ gin at I p.m. with Rick 
Munoz and the Infinity 
Orchestra and Ben San­ chez and his Orchestra. A free dance will be held beginning at 8 p.m. with music by Pete and the 
Artistes. Laie Astel and wife, Susie Mejares will also entertain. 
Western Days king and queen coronation will be held at 5 p.m. 

TERESIAN SISTERS 

Henry de Osso Catholic 
School, Teresian Sisters, will hold its annual spring festival Sunday on the school grounds. 
Seiving of barbeque chicken dinner begins at ll a.m. 
Festival will feature a variety of foods and be­ verages, games, enter­ tainment, flea market, arts and crafts and hand work. 

ST. 
MARY 

M AGDALEN’S SCHOOL 

St. Mary Magdalen’s 
PTC will hold its annual 
May festival Sunday from noon until 9 p.m. on the church grounds. 
Food, games, a giant auction, plant booth and flea market will be open. 
An arts and crafts show is planned with artists from all over the city.

 these. Named for Josiah Bartlett, one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence, this rocker is a

The seat and back are of a closely woven natural cane.

 will cradle the first baby or the first grandchild. It will serve 

 as the vantage point for story-telling or fireside chatting.

Roadrunner Hour 

Radio personality Lee 
Randall is going to leave his home base and move over to television tonight. 
Wait. This is not a per­ manent move, fans. He’ll be back in his regular seat next week. Maybe a little sleepy-eyed for having spent a long Sa­ tu rd ay night-Sunday morning as guest host of television’s “ Nightflight 
‘77.” But he’ll be back, nevertheless. 
“ Nightflight ‘77” is the all-night program of old movies and episodes of 
“ Wild, Wild West” and 
“ The 
M illio n a ire ,’’ which is now being shown on KENS-TV. It really comes on the air at 
I a.m. Sunday morning following Channel 5’s 
“ Big Show.” Other cities carrying this program in the state include Dallas, 
PT. Worth, Austin and 
Houston. 
It has been on the air just a few weeks now but has become so popular with viewers that plans are being made to make it a F rid a y -S a tu rd a y night late show, too. 
Guest host 
But back to Lee Ran­ dall. “ This will be my first tim e on television for some time,” said the popular RTSA program director and disc jockey. 
“ My phone rang and it was B arry Kaye, pro­ ducer of the show from 
Houston. He said, ‘Hey, how would you like to host the show?” ’ 
Randall didn't take too long in saying yes to the idea and he says he is looking forward to the early morning show. 
“ It’s sort of a ‘Tonight 
Show,’ said Randall dur­ ing our conversation. 
“ There is a perm anent host with a guest host which is a disc jockey from one of the stations around. There is a con­ te st going on in each show. We talk to viewers by phone. It will be in­ teresting for me to talk to viewers from PT. Worth, where I worked for five years.” 
“ I have B.W. Steven­ son lined up to be on the show ,” Randall contin­ ued. “ His is a kind of acoustic m usician. A kind of folk-rock music.” 
The disc jockey said that 
Stevenson’s music will be live on the show. 
Texan 
When asked where he was born, Randall com­ mented: “ I am kind of a 
Texan. I was born and grew up in Denver, but I have worked so long in 
Texas, I feel I am a Tex­ an. I have just built a home in Thousand Oaks here.” He said he worked in PT. Worth from 1968 until 1973, then came to 
San Antonio and RTSA. 
Besides his on the air chores, Randall serves as program director of the station. “ PT>r the past seventh or eighth rating period now, RTSA has been No. One in San An­ tonio,” he said proudly. 
When asked how he got into the radio business in the first place, Randall said it all began in high school. “ I becam e the high school corres­ pondent for a disc jockey when I was a jun­ ior. My first radio station was in Montrose, Colora­ do. And I worked at others while I was going to college at the Univer­ sity of Denver.” 
He said he was in and out of college for several y ea rs, but finally f in - 

M em orial Trophy, the most prestigious prize in collegiate ath letics, is awarded each year to the nation’s outstanding col­ lege football player. It is determined by a ballot of the nation’s sports- writersand sportscasters, and p resen ted by the 
Downtown Athletic Club of New York. 
In past years, the win­ ner of the 
H eism an 
Trophy was announced in advance of the presenta­ tion. This time around, that will all be changed. 
It was in 1973 that win­ ner John Cappelletti de­ dicated his trophy to his younger brother, Joey, who was strick en with leukem ia. J u s t a few weeks ago, CBS had a d ram atic special, “ So­ m ething for Jo e y ,” on the life of John and Joey. 
It was rated the top show of the week in the r a t­ ings.

M an Called ished up. “ In 1968 I went to KFJZ in Ft. Worth. I met my wife in Ft. Worth and have two little boys. 
Michael is five and Wes­ ley is almost four. They are neat.” 
Randall said he used to do television c o m m e r­ cials but because of a hunting accident had to quit that. However, he is now back doing one that is running here for the 
San Antonio Symphony. 
“ I think it would be fun to do more television,” the radioman said. 
Most of Randall’s time is spent at the radio sta­ tion, he says. “ I am at 
RTSA all day long, from 
8:3o in the morning until 
6:3o at night. And I work on S a tu rd a y s, too. We just built our new home and I enjoy that. I am a cactus collector and have a big cactus garden. 
“ I am the official plant doctor at RTSA. People bring in their plants and 
I try to make them well.” 
★ ★ ★ 
As everyone knows, 
NBC has been awarded the coverage of the 198o 
Moscow Olympic Games. 
In order to get ready for this mammoth event, the network has been ad­ ding names to its sports staff. One of its latest editions is Geoff Mason, who was the key organi­ zational force as coordin­ ator of all production for 
ABC’s M unich, In n s­ bruck and 
M ontreal 
Olympic coverage. Ma­ son moves over to NBG as vice president, European production. 
All-Pro running back 
O .J. Sim pson has also been signed to an exclu­ sive co n tract by NBG. 
U nder his co n tract he will be w orking the 
Olympics, plus produce and s ta r in som e NBC 
World Premiere movies. 
Along with the Moscow 
Olympic contract, NBG has agreed to telecast the championship events of the AAU Ju n io r O lym ­ pics this year. Tentative dates for these telecasts are August 13 and 14. 
NBC’s coverage of the 
Olympics in Moscow will span 16 days, and the 15o hours of television time will double the 75 hours of TV coverage allotted to the 1976 O lym pics in 
Montreal.

Trophy will be presented to the winner during a television special broad­ cast on CBS. 
It will be broadcast for the first tim e on te le ­ vision as a live e n te r ­ tain m en t and aw ards special late in the fall from New York.

ADDRESS 

Son Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday April 3o 1977 

Glittering modern day skyscrapers may tower 5 o or even I OO stories. But what skyscraper could have the appealing beauty of this business building dating from the Galveston of a century ago? 
This building was restored by the Junior League of Galveston, the first restoration in The Strand project. 
GALVESTON 

Continued from Page IB 

 rooms and offices. There is another restoration for an old-fashioned ice cream p a rlo r and candy sto re . 
Customers will see the candy being made. 
But the appealing apartments here in a downtown area will interest San 
Antonians most. Most will be above ground-floor businesses. 
Nearly all apartment clusters have atriums — an open shaft rising to a skylight. 
We went to the apartment of Robert 
Lynch. Lynch was at work in the final stages of decoration. His unusu al apartment looks out on the harbor and, in clear weather, on ships going up the 
Houston ship channel. 
The most unusual business is at an historic address — 22o2 The Strand. 
Moody empire 
It was built in 1882. Once it was four stories bul the fourth came off in the 
19oo storm. It was in this building that the empire of W. L. Moody Jr. began. 
From this beginning came cotton factoring, private bunks, hotels and the giant American National Insurance 
Co. 
When “ Mr. Moody” died in 1954, there were estimates that his fortune topped $4oo million. 
Today the Moody Building houses lh** Strand Surplus Senter. 
The big, tin-ceilinged first floor is jammed from floor to ceiling with a strange assortment of mostly military goods from all over the world. 
A quick glance shows a Civil War bayonet sheath and an Air Force heli­ copter drop net — ‘‘makes a great swing” — Dutch army bush pants. 
French navy fall-front sailor pants and 
British riding breeches — British sai­ lor pancake hats and leather’Spanish army tankers helmets. 
There are thousands of items. 
‘Col. Bubble’ 
The proprietor is bearded, surplus- dressed “ Col. Bubbie” Reiswerg. 
“ And I’m a B. O. I.,” he added. . 
Then we learned how proudly any one who can wears that title — “ Born 
On the Island." 
From The Strand we went by the historic spot on Water street — now only a building foundation behind a high wire fence — that was Jean La- fitte’s base when he was the scourge of the Spanish M ain. Here he built 
Maison Rouge (Red House) and fur­ nished it in luxury from his booty. An upper floor had portholes for his can­ non. 
When the U. S. forced Lafitte to leave in 1821. he burned Maison Rouge. The foundation there now is of the building built on the cellars and foundation of 
Red House. 
Firsts 
The Galveston Chamber of Com­ merce takes pride in being one of the oldest chambers in the state. 

It was founded in 1845. 

Charles K. “Chuck” Lawrence, executive vice president, points out that Galveston has many firsts. 

The oldest newspaper in the state still being published Is the Galves­ ton News, started in 1842. 

The first convent in Texas was the 
Crsuiine Convent established in 
Galveston in 1947. 

Galveston has these Texas firsts 
— first .telegraph, with a 5o-inilc line to Houston in 1854 — first gas lights in 1856 — first mule-drawn street cars in 1868 — first telephone in 1878 — first electric lights in 
1888. 

There are a number of businesses that are the first in their line still operating in the state — a real es­ tate firm, a drug stofe, a furniture store, a building and loan associa­ tion and the oldest Ford agency dating before 19oo. 

And how about this? 

Galveston golfers in 1898 started playing at the first golf course and country club in Texas. 

^GLOBE 

Clip and Save . . A g On These One - Day Values! 

From Water street, we drove to the docks where a young Negro boy once worked — and from Galveston went on to fame. 
He was Jack Johnson, son of a Gal­ veston school janitor. Johnson — “ LU 
Artha” — on Dec. 28, 19o8, in Sydney, 
Australia, knocked out Tommy Burns and became “ Heavyweight Champion* of the World.” 
Johnson took part in one of the most ballyhooed fights of all time in Reno, 
Nev., on July 4, 191o. Jim Jeffries, the big former champion came out of re­ tirement as a “ Great White Hope.” 
Among newspapermen covering the training camps and the fight was Jack 
London, who wrote the classic “ The 
Call of the Wild.” 
Johnson toyed with J e ffrie s and knocked him out in the 15th round. 
Johnson went on to fight in England and France and became a well-known figure on the boulevards of Paris. 
Johnson, who picked up some of his skill on the docks of Galveston, was recognized as one of the cleverest fighters — with a left jab that experts say has never been matched. 
He lost the title to Jess Willard in 
H avana. Cuba, in 1915. W illard knocked him out in the 28th round. 
Johnson was killed in an automobile accident in Raleigh, N. C., in 1948. 
At 35th and Avenue O is a m arker to another Galveston man whose name is a household word across much of the world even today. 
Borden arrives 

He was Gail Borden Jr. , a native 
New Yorker, who came to Galveston island on Christmas Eve 1829. He was a newspaper editor, map-maker, public official and super land salesman. 
But it was as an inventor that he got lasting fame. The Texas Handbook tells the story. 
One of his first inventions was a 
“ locomotive bath house” — so modest women could bathe in the Gulf. Then cam e a “ tc rre a q u eo u s m a c h in e ” which was a sort of prairie schooner that could travel on eith er land or water. 
He developed a dehydrated flour and meat biscuit that he merchandised at home and abroad. It failed in a big way. 
Then Borden hit the jackpot! In 1853 he came up with a process for con­ densing milk in a vacuum. It was one of the greatest food inventions of all time. It soon sold around the world. 
The giant Borden Company gets its name from this beginning. 
There are so many things about 
Galveston. Brink took us for a tour of the East End Historical District. There ' are a score of homes there that would be outstanding in any other city. 
Bishop’s Palace 

Then in the afternoon Bonnie and I visited three homes that are open to public tours. First was the Bishop’s 
Palace, a majestic four-story, many- turreted structure seven years in the building. 

Magnificent as is the outside, the interior is even more striking. There is a chandelier from Venice, damask wall coverings from London and a marble fireplace from Italy. The Mexican silver, onyx and satinwood mantel in the ballroom, once valued at $1o,ooo, now is priceless. 

It was built by Col. Walter Gresham and completed in 1893. Col. and Mrs. 
Gresham gave parties attended by as many as 1,ooo guests. 

The Catholic Diocese bought it in 
1923 as the Bishop’s home. 

Ashton Villa, built in 1859, is no less glittering. The Historical Foundation here shows a film of the 19oo storm that no viewer can ever forget. 

Then there is the Sweeney-Royston 
House, built in 1885. In it is a 1o-room 
Victorian doll house with parquet floors, stain ed glass windows and electric lights. 

But wonderful as all these are, it is the little things that make Galveston a 
“ city with a difference.” 

Take that nondescript building down near the docks with this sign over its door:

 will be in the downtown store and from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. heil be at the North

Characters 
The 35-year-old artist’s best known prints feature short, chubby characters experiencing the thrill of victory and the agony of defeat while playing amateur sports. 
For instance, a print entitled 
“ Weekend 
Player” shows one of 
Patterson’s bruised and battered characters soaking his feet after an apparently grueling ten­ nis match. 
But in another print called “ Winning Is Ever-

Carter-size grin stretch­ ing over his face. 
“ The main thing about the prints seems to be they give the average person a chance to identify with someth­ ing,” Patterson said Fri­ day. 
Besides giving the public something they can identify with, the 
California native says, his prints are popular because of the over-all increased interest in sports. 
“ Sports have become a major frustration outlet for a lot of people and they take them very ser­ iously. 
“ So most of the prints are about tennis, golf and skiing since those are sports the average per­ son is interested in. Na­ turally I don’t do too many about football and baseball since they’re more specialized,” he explained. 
Understanding 
The artist explained the key to turning out succesfu) prints people will identify with is to fully understand the sport. 
So when he recently wanted to draw a few hockey-related prints, 
Patterson strapped on the necessary pads and skates and glided out on the ice and tried batting around a puck. 
Patterson won several awards for his editorial 

“ LIN IN G UP,” one of Gory Patter­ son’s prints, epitomizes the playful w ay he identifies with the average golfer. 

 cartoons in campus newspapers before 197o, when he formed Thought 
Factory, which distributes his Pro Gra­ phic prints. 
And while Patterson’s prints aren’t considered in the same league with art found in museums, he’s still pleased when he sees where some of his works are displayed. 
“ Sometimes ITI find one of the prints tacked up next to a Renoir or 
Picasso in someone’s home and i t makes me feel pretty good to be in

 that type of company,” he said. 
In addition to his sports prints Pattereon has started to turn out prints that take a humorous looks at various profes­ sions. 
One that has started turning up in dentist of­ fices is of a dentist smiling at a cowering patient before starting his work. 
“ Six or seven years ago the prints wouldn’t have sold because the public would have thought they were too sarcastic. 
“ But now things have changed and people laugh at themselves much more readily,” he, said. 

Puzo busy as writer 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS 
LONDON — Mario Pu-’ zo, who is the co-author of the screenplay for 
“ Superman,” which is in production in London, soon will head for Rome. 
Puzo has written the screenplay for “ Seven 
Graves for 
Hogan,” which deals with spying in Nazi Germany. 
Production of “ Hogan” is to start in Italv in 
June. 

Triple job for Savalas 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS 
HOLLYWODD — Telly 
Savalas has written the script and is starring in and directing “ Mati.” 
The suspense story concerns a psychiatrist who becomes personally involved in the problems of his patients. 
Diana Muldaur and 
Priscilla Barnes are in the cast. 
Filming is under way at Paramount.

The Aces 
On Bridge 
Bv IRA (,. CORN JR. 

“ Seeing is believing •- but feeling is the truth " -- Billy 
Moore 
In today's doubled slam. 
West became a believer as declarer ran his seven card suit. Gasping for air and dis­ cards. West took his only chance and bravely d is­ carded an ace but when declarer made his doubled overtrick. West really felt the truth. 
South's three no trump opening was a modern ver­ sion of the gambling no trump bid. It promises a solid seven card suit (usually a minor) and can act as a dou­ ble edged sword. If the oppo­ nents have the bulk of the high cards, the opening preempts at a very high level. And if partner has moderate strength, one might well steal a game after an er­ rant or lucky lead. 
Mike Cappelletti of Alex­ andria. Va. was at the con- 
•trbls in today’s thriller and when North gambled on a slam. West doubled the stakes betting that the gamblers were wrong. Unfor­ tunately, it was not West’s day but he does deserve an 
“ E '’ for effort. 
Declarer won the heart ace in dummy and ran seven club tricks, that meant that West had to hold on to five cards 
The heart queen was a must else dummy’s jack would be the 12th trick, so the choice was between discarding a diamond or the ace of spades. 
Judging correctly that he cbuldn't afford to discard a diamond (dummy's diamonds would run), West discarded the spade ace in hopes that 
East held the spade king. 
One would think that West had suffered enough for one

 hand, but Cappelletti applied the crusher. Next he cashed the king of spades and West could choose another “ ace” to throw away. 
Six no trump doubled with only one overt rick -- it does seem as if Wests punishment was far more than fit the 
“crime."

R ecital tonight at IW C 

Tile recently formed 
San Antonio Camerata 
Chamber Orchestra of 
Incarnate Word College will present a recital at 
8:15 p.m. Saturday in the 
IWC Auditorium. 
The recital’s program will include 
Bach’s 
“ Brandenburg Concerto 
No.2 in F .” 
Admission is free and the public is invited. 
The 23-member or­ chestra is conducted by 
IWC alumna Mary Henry who also holds a master’s degree in conducting from Southern Methodist 
University. 
The concert will also include works by Britten, 
Strauss and Boyce. 

Sensibility seen elusive at art show 

By ROBERT TIEMANN 
EXPRESS-NEWS ART CRITIC 
AUSTIN - The Wo­ men’s Show in Austin does not give evidence there is a women’s sensibility in art. 
It does prove there are and have been many ex­ cellent women painters, and their work is on ex­ hibit through June 12 at the University of Texas 
Art Museum. 
With all this attention, it will be interesting to see whether or not 
Women will succumb to the mistake of Mexiean- 
Americans and blacks fey forcing a self-consciously contrived sensibility on their art. 
In light of this potential dilemma, some out­ standing women artists 
— such as Agnes Martin, 
Helen Frankonthaler, and Louise Nevelson — have refused to partici­ pate in this kind of show. 
It is interesting that 
Georgia O’Keefe refused to. allow any of her erotic flower paintings to be exhibited lest they be construed as female-type paintings. 
Aside from these omis­ sions, “ Women Artists . . 
. 155o-195o’’ is probably the most complete cata­ loging of female artists ever assembled. 
With paintings from 
European as well as 
Kennedy, 
Lenz stars 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS 
HOLLYWOOD 
- 
George Kennedy and Kay 
Lenz will star in “ Mean 
Dog Blues.” 

Filming of the prison drama is scheduled to start in May. 
Lollipop 
Picasso 

Review 

American collections, many important artists are represented, includ­ ing Mary Cassatt, Sonia 
Delaunay, Frida Kahlo, 
Natalia Goncharova, and 
Berthe Morisot. 
The show is a novelty because all the paintings are made by women; but mere novelty is trans­ cended because the ma­ jority of paintings are of outstanding quality. 
And, after all, quality is tile only issue in art. 

Schools’ concert 
Monday 

The North East School 
District will highlight 
National Music Week 
Monday with a presenta­ tion by its various con­ cert and junior orches­ tras. 
The concert will be gi­ ven at 8 p.m. Monday in the 
Roosevelt 
High 
School Auditorium, 511o 
Walzern Road. 

Among participating students are gold and silver medalists. 

The concert is free and open to the public.

Rudy Trevino, lecturer in painting at the Uni­ versity of Texas at San Antonio, has been selected as one of five Texas artists to represent the state in a national traveling art exhibition Trevino will show an acrylic paint­ ing in “ Rakes Antiguas-Visiones Nuevas" 
(Ancient Roots-NEW Visions). The exhibit was organized by Fondo Del Sol of W a ­ shington, D.C., and New York City.

Cygnets at Arneson 

The synchronized swimming talents of the- 
Cygnets of San Antonio will be featured at 5 p.m. 
Sunday in the Arneson 
River Theater. 
Originally scheduled to be a part of Fiesta Week, the 1977 Aquatic Extra­ vaganza will co-star the 
San Antonio College Folk 
Dancers. 

The synchronized swimming team, which is directed by Margaret 
Swan, won its fifth Junior 
National 
Team 
Championship in compe­ tition held in Houston in late April. 

Tickets are priced at $2 for adults and $1 for children. Proceeds will go to the travel funds of the two entertaining groups.

Registration due for craft classes

THE DAMNED” 

“AIRPORT 7 7 ” 

‘IT’S ALIVE” 

“THE SLIPPER 
AND THE ROSE” 

Registration opens 
Monday for an expanded program of classes at the 
Southwest Craft Center. 

The new curriculum offers day and evening sessions for beginners and advanced students in 
IO craft areas, plus four, special courses for chil­ dren. 
Adult classes, which will be held June I through Aug. 27, run the gamut from one-day workshops to courses varying from two to IO weeks. 

Today at 

C E N T U R Y S O U T H B 

I W Mil ». .tlMlSl. tic-CSII 

The classes include ca­ ligraphy, harness weav­ ing, rug-hooking, spin­ ning, embrodiery and metal casting. 
The summer semester will also include special 

 classes in beginner and intermediate guitar. 
For information, regis­ tration or free copy of the new summer semester brochure, telephone 
224-1848. 

Diana Ross in 'The Wiz’ 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS 

NEW YORK - Diana 
Ross will star as Dorothy in “ The Wiz.” 

Sidney Lumet will dir­ ect the fantasy musical. 

Filming is acheduled to start in New York City in September. 

The production is said to be one of the most lavish musicals ever produced.

Home 

By JAMES MCCRORY 
Communities Organized for Public 
Service is not as revolutionary as some people think it is, Tucker Gibson told the Bexar County Republican Women’s 
Ciub Friday. 
A professor of political science at 
Trinity University, Gibson described 
COPS as an organization of people wanting a piece of the action. 
While some may not agree with 
COPS’ tactics in obtaining its ends, 
Gibson observed, wanting some of the 
“ goodies” does not constitute a revo­ 

 lution. 
“That's American as apple pie,” he observed. 
Addressing the club at a luncheon at the Bright Shawl, Gibson told the 
Republican women the advent of sin­ gle-member City Council districts do­ vetailed with the decline of the Good 
Government League, but did not cause its demise. 
He said the CGL declined, and fin­ ally died, because its leadership con­ census broke down after its last suc­ cessful election in 1971. 

It wasn’t a revolt of the masses against the leadership, Gibson ob­ served. but rather the breakdown of the GGL leadership concensus, its failure to address itself to changing times, increased civil rights activities and extension of the Voting Rights Act to Texas. 
To say the Alliance for a Better City replaced the GGL, Gibson reported, is absurd. 
The GGL, he explained, during its greatest years was broadbased, and 
ABC never was. Describing ABC as a 

 front organization, Gibson said it never had the substantive organization the 
GGL enjoyed. He cautioned the ABC may come along. 
During the GGL’s better years, Gib­ son said, most of the council members came from what are now Districts 7, 8, 
9 and IO on a broad sweep from the 
Northwest to the Northeast sides. 
He noted that since council-manager government was adopted in 1951, not a single council member was elected from what is now District 6 on the 
Southeast Side until this year. you cam afford spend $119. you cain altSord elegant! chair! 

Come to Fisher’s and choose the ones to suit your style and budget. W e offer you our finest decorator chairs in a wide selection of colors and fabrics . . . and they’re waiting for you at 1 /3 o ff . . . and more! O nly a few o f the many gorgeous chairs are illustrated here, and they are comfortable as they are beautiful. Shop today for best selection!

C o lo r ^ lo flse r's 
Plants are g re e n 

THO U SANDS of different plants are on display at both 
Mission Nursery locations 

 year-round business 

San Antonio’s largest chain nursery, 
Wolfe Nurseries, has a large selection of foliage and flowering plants and acces­ sories available for Mother’s Day or any occasion. 
“ Our blooming pot plants are coining in now,” announced Jo e M oncada, m an ager of the Wolfe 
Nursery at 88o2 Perrin-Beitel. 
“ But plants are not just for special occasions,” lie added. “ They’re something people of all ages can enjoy. Our foliage plants will last year after year. 
“ We have foliage plants to suit every taste ami pocketbook, from .‘IO cents to $59, depending upon the individual’s needs. We also carry containers, potting soils,- fertilizers and instruction books.” 
Wolfe N ursery is still very much aw are of the boom in home decorating plants. Although open less than three years, the Perrin-Beitel store is already the second largest in the Texas and Oklahoma Wolfe chain, behind the Wolfe Nursery on San Pedro. 
The house plant popularity has made the nursery business a yearround one. 
Moncada has also witnessed an interest in vege­ table gardening, with many people purchasing small plants. 
While Wolfe does not contract landscaping, it does have personnel in the stores to help a homeowner lay out a landscape plan so plants will be in the most advantageous and attractive positions. 
Other Wolfe Nurseries are at 37oo Broadway, 15o7 
Ruiz, 7oo7 San Pedro, 8714 S. Flores and 1134 Pat 
Booker in Universal City. 

EXQUISITE fountains and bird baths are available at W olfe Nursery along with a variety of plants 
G ardening is fun

IN CLU D IN G SU N D A Y 

Plant tips dispensed 

By early afternoon, 
Paul Zavala’s desk is covered with phone messages. 
After he’s returned from checking on his com pany’s various landscape projects and giving his attention to pressing details at the nursery, Zavala will re­ turn each of these mes­ sages. 
He’ll answer, by the end of the day, dozens of questions from custom ers and non­ customers alike, all con­ fident Zavala can give them the help they need with their plants, shrubs, trees and flowers. 

Success 
This kind of attention reflects not only Zavala’s personal philosophy, but the reason for the contin­ uing success of Paul’s 
Green Thumb Nursery, 

85 Haby and now a se­ cond location, 51o3 Blan­ co. 
The Haby address, lo­ cated at the end of a street without through traffic, is a bit difficult to find. The firm got almost no drop-in business. 
Zavala decided the so­ lution was to open the new nursery on Blanco, just a few blocks from the original Paul’s Green 
Thumb Nursery. 
Passersby drop in to check the offerings on the well-traveled Blanco. 
Some buy, but those who don’t find exactly what they re looking for are referred to the original five-acre site on Baby, where the offerings are more extensive. 
Right now 
Paul’s 
Green 
Thumb .has a variety of flowering plants in slock, which would m ake perfect 
Mother’s Day gifts. 
Mission offers quality service 

How can a nursery go wrong offering low prices and first rate service? 
The answer is, it can’t, and that’s certainly the case this year with Mis­ sion Nurseries, 2919 Mis­ sion Rd. and 12823 Na­ cogdoches Rd. 
“ Business is fantas­ tic ,’’ said co-owner 
Frank Allen, who super­ vises the Mission garden center on Nacogdoches. 
“ We’re 25 to 5o per cent ahead of last year.” 
Allen attributes the improvement to favora­ ble weather, an ample stoclcof merchandise and the fact that the newer 
Nacogdoches store has finally become estab­ lished. 

Confidence 
But Mission customers would probably mention other factors, especially the good buys available and their confidence in the expertise of the Mis­ sion staff. 
Allen acknowledges that these have been ingredients in Mission’s success since the Mission 
Road store was estab­ lished in 1961. 
“ Service is our back­ bone,” Allen said. “ We try to give customers the kind of personal attention they • just can’t get from the big chains.” 
Reflecting this, Mis­ sion avoids commission sales because, Allen says, “ We don’t want a customer sold something he doesn’t need. 
“ Our main goal is to have our customers feel welcome. They can take all the time they need to browse and we’re always happy to answer any 

 questions they have,’’ 
Allen continued. 
“The only time we try to speed things up is at the checkout counter, be­ cause we don’t want to keep our custom ers waiting when they’re ready to leave.” 
This even applies dur­ ing the busy weekends of this boom time of year for nurseries, says Allen, but he does encourage custom ers who can to shop on the less hectic weekdays. 
As to price, “We have always maintained as low a price as you can find in 
San Antonio on the mer­ chandise we sell,” Allen said. 
Quality 
Still another important feature at Mission is the emphasis on quality. 
“Since most nurseries buy from the same sup­ pliers, quality is equal when the plant comes in­ to the store,” Allen said. 
“ The important thing is what happens to it between the time the store gets it and the time it s sold to a customer. 
“ We tend all our plants, trees and other items very carefully, do­ ing everything we can to keep them just as healthy as they were when we received them. 
“ This means regular watering, regular feed­ ing and close attention to their appearance.’* 
The Mission policies are carried out by the nursery’s experienced managers and staff. 
Allen said Mission also stocks the widest possi­ ble variety of merchan­ dise in the hope that each customer “can find most anything he wants when he shops with us.”

SAN PEDRO AVE 

Grimm’s experience has ’no substitution’ 

Son Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Soturdoy April 3o 1977 

•’JCT 

Although 
G rim m ’ s 
Garden Center, 6923 San 
Pedro, dales back to 
1936, the service and merchandise are as mo­ dern as 1977. 
Rudy Chavez Sr., pre­ sident and manager, is constantly striving to up­ date and modernize the garden center. 
He has a sign promin­ ently displayed in his of­ 

 fice, 
“ There is no substitute for exper­ ience.” He believes in this bit of wisdom and offers his 24 years as a nurseryman as one rea­ son for the success of 
Grim m’s. 
Retail sales personnel are taught to give plant­ ing instructions with all plants purchased. 
Customers are urged to 

 bring th e ir botanical problems to the store where sales personnel will try to analyze and advise. 
Chavez encourages customers to give pro­ gress reports on their plants. “ I have confi­ dence that what I ’ve told them is going to work. 
We’re large enough and sm all enough to give 

> • 
-x n L , 
K S P 
M m m 
/ ' 

LYDIA DEFFENBACH and Virginia Chavez from G rim m ’s on 
San Pedro look o ver the variety o f fresh plants 

 personalized service.” 
G rim m ’s is one of the few local nurseries which grows its own plants. 
This allows Grim m ’s to keep a large stock on hand. growing their own in quantity rather than buying a limited number from a supplier. 
Specimen and tropical plants and shrubs are trucked or flown in from 
C alifornia and Florida and displayed outdoors so they are already ac­ clim ated when p ur­ chased. 
G rim m ’s landscape departm ent has un established reputation in the San Antonio area, both for residential and com m ercial landscape area services. 
A registered Lands­ cape Architect is availa­ ble for plans, suggestions and recommendations. 
G rim m ’s has performed some of the largest major landscape jobs in the ci­ ty, yet never hesitates to design residential lands­ caping. 
Too many cooks 
Many people have problem s with their plants because they try to follow advice from too many sources, Chavez pointed out. 
“ Go to one person you have confidence in and stick with them from top to bottom ,” he suggest­ ed. 
F re q u e n tly there is more than one successful way to treat a given sym ptom . With two or more experts involved, they may use conflicting methods, each of which would be successful if used alone, but which may destroy a plant if used in combination with another. 
A top line of fertilizers, chemicals and plant-re­ lated items are carried. 
Quality brass planters, ceramic pots and woven baskets are carried as custom er convenience items. 
G rim m ’s office staff, based at the San Pedro center, is always willing to answer questions re­ garding accounts or pur­ chases. 

GRIM M ’S Bandera Road c e n te r f e a t u r e s 

• :&-• : >:*• ......Wg&K p la n ts in n a t u r a l o u t d o o r se ttin gs 
Grimm’s is 
'budding’ 

G rim m ’s 
Garden 
Center at 17o4 Bandera 
Rd. is a “ budding” young nursery, if you’ll excuse the pun. 
Although in existence only since February, 
1975, it has already established itself as a successful garden center with a long list of satis­ fied customers. 
Manager Rudv Chavez 
•lr., a Texas Certified 
Nurseryman, states that the landscape depart­ ment in this northwest nursery is fast develop­ ing, also. 
As shown in the pic­ ture. the natural setting of the three-acre nursery makes for a beautiful outdoor display of shrubs, flowers and bed­ ding plants with plenty of room for parking. 

A great variety of trees are both nursery grown 

 and locally dug, accord­ ing to customer prefer­ ence. Grass sold by the yard is an im portant customer item that 
Grimm’s is able to fur­ nish from its own locally grown source. 
For new home owners, 
Grimm’s can provide in­ stant lawn and landscape with large shade trees, ornamental or fruit trees, as desired. 
Inside the nursery is attractively designed to best display seasonal plants, containers of all kinds, garden tools and the usual fertilizers, in­ sect controls and chemi­ cals. 
Need a g ift for 
Mother’s Day, birthday or convalescent? Chavez recommends a visit to 
G rim m ’s where they’ll dress a pot plant or re­ pot a plant in a unique container.

Persistent stain 
I am writing this letter in hopes of soliciting some help in dealing with a local entrepreneur who has failed to meet with a contractual agreement. 
The individual owns and operates a local cleaners. 
About three weeks ago I purchased a new set of 
Army whites for $89.75. I had the whites tailored at 
Ft. Sam Houston and wore them one night. 
Prior to wearing the whites I visually inspected them to see if any defects existed. None were noted. 
After the first wearing I took the whites to the cleaners. 
After two days I returned to pick up the whites. I did not look at them until I returned home, at which time I noticed that the whites had two large brown water stains on the pants legs. 
I wore the whites that evening and returned them the following day to the cleaners to point out the stains. 
I was told the cleaners would insure the stain was removed. 
My wife picked up the whites about two days later and did not check to see if the stain was removed.. 
That night I noticed the stain was still present. 
I told my wife to take the pants back arid she did so the following day. She pointed out the stain to tho* owner and said that since the cleaners had put the stain in the pants, they should either remove the; stain or replace the pants. 
My wife told me she was not abusive or threaten- ing. She also told me the owner hedged but finally* said he would do his best. lie was indignant that my wife would even come in and complain about his lack of service. She told me he raised his voice but did not use abusive language. 
On April 25, my wife called the owner to ask if the pants would be ready that day. She was informed by the owner she was out of line and causing him problems. 
She was cussed at and yelled at over the phone. 
After verbal abasement, the owner told her we were not permitted to do business at his establishment- again. 
My wife called mc at my office in tears. I called the ow ner to verify this and he began to cuss me out * 
I took it for five minutes before he told me I would have to get a court order to make him replace the, pants. 
I don’t feel my request for cleaning an expensive’ 
Army uniform entitles me or my wife to such abuse. 
I also feel that since this firm put the stains in the pants, it should either take out the stains or replace the pants. 
» 
Since Army whites are sold as a total uniform, I* am unable to purchase the pants alone. Conse> quently, I feel that it is w ithin the ow ncr’s respon­ sibility to reimburse me $89.75. 
I would appreciate all that you can do to help me in this matter. 
M. W. I..

P h le g m 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: Could you discuss the prob­ lem of phlegm in the throat? Where does it come from ? Is it sig n ific a n t if it changes color or consistency? — C.B. 
The mucous lining of the respiratory tract, in­ cluding the nose and throat, is continually producing mucus (or phlegm). The purpose is too cool the incoming air and get rid of unwanted bacteria and foreign particles. It does this efficiently and unno­ ticed until it is forced to overwork because of some irritation. Then it overproduces and we have a 
“ running” nose or phlegm in the throat, often a cough. 
A dusty atmosphere can be enough to set off heavy mucus formation. Smoking is a source of chronic mucus. Allergy is another source, animal dander being a prime offender. Chronic infection of the nasal sinuses is another common cause of excessive mucus. 
In most longstanding cases continuing irritation is the secondary cause of the mucus, and one m ust search for the principal culprit in the environment. 
Thick mucus usually indicates an infection, more so than clear thin mucus. Often, if the source is not eliminated, more serious problems develop such as a sinus infection. I discuss this in my booklet on the various sinus problems. For a copy, send 35 cents and a stamped, self-addressed envelope to me care of this newspaper. 

STEYE ROPER

BIRTHDAY 
SUNDAY: Your year is full of mind-sharpening episodes, high rew ards for taking initiative, do­ ing your own thinking. 
The last quarter-year is quiet, a tim e for em o­ tional and sp iritu a l needs. Express your true feelings iii all real rela­ tionships. T oday’s na­ tives are a m bitiou s, dependable, with leader­ ship qualities. Those born this year before 3:1o p.m. EDT will be artists iii exacting media, such as jewelry design. Those born later will go iii for intangibles, ideas.

Bus driver 
I want to be the voice of many who caught the bus* from Wonderland Mall and went downtown for 
Fiesta on the first night — the one with the big rain and flooding. 
Enroute, all passengers were laughing and having. a great time of revelry. No use telling of our return; trip in the downpour and all the newly m ade streams. 
But let me tell you about our great bus driver. Our bus was loaded — people standing from back to front. All were soaking wet. 
This fine, great driver toured us through streets with stalled cars and other buses with stranded passengers. lie kept our spirits up by singing and soon we all joined in, laughing and joking all the time he was taking us on detours and out-of-the-way streets without a wobble. 
The passengers were delivered safely and with very high spirits to where they had caught the bus earlier in the evening. 
We want to thank this great bus driver for giving us a fine ride and for his safe driving in such a downpour through such waterways. 
THELMA POOL 

Action-Express would Antonians with excellent also like to thank E. D. service so their outing to 
Estell for providing San 
Fiesta was not ruined

The POWER of FAITH 

By WOOD I ISHMAEL 

THE BIBLE 

No. 289 Rebuilding the Temple 

In the second year of the reign of King Darius I, the Lord sent a m essage to his prophet Haggai. It was Haggai's duty to inform the governor of Judah and the High Priest that the tem ple was to be re­ built before the land would again be made productive. 
“Go up to the mountain, and bring wood, and build the house; and I will take pleasure in it, and I will be glorified, saith the Lord. Ye looked for much, and, lo, it came to little; and when ye brought it home, I did blow upon it. Why? saith the Lord of hosts. Because of mine house that is waste, and ye run every man unto his own house. Therefore tfie heaven over you is stayed from dew, and the earth is stayed from her fruit." (Haggai 1:8-1o) 
However, once the rebuilding was underway, the prophet delivered a more salutary prophecy. "Consider now from this day and upward, from the four and twentieth day of the ninth month, even from the day that the foundation of the Lord's tem ple was laid, consider it.... from this day will I bless you." (Haggai 2:18-19)

Rev. Frank Stribling and Bill Finto, realtor, who sold the structure to the church, formerly belonging to the congregation of the C alvary M issionary Church. The Rev. Mr. Stribling is the pastor of Calvary. 
Church hospital taxation is serious 

The call for removing ch u rch h o sp itals from tax exemption m ade this week by Bexar County 
Hospital D istrict c h a ir­ man Dr. Harvey Hornet raises this serious issue before our community. 
B exar County J u d g e 
Blair Reeves has issued s ta te m e n ts s u p p o rtin g the idea of investigating the charitable services of these institutions to see if the county is justified on that basis iii m aintaining their tax exemption. 
The accusation is being made that these hospitals are charging off uncol­ lectable debts as if they w ere c h a rity an d are funneling their charity p a tien ts to th e B ex ar 
County Hospital. 
Such activity places an u n d u e b u rd e n on the 
Bexar County Hospital 
District and the public taxpayers and becomes the basis for calls to re­ move tax exemption. 
T hese a rc s e rio u s c h a rg e s and sh o u ld be investigated thoroughly 

 lea 
Ta'lur. 
First Baptist Church rn 

 to determ ine the facts. 
C h u rch -related hospi­ tal spokesmen have den­ ied them and m ain tain that they are perform ing their function in dealing with the needs of the poor in a responsible manner. 
Modern h o spitals are c o m p lex in s titu tio n s . 
T hey o p e r a te u n d e r a myriad of regulatory po­ licies. 
The m ounting cost of health care in our nation has become a m a tter of national priority of con­ cern. 
While some politicians 

 tend to demagogue off of th e iss u e , d is c o u n tin g their voices does not dis­ p la ce th e p ro b le m of what to do about rising health costs. 
History 
T h e h is to ry of the h o sp ita l m o v e m e n t r e ­ veals that it was horn in the compassionate hearts of C h ris tia n c o m m u n ­ ities. 
Churches fashioned ho­ spitals because there was a concern about fulfilling the ministry of the Great 
Physician. 
In m o d e rn tim e s we often fo rg e t th a t hospitals reflecting a de­ te rm in a tio n of a c o m ­ m u n ity to c a re for the sick solely because every p e rso n h as a rig h t to health cam e as a result of organized religious acti­ vity. 
Church hospitals have th r e e b a s ic p u rp o s e s from th e c h u r c h m a n ’s point of view. 
The first is the convic­ tion that it is in the will of 
Catholic-Anglican differences persist 

VATICAN CITY (AP) 
— Pope Paul YI and the 
Archbishop of 
Canter­ bury, Dr. Donald Cog­ gon, conceded 
Friday that serious o b sta cles, particularly on m arriage after divorce, rem ain on the road to Roman Catli- olic-Anglican unity. 
The obstacles contrast­ ed with a g lit te r in g 
Christian unity service in the V a tic a n 's S istin c 
Chapel w here th e two religious leaders prayed together. The 79-year-old 
Pope and the 67-year-old archbishop em braced in a “ kiss of p ea ce” s y m ­ bolic ut the p r o g re s s achieved since an A ng­ lican p r im a te an d a 
Rom an C ath o lic pope first met here in 196(1. 
That meeting broke the ice of m ore ‘ hail 4o11 years separating betw een the two churches. 
Unity 
But a common declar­ ation signed by the two leaders did not minimize continuing d iffe re n c e s that rem ain to u n itin g th e 6oo m illion R om an 
Catholics and 6o million 
A nglicans. T h e d i f f e r ­ ences ran g e fro m the problems of mixed m a r­ riages to the ordination of women as p rie sts iii the Episcopal Church in the United States. 
Festival set for Sunday 

B lessed 
S a c r a m e n t 
C h u rch will hold its 
Spring Festival from ll a.m. to 8 p.in. Sunday on the church grounds at HO 
Shannon Lee Drive. 
The festiv al will in ­ clude food and gam es. 

The common decla­ ration recom m ends the work of a joint Angli­ can-Roman 
Catholic 
C o m m ission c o n tin u e 
“ through procedures ap­ propriate to our respec­ tive communions, so that both of rhein may be led along the path to w ard unity. The moment will shortly come when the respective authorities must evaluate the con­ clusions.” 
The c o m m is s io n , which first m et iii 197o, reported ag re em e n t on the practice and meaning of the 
Eucharist, the s a c ra m e n t in w hich bread and wine are con­ sumed as the body and blood of Christ, and on the c h a racter and func­ tion of the two churches. 
It agreed that if they un­ ite. Rome should have authority over the union. 
Beyond these c o n c lu ­ sions. however, a gap al­ so remains to be bridged on th eo lo g ical d i f f e r ­ ences over the doctrines of the Im m acu late Con­ ception and the Assump­ tion. 
Mixed 
Dr. Coggan, spiritual leader of the worldwide 
6o million-member Ang­ lican community, includ­ ing th re e m illio n U.S. 
'Episcopalians, em pha­ sized the p ro b le m of m ixed m a r r ia g e s in a news conference after the prayer service. 
“ I have underlined the tragedy for children of a m ixed m a r r ia g e w hen th e ir p a re n ts c a n ’t receive c o m m u n io n together,” he said refer­ ring to his challenge to 
Pope P aul to sa n c tio n shared Holy Communion 

 between A nglicans and 
Roman Catholics. 

V atican o fficia ls a p ­ peared cool to the idea, though there was no of­ ficial rea ctio n . “ You c a n 't ex p ect a q u ick comeback.” the Anglican leader said. 

The Vatican basically approves of mixed m a r­ riag e s p ro v id ed the 
Roman Catholic spouse pledges to do his or her utmost to raise children in that faith. The A ng­ licans d e s c rib e th e m ­ selves as more flexible.

"Principles o f Receiving Revelation ” 
.encouraging the Christian community to become what Jesus intended ... a positive, healing influence in a hurting world.” 

Anniversaries to be celebrated 

God rev e ale d in J e s u s 
C h ris t for m en to be w hole. H ea lin g itself comes from God. 
H ospitals, m edicines, and doctors becom e in ­ s t r u m e n t s for th e fu l­ filling of that purpose. 
This is true in all kinds of hospitals w hether o p er­ ated in the nam e of Jesus 
Christ or not. 
A second purpose is to deal with those who are weak and helpless in the healing process. This is the issue being discussed in our community. 
T he task of rea ch in g out to touch those who are unable to help them ­ se lv es is a p a rt of the p re a c h in g of th e Good 
News to the poor about which Jesus exhorted his followers. 
The cost of that ca re m u st be paid by so m e ­ body. 
In the C h ristia n co n ­ c e p t, th e fo llo w ers of 
Christ are responsible for ta k in g w h at r e s o u r c e s they have and investing them in the lives of those w ho a re God s sp e c ia l concern — the poor, the weak, and the helpless. _ 
A third purpose is for b e a rin g w itness to the m essage of Jesus Christ. 
T h e p ro p a g a tio n of one s faith is not som eth­ ing th at can be put on and put off like an over­ coat. It is a part of the very fabric of the healing ministry. 
The sharing of the faith is a stated purpose of a church-related hospital. 
It bears witness directly to a com passionate con­ c e rn th a t C h rist has created. It adds credibi­ lity to th e w itn e s s to those who are outside the im m ed iate touch of the hospital. 
It also has a particular concern to deal with the s p ir itu a l d im e n sio n of p e o p le ’s lives as they come into touch with the h o s p it a l’s p r o g ra m of healing and ministry. 
Faith 
Tax exemption does not simply center on the uti­ litarian nature of the ho­ s p i t a l ’s co n trib u tio n to th e c h a r ity w ork iii a c o m m u n ity . 
It also c e n te r s on th e u n iq u e nature of the propagating of the faith. 
“ T he power to tax is the power to destroy” has been a b a s ic axiom in considering relationships b etw een c h u rc h and state. 
In order to protect the propagation of the faith, the state has been, under our sy ste m , re s tra in e d from taxation of religious activities. To the degree a hospital performs these d is tin c tiv e ly re lig io u s m inistries, they are not s u b je c t to the ta x in g power of the state. 
* C h u rc h h o s p ita ls should serve the poor, not b ecau se they a re p r e s ­ sured to, but because it is a part of the basic nature of their being.

Oblate College of the 
Southwest will celebrate its 5oth anniversary as a p ro fe ssio n a l school of theology in San Antonio with a 7 p.m . concele­ brated Sunday Mass. 
Archbishop Francis J. 
Furry will preside at the 
Mass in the college’s Im­ m a c u la te 
C onception 
Chapel. 
Ministry in the m ulti­ cultural southwest is the theme of this anniversary year. 
T he co lleg e is sp o n ­ sored by a w orldw ide m issio n ary group, the 
Oblates of Mary im m a­ culate. 
Oblate offers two grad­ uate degree programs. 
The first p ro fessio n al degree for m inistry is called the Master of Di­ vinity. T he a c a d e m ic degree, the M aster of 
Theological Studies, is pastorally oriented. 
B esides religion and culture, two other basic thrusts of the college are to explore contemporary s p ir itu a lit y as it is em erging in the Ameri­ can Catholic Church and the w om an’s role in the church’s ministries.

SISTER JOAN LYNNE COE 

NUNS TESTIMONY 
There are no words to say all the blessings this revival has been on my life. G od has answered prayers of 
37 and even longer years. I knew the first night 
Brother 
Petty was a truly blessed man of God. The se­ cond nite I knew he was a Prophet called by G od to prepare the way of the 
Lord. 
I sensed he had been faithful to G od in the darkness of his room and of his life - obedient to 
G od s will and to the call G od placed upon his life. I had back pain since I 9 6 o ; two injuries and two slipped discs and surgery. There were months of pain so great I felt I could die of it. For four days at work I had been unable to walk straight or bend down. That second service I told two ladies my back hurt so bad I could hardly stand it and I cried with the pain. A short while toter 
Brother Petty siad, “ There is a lady here with back trouble (pain) & the Lord wants to heal it if she will come forth.” I was up to the alter in IO seconds. He told me to bend over three times which I did without any difficulty and no pain. It has not returned, and it never will return. The 
Lord has healed me. Glory to G o d and praise to 
Jesus, and thanks to 
Brother 
Petty for his obedience to the will of G od to let G od minister through his life and works. 
Sunday School 
1o:oo a.m. 
Morning Worship 
I 1:oo a.m. 
(Rev. W.A. Petty will be ministering) 
Camp Meeting Tabernacle 
3oo3 East Southcross 
Key. Petty: Pastor 
“The Church that Cares for You." 

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday April 3o 1977 
G ainers top losers, but m arket declines
