NMV YO RK (A P ) - 
The stock market was mixed Friday in a quiet session dominated by continuing speculation that the Federal Reserve had begun to tighten credit. 

The Dow Jones average of 3o industrial stocks slipped .42 to 926.9o. fin­ ishing the week with a net loss of .17. 

Most other indicators showed moderate gains for the day. Advances outnumbered declines by about a 5-3 margin on the 
New York Stock Ex ­ change. and the ex­ change’s composite in- ilex picked up .12 to 53.66. 
There were 18.33 mil­ lion shares traded on the 
Big Board, against 18.37 million Thursday. 

Jump 

As the market opened the Commerce Depart­ ment reported a 1.4 per cent jump in the index of leading economic indica­ tors last month—-the sharpest increase it has shown since July of 1975. 

The figures provided new evidence that business activity was rebounding strongly from the bad-weather setback it experienced early in the year. 

But analysts said the market was held back by concern that the Federal 
Reserve might have begun encouraging a rise in short term interest rates. 

Expectations that the 
Fed’s anti-inflation stra­ tegy might call for a slight tightening of credit have been prompted by a recent acceleration in the growth of the money supply. 

Standard & Poor’s in- 

Business and Finance 

 a*: if 

 dex of 4oo industrials rose .22 to 1o9 even, and 
S&P’s 5oo-stock compo­ site index was up .24 at 
98.44. 

Lucky Stores, the most active issue as of the 4 p.m. close of the NYSE, was up Va at 14(4. A 
187,7oo-share block trad­ ed at 131'2- 

General 
Electric climbed I Eg to 537% in active trading. The stock 

 has been strong since mid-week, when the company projected higher second quarter earnings. 

Burlington Northern gave up 1% to 49*4 on 
Securities and Exchange 
Commission criticism of the company’s financial reporting methods. 

Phillips Petroleum fell 
• 1V2 to 537/4 following the failure of another effort 
New potatoes get attention 

With the expiration on 
Friday of the May deli­ very, potato traders’ at­ tention will now be fo­ cused entirely on new crop conditions and pro­ spects. 
Last season’s huge re­ cord crop was the result of expanding planting in 
Idaho, Washington and 
Oregon and the prepon­ derance of supplies in that area led to dull cash 
. markets despite good ex­ port demand early in the season and heavy pro­ cessing activity. 
A cutback in plantings is in the offing for this year’s fall crop with a drop of 4 per cent from last season’s area fore­ cast of farmers inten­ tions. 
Spuds for November delivery have traded in a range of $5.3o to $6 per cwt. since the contract was listed last year. 
Also drawing notice over the balance of the 
Spring will be Florida orange groves.

Dry weather has. slowed new growth of late despite stepped up irrigational efforts by growers. 
It is generally the case that in a season follow ing a freeze, production suffers somewhat and even with normal preci­ pitation a smaller crop than that forecast prior to the freeze would seem to be in the offing. 
Currently, frozen con­ centrated orange juice futures are trading at the historically high levels of around 8o cents per pound, due in large part to the reductions in the yield of fresh oranges following the dehydrat­ ing effects of the January freeze. 

 to cap the Phillips oil well in the North Sea which blew out a week ago. 
Rallied 

Hospital stocks, which have been depressed recently by President 
Carter’s proposals to limit the rise of hospital rates, rallied on the strength of some an­ alysts’ favorable com­ ments on the group. 

Humana climbed I7-* to 
16%, and 
American 
Medicorp was up % ut 
9%. 

Pickwick International added 1% to 22 and 
American Can tacked on 
% to 39%. The two com­ panies announced a definitive merger agreement. 

In other markets, the 
American 
Stock 
Exchange market value index advanced .41 to 
112.17, and the NASDAQ composite index was up 
42 at 95.48. 
Change approved for bank 

Approval to reorganize 
Kelly Field National 
Bank as a bank holding company was granted 
Friday at a special meeting of bank stock­ holders. 

Under the proposed plan, which still requires governmental approval, 
Kelly Field Bancshares 
Corp. of Delaware would become the parent cor­ poration for the local in­ dependent bank. 

Kelly 
Bank share­ holders would trade holdings on a one-for-one basis for stock in the new corporation.

E x p r e s s - H e w s A n a l y s i s 

MONDAY — The Dow Jones Indus­ trial Average took a swan-dive, plung­ ing lO1^ points in the first hour of trading. The Dow wound up at a 15 month low at 914.6o (its lowest since 
Jan. 13, 1976, when it closed at 912.94), for a loss on the day of 12.47. Tape action indicated lack of desire to buy rather than dumping as volume ran a modest 2o.4 million shares. Analysts cited the negative attitude of buyers was fear of inflation, taxes and lack of confidence. 
TUESDAY - The Dow industrials held after dropping 28 points in three straight days. The industrial average advanced 1.o2, while the NYSE index of all common stocks lost o.o4 at 52.96. 
This was the lowest level for the NYSE index in 5 months (since Nov. IO when it closed at 52.9o). Brokers said cau­ tious buying and short covering halted the decline. 
WEDNESDAY 
— Bullish chart technicians said a “ double bottom’’ had been formed around the 91o-915 area on the chart pattern (made the first and last week in April). The market progressed higher at each hourly reading with the DJA1 closing up 8.14. Volume was slightly higher than Monday and Tuesday, Bullish items included corporate inventory re­ building and business productivity rose 3.2 per cent annual rate. 
THURSDAY - After drifting down­ ward in early trading, prices held, then turned upward. The Dow indus­ 

 trial average posted a plus 3.56 at the close. Volume of trading was at a re­ duced tempo. Helping the buy side of the market was a report that first quarter earnings of many companies were better than had been predicted. 
After the close the nation’s MI basic money supply for week ending April 2o was $321 billion vs. $321.3 billion the previous week. 
FRID AY — More stocks advanced than declined but the Dow Industrials closed with a tiny loss of o.42. The 4 p.m. New York Stock Exchange close showed advances leading declines by 
82o to 537. The N YSE index gained 
o.12. News item: Commerce Depart­ ment reported leading indicators rose 
1.4 per cent in March versus o.4 gained in February. 

SUMMARY - At the end of the week’s trading the market wound up about where it closed the previous week. The Dow Jones Industrial Aver­ age posted a tiny loss of o.17 and the 
NYSE of all common stocks another tiny loss of o.o3. Volume trading was 
8.1 million shares less than the pre­ vious week. 

R A N G E — High was made on Fri­ day at 931.99. Low was made on Tues­ day at 91o.36. Close, Friday, 926.9o. 
Loss on the week, o.17. Volume, all shares traded on the NYSE, 97.77 mil­ lion shares. 

ANALYSIS BY CHARLES CARDEN 
Food prices rising rapidly 

WASHINGTON (AF*) 
— Consumer food prices are inching up faster than had been expected and may average four to six per cent higher for the year than in 1976, the 
Agriculture Department said Friday. 
The new prediction fol­ lowed an announcement by the 
USDA’s 
Crop 
Reporting Board that prices of raw farm products rose 1.5 per cent from March 15 to April 
15, Hie fifth consecutive monthly increase. 
Officials said that 
“ even with the favorable weather, moderate (re­ 

 tail) price increases are in prospect in coming months for meats, dairy products, vegetable oils, processed fruits and vegetables and possibly sugar products.” 
The department had been predicting that re­ tail food prices may go up an average of four to 

 five per cent compared with the 3.1 per cent in­ crease in 1976. Food 
-prices rose 8.5 per cent in 
1975 and 14.5 per cent in each of the two previous years. 
“ For the consumer, the upward pressure on food prices this year has been largely due to sharply 

 higher prices for coffee and freeze damage to ci­ trus fruits and winter vegetables,” the depart­ ment said. 

Retail food prices in the first quarter were up three per cent from both the fourth quarter of last year and the first quarter 

 of 1976, “ a somewhat larger increase than ex­ pected earlier this year.” 

Officials said con­ sumers can expect “ ad­ ditional upward pressure will come from higher prices for coffee, cocoa, and other imported foods.” 
Continuing coffee shortage predicted

AG EN C E FRANCE PRESSE 
RIO DE JANEIRO — 
Coffee has gone up in price because of a short­ age, and this shortage will get worse in 1978, 
Eausto 
Cantu 
Pena, president of the Mexican 
Coffee Institute, said here. 
Cantil Pena, currently touring Latin American coffee producing countries, said the basic 

^CLASSIFIED DISPLAY 

Marketplace 

 reason for the sharp rise in world coffee rates was a shortage of supplies. 
This shortage was not solely due to temporary, climatic or political fac­ tors. There was also a structural problem stemming from the age of plantations: this, in turn, was the conse­ quence of low selling rates over the past de­ cade, he said. 
Cantu Pena added: 
“ Coffee prices in 1978 will be at least as high as they are now.”

CHICAGO (A P ) - Old crop soybean fu lures advanced 45 cents on the Chicago 
Board of Trade F rid a y a fte r four days of declines th a t totaled $1 23 
Soybean meal was up the allow able lim it of $15 a ton and soybean oil prices rose to the lim it of IOO points, or I cent a pound D eferred options in soybeans and in meal posted lesser gains but the near by oil options were about one ha lf as strong as the lim it close 
Wheat futures cam e under heavy late selling pressure and lost 5 cents. Corn and oats prices were n a rro w ly m ixed 
Iced b ro ile rs gained up to '? cent a pound a fte r a rath er m odestly traded ses sion. 
Soybean and meal futures were strong an the opening bell, advancing to near lim its under good, m ixed support 
There were sellers in the two pits but this con tinqent began to fade aw ay as prices rose. In the closing m inutes, the three old crop m onths touched lim its in the bean pit 
Oil trad e was considerably lighter than m eal or beans but new crop m onths were m ore a ttra ctive to the speculative e lem e nt 
The heavy demand in the com plex after 
(tour weak days was thought to have been largely speculative as tongs assumed new posituons a fte r the heavy seiloff 
There was some short covering early, however 
W heat, corn and oats prices were gen erally steady to a sh ade higher w a rly, but wheat futures then cam e under some liquidating pressure after the m idw ay point The new crop m onths were under 
Host pressure. Corn and oafs a ttracted good com m e rcial support and, late in the 
Jay, com m ission house buying. 
Opening of the session was delayed 15 m inutes because Thursday's heavy vol ume had caused some backshop prob lems. 
At the close, soybeans were 26 to 45 cents a bushel higher, M ay 9,85. wheat was t '4 to 5 low er. M ay 2.57+4, corn was unchanged to I Vi higher, M ay 2,48++ and bats were '4 lower to I higher, M ay I 74.

Page I 2-C_______San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS—-Saturday April 3o 1977 
M alpractice insurance is up to solons 

The end of the mal­ practice insurance crisis in Texas is now in the hands of the legislature, the head of the Texas 
Medical Assn. said Fri­ day. 
Dr. L.S. Thompson Jr. of Dallas was featured speaker to a group of seniors at the University of Texas Medical School at San Antonio at the 
Hilton Palacio del Rio 
Hotel. 
Dr. Thompson said it is 
4 federal lawyers honored 
Four assistant U.S. at­ torneys here have been honored for their work under U.S. Atty. John El 
Clark. 
John M. Pinckney III, 
Clark’s first assistant, has been praised by the head of the 
U.S. 
Immigration and Natur­ alization Service for his work enforcing federal immigration laws. 
And Asst. U.S. Attys. 
LeRoy M. Jalin, VV. Ray 
Jahn and James VV. Kerr have been named out­ standing assistant U.S. attorneys by the U.S. 
Justice Dept. 
LeRoy Jahn was cited for her work as head of the appellate section of 
Clark’s office. 
Ray Jahn is a trial at­ torney in the criminal section. He has spear­ headed the state-federal probe of South Texas banking irregularities. 
Kerr is the chief of the 
Controlled Substance 
Unit. 

 vital the state legislature pass laws to ease the medical malpractice in­ surance problem. 
“ The commission ap­ pointed by Gov. Dolph 
Briscoe to study the mal­ practice insurance problem concluded that the crisis has had an ad­ verse effect on both the cost and availability of medical care in our state,” he said. 
“ Its recommendations should not be ignored.” 
A bill, passed by the 
Senate two weeks ago, now includes a number of important amendments that would implement most of the commission’s key recommendations, he added. 
Hopeful 
“ The ultimate fate of this bill is now up to the conference committee,” he said. “ We are hopeful the committee will not undo the wgtk of the 
Senate. 
“ It would be foolish for lawmakers to ignore re­ commendations of the commission expressly created to study the problem.” 
The malpractice bill, among other things, pro­ vides for a statute of li­ mitations of two years from the date of alleged injury for those filing claims, limiting awards to $5oo,o(1o plus cost of past and future medical expenses and disallowing claims based only on an oral w arranty of cure. 
The bill also provides protection against suit for those who report legitimate concerns about alleged physician incompetency. 

S.A. schools not affected 

The Supreme Court’s recent ruling on corporal punishment in the public school will not affect the policy of six large San 
Antonio school districts. 
That was the indication given by superintendents of San Antonio, South San 
Antonio, 
Northside, 
North East, Harlandale and Southside districts. 
The nation’s highest court ruled 5-4 that cor­ poral punishment in public schools, no matter how severe, does not vio­ late constitutional pro­ tections against cruel and unusual punishment. 
North East Supt. Ivan 
Fitzewater said the dis- 

 preme Court ruling and would not be affected. 
Ed Cody, Northside su­ perintendent, said, “ We don’t see where it will change our procedure here.” 
Louis Bernal, South­ side superintendent, said corporal punishment al­ ready is in the district’s policy book. 
Charles Buggess, Har­ landale superintendent, and Harold Hitt, San An­ tonio district chief, both said the ruling did not affect their districts. 
Herbert Harper, South 
San Antonio superinten­ dent, said the South San board of trustees had 

N ancy N egley, left, president of the King William 
Assn., gives a helping hand to Vivian Hamlin, right, in the planting of a live oak tree Friday at 1o7 King 
W illiam St. The occasion w as in observance of 
Arbor Day. Assisting with the shovel work is W a n ­ da Ford. — Staff Photo by larky Tarsikes. 
Computer drill set 

Students from Boone, 
E’ive Palms and Kindred 
Elementary schools will compete in math drill and practice problems presented to them by the computer. 

Students from 
16 schools will show how they can use a computer in problem solving and math drill competition at 
8:.‘IO a.rn. Saturday in 
Region 2o’s Education 
Service Center. 
Students from 13 San 
Antonio area high schools will see how fast they can solve problems through the use of the computer, doing their own math programming. 
Competing will be stu­ dents from John Jay, 
Holmes, 
Marshall, 
Roosevelt, Judson, Cole, 
Fox 
Tech, 
Burbank, 
Highlands, Sam Houston, 
Jefferson, Lanier and 
Wheatley hirrh schools. 

 trict’s policy already is in 'authorized paddling be- keeping with the Su- fore the ruling. 
Council announces final appointments 

The outgoing City Council has announced ap­ pointments to three boards — the final choices it will make. 
Newly-elected council members take over next week. 
Olivia Garza was replaced on the zoning commis­ sion by Jesse Oviedo. 
Reappointed to the San Antonio Development 
Agency Board were the Rev. La Valle Lowe, Richard 
Borrengo and Mrs. Minnie Garcia, wife of State Rep. 
Matt Garcia. 
Baldemar Perez was appointed to replace outgo­ ing SADA board member Richard De Munbrun. 
Reappointed to the Carver Community Cultural 
Center Advisory Board were Velma Butler, Sister 
Mary Boniface, Dr. S.T. Scott and Mrs. Wilethel 
Brooks. 
Also appointed to the board were Joyce I). Sowells and Lois White, who replace outgoing members 
Norva Hill and Leonora Castellanos.

The Canonet G-lll 
17 is a compact 35mm rangefinder camera for snapshots or slides. It offers the convenience of fully automatic exposure control with a CdS photocell to give you perfect pictures every time. 

Many features developed for Canon’s -most expensive cameras are found in the G-lll I 7. It has a 6-element lens with Spectra Coating which guarantees excellent color balance. It uses cordless electronic flash with its special D ay ’n Night control. It has a film wind indicator, OL quick film loading mechanism, self-timer, and battery check. It has nine speeds from I /4 to I /SOO of a second and B. And the G-lll 17 gets all its power from one tiny inexpensive 1,3V mercury battery.

Now you can have a beautiful green lawn 

 f m 
§§§ fplt 
• I 

 without work or worry thanks to liquid fertilizers applied by a-PernnvGreen. 

A greener lawn is whal you'll notice first— usually within IO to 14 days after we first spray your lawn. 
It will be greener because it is healthier. Greener because a-Perm-o-Green’s nutrients are promoting a deep root system and strong stems and blades. 
You’ll notice something else too, no chinch bug or grub worm problems because a-Perm-o-Green applies the correct insecticide at the right time— before damage is done. 
Join the thousands who are enjoying greener, healthier lawns thanks to a-Perm-o-Green applica­ tions last year. Your satisfaction is assured or you don’t owe us a cent. 

Why is a-Perm-o-Green NO effective? 
. 
Your lawn is sprayed with liquid fertilizer specially prepared by a-Perm-o-Green to meet current soil, temperature and moisture conditions. 
Nutritional elements plus nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium are seasonally adjusted to promote the growth most beneficial at the time of application. 
Research proves that proper nutrition— rather than the soil itself— makes the difference between success and failure in creating a beautiful lawn. And creating beautiful lawns is what a-Perm-o-Green is all about. 

Avm ^ M iJ g 1 flS hw ^ oaWrna7 « P M o?sabte to buy fertilizers and insecticides in quantity and pass the savings on to you. The average size lawn really 

 does average less than $2o per application— about the same as if you bought materials and applied them yourself (not counting the trips you’d make to the fertilizer store, the time and gamble over the correct mix to use, and the spreader equipment you’d have to rent or buy!) 

When do, you join the program? Now! 
Over the next few week^our lawn care profes­ sionals will take the a-Perm-o-Green trucks out to spray this year’s first treatments on lawns throughout this area. 
Make sure your home is one of our first stops. Call us right now!

San Pedro Hills calls you to country living 

The best of luxury living is in San Pedro Hills, an established com m unity of fine homes in north central 
San Antonio. 
The beautiful hills of San 
Pedro Hills are blossuming with luxurious new homes. These distinctive homes will be open for a springtime showing this weekend. 
Hillside sites 

These homes are especially designed for hillside sites over­ looking San Antonio. Soaring ceilings, large fireplaces, ex­ pansive living areas and easy care kitchens complement the gently bending oaks which sur­ round most homes. 
Quality in design and con­ struction is a trademark of San 
Pedro Hills builders. This tra­ dition is felt in every home and garden home. The workmanship is superb. No detail has been spared in making every one a high quality home. 
San Pedro Hills community has a swim and recreation club. 
Membership is included in the purchase of a new home and al­ lows the use of the swimming pool and recreational area. The club is another part of the total community in San Pedro Hills. 
San Pedro Hills proudly pre­ sents affordable country living in that its prestige homes are priced from as low as $48,ooo. 
The community is planned to grow quietly in its natural wooded environment without disturbing the things that make it unique. Only the highest qua­ lity in construction is consi­ 

SAN PEDRO HILLS is a north central San Antonio com m unity which invites all to see country, luxurious living in homes built affo rd ab iy 

 dered, from the ground up. 
Every home is considered ex­ clusive to blend with its natural surrounding. 
A special kind of American dream lives here with the inde­ pendence of owning a home and the practicality of making the smartest possible investment for now and future years. This investment is the surest way to let your money grow while 

 building your equity. The mort­ gage interest and property taxes paid are deductible from income taxes. Ultimately, home owners here pay less for their homes than they think. 
San Pedro Hills has been de­ signed with children in mind, too; future school sites are cen­ trally located. All children at­ tend schools in the North East 
District, San Antonio’s finest. 

The recreation spectrum here is offered to all residents. San 
Pedro Hills features a private center with an Olympic size pool, bath houses and tennis courts. A perfect place your children to play? You bet, with miles of open spaces and wind­ ing roads perfect for cycling and exploring nature. 

This sparkling community is 

 located in north central San 
Antonio so as to let residents enjoy the benefits of country living with actual “ in town’’ convenience. 
San Pedro Hills boasts nearby shopping centers, churches, en­ tertainment and medical faci­ lities. The neighborhood even offers a park now under way and, at the same time, affords easy access to downtown in 

 minutes by the present Loop 411) interchanges and, in the near future, directly by the North 
Expressway. 
Come feel the tradition in San 
Pedro Hills. Homes will be open from noon until dusk. Luxury homes are priced from $48,ooo. 
Simply exit from NAV. Loop 
41o to San Pedro Avenue (U.S. 
Hwy. 281 N.) and proceed north to the entranceway.

Antonio, offers fresh alter­ natives for the home buyer of moderate income who is looking for a quality home in a beautiful setting but at p ric e s that fit the fam ily budget.

 ting the dream of a new home 
“ out of reach” for the average home buyer, Ray Ellison Homes is offering a wide variety of fresh floor plans and exteriors in an attractive price range of 
$28,ooo to $35,ooo. 
Outside city limits

 more attractive than rent in more ways than one. 
But sky Harbour homes are in no way mere “ shell” homes.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW S— Saturday April 3o I 977 
Rusticity, splendor 

 make Fair Oaks ideal 
If ever you had the in­ clination to own a piece of land, now is the time to make that dream a reali­ ty. Some of the most beautiful Hill Country land available is just north of San Antonio at 
Fair Oaks. 
Steeped in recent his­ tory as a thoroughbred race horse and cattle ranch. Fair Oaks has been carefully developed by the Don Smith Co. into one- to 15-acre tracts that provide dramatic, oak- covered homesites that can be purchased and built on now or later. 

Wide paved streets through the area have been named after the fa­ mous race horses and tracks of the world, and there are miles and mites of riding trails for equestrians. 
Amenities 
Recreational facilities abound at Fair Oaks. The 
Fair Oaks Racquet and 
Swim Club offers eight tennis courts, a practice court and a super size swimming pool sur­ rounded by following lawns and great oak trees. 

A clubhouse, with Pro 
Shop and dressing faci­ lities, is adjacent to the pool and courts. Profes­ sional tennis instruction will be provided by Mike 
Moore, in cooperation with Bill O’Bryant of 
McFarlin Tennis Center. 

Golfers have not been forgotten at Fair Oaks. 
At the very heart of the development is a cham­ pionship - quality golf course now under con­ struction. The course, designed by professional golfer Gary Player and 

Hon Kirby of Kirby / 
Player & Associates, Golf 
Course Architects, will feature a 
6,756-yard course that traverses the undulating terrain of 
Fair Oaks as one that will offer sufficient challenge for highly experienced players and average players alike. 

 h air Uaks offers a life in the country yet pro- v ides the conveniences of city - type utilities and ready access to N. VV. Ill ll) for commuting lo San 
Antonio. It is just a short driving distance to UT- 

The rustic beauty of 
Fair Oaks is seen in the splendor of the main clubhouse and its manicured grounds. This soon will be the center of activity at Fair Oaks. 

SA, USAA. the South 
Texas Medical Center, major shopping malls 

 and entertainment in northwestern 
San 
Antonio.

SanAntonioEXPRESS-NEW S— Saturday April 3o I 977 

W oodbridge Phase ll holds grand opening 

Woodbridge, where leisurely lifes styles thought impossible by many become enjoyable rea­ lities at affordable prices, is holding a Grand Opening for its 
Phase II this weekend. 
On th e p re m is e s of th e se sta te ly townhouses is a recreational package c a r e f u lly o la n n ed to g iv e y e a r s of pleasure to 
Woodbridge residents. 
Leisure is plentiful here, for residents n ev er need to worry about m a in te n ­ ance of their townhomes or their se­ curity. 
Joyful discovery 
W oodbridge, 31o2 and 31o3 Eisen- tiauer Rd., already has been the joyful discovery of numerous San Antonians. 
In fact, its first phase, on the south 

 side of E isen h au e r Road, is alm ost sold out. This, however, is the adult- oriented part of Woodbridge. 
Two lighted, acrylic-surfaced tennis courts, two swim m ing pools, two club­ houses and a picnic garden area m ake 
W oodbridge m ore than ju st a hom e address. I f s a total environment, per­ fect for active life styles of profession­ als or those who want the most out of retirement. 
One c lu b h o u s e f e a tu re s a p a rty room , kitchen and g am e room ; the other, a sundeck, ping-pong table and firepit for cookouts. 
All this is for the exclusive enjoy­ m e n t of W oodbridge re s id e n ts and their guests. 
T h e in te r io rs of th e W oo d b rid g e tow nhouses a re visually exciting by their “ open” design accomplished by b ro ad w indow ex p a n se s, h an d so m e 

 fireplaces and lavish finishing touches. 
E x tra la rg e 17- by 24-foot m a s te r bedrooms are common at Woodbridge. 
So a re fash io n a b le c o m p a rtm e n te d baths. One of the W oodbridge plans has two com partm ented baths off the sam e bedroom — one for him, another for her. Larger units have 3*/fe baths. 
All Woodbridge townhouses have at least V-fii baths, each stunningly fin­ ished w ith h an d -an tiq u ed cab in ets, rich coordinated w allpaper and large lighted m irrors. Each town home also has a fireplace and a balcony. 
T hree m odels ra n g e in size from 
1,75o to 2,7oo sq. ft. The buyer has a choice of a two-car carport or a totally enclosed garage. 
Buyers also are given their choices in selecting colors for the attractive interiors of their townhomes. They can select floor covering, w allpaper and 

 even colors for vanities. 
T h e k itch en s, too, a r e unusually a ttr a c tiv e and fully eq u ip p ed with top-name appliances. They feature an exceptional amount of storage, plus a built-in planning desk, complete with drawers. 

Energy-saving features are common to W oodbridge tow nhom es, too. The cost of operating utilities is lessened substantially by eight inches of solid 

 in su latio n inside the o u ts id e walls; w e a th e rs trip p in g on o u ts id e doors; bronze, solar-paned glass; all-electric appliances; and separate healing and air conditioning systems. 
W ith in 
N .E . 
Loop 
41o, the 
W oodbridge Townhomes a r e conven­ iently near N.E. III 35 and North Star, 
Central P ark and Windsor P a rk Malls. 
T hey’re also close to the business and professional centers of the North Side, 
Alamo Heights and downtown. 

W o o d b r id g e 
T o w n h o m e s, 
3 1 o 2 and 3 1 o 3 Eisenhauer 
Rd. in northeastern San A n ­ tonio, is holding the grand opening of its Phase ll this weekend. The project is ideal for the active professionals or the com fortably retired since it o ffe rs a m p le r e c r e a tio n a l amenities for both and a care­ free life style which requires no time or work for m ainten­ ance o f either the residences or the premises. 

Security of all residences is d e te r­ mined not only by limited access to the project’s prem ises but also a highly tra in ed , 24-hour se c u rity p atro l on guard seven days a week. 
Woodbridge Townhomes are priced from as low as $47,5oo to $8o,ooo. 
The project is reached m ost easily by exiting from N.W. Loop 41o to Harry 
W urzbach Road and g o ing south to 
E isenhauer Road, where a turn right leads to Woodbridge Townhomes.

‘‘The U.S. single-tamiiy housing m a r k e t is en te r­ ing the peak Spring and 
S u m m e r season s in the best s h a p e in m a n y a y e a r . ”

P on ti u s, exe cu tiv e vice president of the National 
Association of Realtors, in t h e a s s o c i a t i o n ’s m on th ly real e state sta-* tus report. 

Rare mesh 

“ W i t h a l i t t l e b it of luck. 1977 could easily be t h e b e s t y e a r e v e r for single-family con struc­ tion and the sale of both new and existing single­ family h o m e s , ” Ponti us said. 

Noting a r a r e m esh of supply and d e m a n d , the report ob serves that: 

• 
New single-family c o n stru cti o n is b ooming and should m a k e this the greatest single-family housing production y ear of the decade. 

• O n e h a l f of all new h o m e b u y e r s m u s t sell t h e i r e x i s t i n g h o m e . 
T h u s, li s tin g s of re s a le p r o p e r t i e s should grow s u b s t a n t i a l l y , t h o u g h p e rh a p s not a rate suffi­ c i e n t to m e e t th e de mand s. 

• T h e m o rtg a g e m a rk e t is highly favorable, with a record rate of deposits into the thrift institutions m a k i n g fu n d s a v ail ab le to fi nance th e expected b r i s k s a l e s a c t i v i t y of s i n g l e - f a m i l y h o u s i n g this Spring. 

As to d e m a n d for h o u s i n g , t h e r e p o r t points to a n u m b e r of fa­ vorable factors. A large pe rcentage of households a r e h e a d e d by th o se in the 25-35 ag e range, the p rim e age for buying the f i r s t h o m e . C o n s u m e r c o n f i d e n c e , th e r e p o r t says, has b een re sto red by im p r o v e m e n ts in the o v erall e c o n o m y a n d a rise in em p lo y m e n t and personal income. 

“ T h e r e a r e few good r e a s o n s fo r p o t e n t i a l bu ye rs to rem ain on the sid e lin es," Pontius said. 
“ M an y feel th a t the o p ­ p o rtu n itie s to a c q u ir e a single-family home will not be a s good a s nex t y e a r . H o m e p r i c e s a r e e x p e c t e d to r i s e , a n d m o r tg a g e interest credit is e x p e c t e d to be m o r e expensive in 1978.”

When making a major purchase, it is a great satisfaction to know that the man you're dealing with is competent in his field and really knows what he is talking about.

Ask him for references in the neighborhood: the names of local ho­ meowners for whom he recently did work. Check with those people. Their com m ents are much more meaningful than the testimonials of TV comedians or football stars.

Burns Co. building for ‘first family 

GREAT A M ERICA features coxy, spacious dens in hom es 

It’s not even open yet, but the Michael Billings­ ley family is taking no chances with their new homesite in Royal Ridge. 
The family got the jump on San Antonio Ut be the “ first family” in town to select a new home location in the 
Burns Co. portion of the development. The firm is yet to open its new area. 
By June 
The 128-tract portion, scheduled to begin con­ struction in April with new homes ready for oc­ cupancy in June, peace­ fully sits among the wooded rolling hills of northeastern 
Bexar 
County. The roads, as yet unpaved, gently sweep through the area, follow­ ing the natural contours of the land to preserve as much of the natural set­ ting as possible. Hilltop sites offer a splendid view of the San Antonio skyline by day; a twin­ kling array of distant city lights by night. 
This quiet, spacious countryside setting was just what Diane Billings­ ley wanted for the chil­ dren. She added that the 

 location is minutes away from the family’s place of worship; her hus­ band’s position at Fort 
Sam Houston; excellent schools for Scott and Re­ becca; and major shop­ ping malls and enter­ tainment facilities for the whole family. 
The Billingsley family came to San Antonio from West Point only three months ago when 
Michael accepted a resi­ dency in oral surgery at 
Brooke Army Medical 
Center. The whole family fell in love with the cli­ mate and friendliness of the Alamo City, and they decided to make this their permanent home. 
Rather than rent, Mi­ chael and Diane knew the advantages of invest­ ing in home ownership. 
And after shopping over 
San Antonio’s home­ builders, they chose the 
Burns Co. to build their first home. 
Why Burns? Their commitment to energy conservation, say M i­ chael and Diane. 
Every Burns Co. home is built with the proven 
“ Power Saver” con­ struction techniques to

Don’t drain 
If your house is heated with a hot water boiler, there is no reason to change the water. They hydronie system is sealed, and any impur­ ities brought in with the fresh water originally have lo settled out. 
Bringing in new water also brings in new im­ purities. They are not of great significance unless you keep adding fresh water repeatedly so, don’t do it, advises the 
Better Heating-Cooling 
Council.

FIRST fam ily to m ove in soon 

NOW IS THE TIME 
TO BU Y A NEW HOM E 

This New Hogtie 
Costs Less Than 
Your Old Home. 

I ’m Buddy Burns. And I d like to shed some licht on your old home, lf your home is 
5 years old or older, chances are it's obsolete. 
That's right, obsolete. Be­ cause at the time your home was built, there were virtually no energy-effi- ciency standards. As a result, many San Antonians are faced with utility bills that may soon exceed their house payments! 

Why N O W Is The Time To Buy. 
Let's look at the facts. Since you invested in your home a few years ago, two things have hap­ pened. For one, you've been making house payments for sev­ eral years, so your equity has grown. Tot*, since the cost of building a new home has stead­ ily increased, the cost of replac­ ing your home has increased. 
BUT, because your old home isn't energy efficient, it wastes valuable energy. And believe it or not, homeowners around the country are actually beginning to lose money when they sell their older homes. Because no­ 

 body wants to buy a home where the cost of heating and cooling ayments. 
IXJ exceeds the monthly pa 
M y advice is this: With the money you can make by selling your old home right now, you can probably make the down­ payment and move into a new 
Burns Co. Power Saver '*' home today. And, while your house payments may be a little higher, the lower utility bills should easily offset the difference. The only thing you can't afford to do is wait much longer.

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday April 3o I 977 
* 

On how to control lawn problems 

By TERRY WILBOURN 
C O U N T Y E X T E N S IO N H O R TIC U LTU R IS T 
Spring always brings a flurry of activity for many of us, par­ ticularly when it comes to lawn chores. Indeed, this is the time to perform many chores to maintain a healthy grass. 
Apparently, I have opened a can of worms, so to speak, with my com­ ments on applying soii to a lawn. Some misunderstanding has arisen, perhaps due to the fact that I did not fully ex­ plain the advantages and disadvan- 

CtA&UFUED DISPLAY 

 tages of applying soil to the lawn. 
I suppose previous implications were to never use topsoil. This is not so. 
Good quality topsoil is definitely an asset when establishing or putting in a lawn. 
Many of the soils are shallow and rocky, while others are comprised mostly of caliche. In this case, adding six to 12 inches of good topsoil to the lawn will provide a good base for grass establishment. 
Also, there may be situations where applications of topsoil to an established or growing lawn will be beneficial. 

C l A SU FWD DISPLAY 
CLASSIFIED DISPLAY 

3 AND 4 BEDROOMS 

M A R K E T E D E X C L U S IV E L Y 

B y W A L T C O R N E L I U S 

828-6343 

*33,65o to *36,ooo 
8 % V A Financing 
FH A & C onv. A v a ila b le 

N O R T H S ID E S C H O O L S : 3 B K S . F R O M 

E L E M E N T A R Y 
& - C L O S E 
T O 
H O L M E S 

H IG H 
& 
S '.'L 
R O S S 
JR 
H I G H — F E A 

T U R IN G : 

• 2 B ath s • C u sto m C a b in e ts • C e n tra l 

H e a t & 
A ir • Lots O f C lo se t S p a c e • 

H ig h O n A Hill. 

O p e n 1o A M Til D ark 
H.P. ORTS CONSTRUCTION 
Sales Off: 6oo3 White Clodd 
6 8 4 -1 3 8 6 

This would be true if there are low spots in the yard where water stands. or if there are areas that have eroded. 
Light applications to areas that have been killed or injured by chinch bugs and / or grubworms will definitely help in re-establishment. 
If you have a healthy, vigorous lawn grass, I still do not think it’s wise or necessary to apply topsoil to the top of the grass. Certainly do not make it an annual practice. I have seen lawns where weed seeds and sprigs were brought in with the topsoil. Also, grubworms could be introduced. Cer­ tainly the source of the soil would be a factor here." 
When we say “ good quality" topsoil, one generally is referring to a sandy loam. A sandy loam is far superior to the heavy clays one may obtain. A true loam soil contains about equal parts of sand, silt and clay. Of course, a sandy loam would contain slightly more sand by volume than silt and clay. This type soil would be a welcomed addition to many of our yards at lawn establish­ ment time or when rejuvenating weak or dead grass. 
Topsoil is sold by the cubic yard; so, if you were to put two inches over dead or weak areas to rejuvenate the grass, one cubic yard would cover approxi­ mately 162 sq. ft. If you were applying six inches over an area to establish a lawn, one cubic yard would cover ap­ proximately 54 sq. ft. 
Worst lawn pest 

The chinch bug is probably the worst lawn pest we have here in South Texas. 
It seriously damages St. Augustine grass. As the insect sucks the plant juices, it releases a poison that causes yellowish to brownish patches to ap­ pear in lawns. If the attack does not kill the plant, it recovers slowly, and the lawn looks bad for a long time. I 

 am presently seeing a few chinch bug - damaged lawns; so. be on the lookout for them. 
These discolored areas are generally where sunshine strikes the lawns se­ veral hours daily. The chinch bug is a sunshine - loving insect and seldom at­ tacks grass in a dense, shady area. It is about a fifth of an inch long when ma­ ture. It is black with white patches on its wings, which it folds over its back. 
If you decide to wait on spraying, be sure to check your lawn for this pest on a sunny day each week during the 
Summer. You can readily find chinch bugs by slowly sliding your foot through the sod and watching for the bugs to crawl across your shoe. 
Another way to check for them is to cut the top and bottom out of a fairly large can to form a cylinder. Press this into the ground in areas where the chinch bug is suspected. Fill with water and watch for the insects float to the top. 
There are numerous chemicals one can use to kill chinch bugs. They are 
Aspern, carbaryl, diazinon, Dursban, ethion or Trithion. With each chemi­ cal, read the label for rates to use and precautions and use each accordingly. 
If your lawn has a history of chinch bug problems, you most probably will have them to some extent this year. If they are to be present this year, they will be there now in a young, immature stage. They are harder to recognize and actually won’t be doing any signi­ ficant damage, but they are easier to kill now. 
So, sometime in April or the first part of May would be a good time to put out your controls. 
Dreaded disease 

Brown patch is a discase that causes many gardeners much concern in try­ ing to maintain a beautiful lawn. The 

 fungus that is responsible for brown patch attacks almost all species of grasses but is more serious on bent­ grass. bluegrass, St. Augustine and centipede grasses. Brown patch is one of the most prevalent lawn diseases during warm, humid periods of time. 
There are several factors that tend to make the grass more susceptible to brown patch. One of these is the ex­ cessive application of nitrogen ferti­ lizer. This promotes a lush growth of grass that is readily attacked. Another condition that leads to severe disease development is watering late in the afternoon and allowing the grass to remain wet for long periods of time. 
Also, the buildup of thatch is another condition that promotes excessive dis­ ease development. 
Thatch is the buildup of grass and plant debris in the root and crown area of the turf. The accumulation of thatch creates a most favorable environment for the development of many disease - causing fungi and, at the same time, a most unfavorable environment for the graSvS. 
Brown patch is characterized by the development of irregular circular ar­ eas a few inches to several feet in dia­ meter. These areas may have a brow­ nish to gray discoloration. In certain grasses, a narrow, dark smoke • co­ lored ring may border the disease ar­ ea. These watersoaked or scalded spots 

 in the lawn spread very rapidly, be­ coming large brown areas, 
Generally, brown patch attackes on­ ly the leaves and stems of the grass; however, if it is not controlled, it can attack the roots and kill large areas of the lawn. Brown patch is quite severe on St. Augustine in the Spring, espe­ cially at temperatures of 
6o to 75 degrees F. At temperatures of 8o degrees F and above and under low moisture conditions, the activity of tho fungus decreases. 

Prevention is the best method of disease control. To prevent brown patch or other lawn diseases from de­ veloping. practice the following control procedures: 

•Manage the lawn properly by using recommended practices of watering, fertilizing and mowing procedures. 

•Follow procedures for thatch con­ trol. 

•When brown patch is a problem. limit the amount of nitrogen fertilizer applied. 

•When brown patch occurs, use one of the following fungicides: PCNB. 
Byrnie, Daconil 2787. 

Bo sure to follow the instructions given on the label aS to the rate to use and time of application.

Bv TEK RY WILBOURN 
C O U N T Y E X T E N S IO N H O R TIC U LTU R IS T 
Every year I grow' sweet corn in my garden, I have worms in the ear. Is there any way to prevent these worms from getting in? 

The corn earworm is definitely a problem and one difficult to control. 
You need to keep either a spray or dust of Sevin on 

 the ear from the time the silks appear to harvest. 
This may mean applying every other day. 

Chinch bugs damage my St. Augustine grass every year. Is there any way to prevent them from damaging my yard? 

If the chinch bug is to be a problem this year, he will be present now in a young, immature stage. 
Consequently, 

Questions on various 

 aspects of lawn, garden or plant care, as well as landscaping, can be ans­ wered in this column. 
Please address any corre­ spondence to the colum­ nist himself and not to this 

 c lX ssTfied d is p l a y 

I n c r e d i b l e ? ! 

 putting out your controls in April or the first of 
May is advisable. The chinch bug is easier to control then.

Larry Rosow and Mar­ vin Kline have announced the addition of two resi­ dential sales associates to their staff of Rosow & 
Kline, Realtors. 
Each addition was made at the realty firm’s office at 5226 Fredericks­ burg Rd. 
Dianne Reeves, a na live Lousianan, graduat­ ed from the University of 
Southern 
Mississippi with a degree in psycho­ logy and education. She was a co - founder and assistant director of the 
Mississippi Gulf Coast 
Drug Abuse Center. She has been a member of the Harrison County 
United Way Board, the 
Gulf Coast Association for Mental Health and the Harrison County Help 
Line. 
A San Antonian since 
1957, Elouise Arbuckle graduated from the 
American College of 
Real Estate here and worked for Southwestern 
Bell Telephone Co. and 
Gill Cos., Realtors. 

Heat control 
Modern apartment buildings usually permit each tenant to dial his own heat. A single cen­ tral control can cause 
•overheating of some apartments just to get adequate heat to the more remote ones, and builders know they can save that wasted fuel by providing each apart­ ment with its own ther­ mostat, comments the 
Better Heating-Cooling 
Council.

San Antonio EX PR ESS-N EW S— Saturday April 3o 1977 

Bill Ash, center, director and sales manager of Great America, Realtors, announced the winner at the close of an eight-week listing contest. Associate Fred Mosley received a m icrow ave oven for listing alm ost 

$2oo,ooo of residential properties. Asso­ ciate Marian Tilson was named “ Associate of the M o n th " for her contribution of 
$ I 38,ooo in sales. 

S o l a r f u e l 

 w o r k s w e l l 

 a t p r e s e n t 

By KAY RAGSDILL 
PRESIDENT. S A 
BOARD OE REALTORS 
If nothing else. lust 
Winter’s frigid tempera­ tures and fuel shortages in much of the nation convinced many Ameri­ cans that the era of cheap, plentiful fossil fuels is coming to an end. 
It became obvious that alternative sources of energy must be found and developed. 
One of the most fre­ quently discussed alter­ natives is solar energy. It has three endearing qua­ lities: it’s plentiful; ifs non-polluting; and. best of all. it's free. But. is solar energy a dream for tomorrow or does it have practical applications today? The answer to both questions is yes. 
Developed 
According to John 
Blake, executive director- of the Solar Energy In­ dustries 
Association 
(SE JA ), the technology for solar home heating and water heating is well developed. Although re­ finements in current sys­ tems may take place, further engineering 
'breakthroughs are not expected. 
The S E IA . a three - year - old organization, represents 122 manu­ facturers of solar equip­ ment plus 193 contractor 
- installers. 
Solar air conditioning is about three years away from becoming economi­ cally feasible, Blake says, while conversion of solar energy into electri­ city is still in the deve­ lopment stages. 
Blake says that no one really knows how many homes in the United 
States are now equipped with solar space heating or water heating equip­ ment. Such statistics have not been kept. How­ ever. in light of current consumer interest stimu­ lated by rising energy 
Am erican 
College makes move 
Construction is under way on the new head­ quarters and classroom facilities for the Ameri­ can College of Real 
Estate. 
The property, at 485o 
Walzem Rd., was recent­ ly purchased by the 
American College of Real 
Estate and, in addition to remodeling a portion of the building for adminis­ trative offices, 1,ooo sq. ft. of space is being add­ ed for a modern class-- room facility. 

 costs, the future of solar energy in the country looks bright. 
According to the SEIA, within five years more than 498.ooo homes will be equipped with solar water heaters. About 
34.3oo will be equipped with solar heating as well, lf Congress passes incentive tax credit le­ gislation proposed by the 
SEIA , the rate of installations could great­ ly accelerate. 

Such legislation would help home owners and home buyers overcome what is now a high hur­ dle, the steep initial cost of installation. Installa­ tion of a solar water heater can range in price from $9oo to $1,2oo. 
Installation of space heating can cost $8,ooo to 
$8,ooo. And that’s in un average new home. In­ stallation in an existing home is more expensive. 
It must be tutted that these costs do not include costs for necessary back­ up systems. Such sys­ tems. which can be tied into the solar systems, are needed to provide heat and hot water when stored solar energy is exhausted during pro­ longed overcast periods or cold spells. 
It is possible ti* build systems that could pro­ vide IOO per cent of a home's needs. However, the costs are prohibitive. 
Systems that can provide 
OO to 7o per cent of a home’s heating needs and 7o to 8o per cent of tile hot water required are feasible. 
In spite of high initial costs and the need for backup systems, instal­ lation of solar equipment makes sense now in cer­ tain cities, according to a recently released study conducted by the U. S. 
Energy and Research 
D e v e I o p rn e n t A d m i n i s * tration (ERDA). In com­ paring the costs of solar and electrical energy, the study concluded that installation of solar space and water heating equip­ ment would pay for itself in IO to 15 years in such cities as New York, Mia­ mi. Boston, Atlanta and 
Los 
Angeles, among others. 
Detailed information on solar systems and a comprehensive listing of manufacturers and ser­ vice organizations in the solar industry can be found in the Solar In­ dustry Index published by the SEIA . You can obtain a copy by sending a check for $1o to Solar 
Industry 
Index, 
IGOI 
Connecticut Ave., NAV., 
Suite 832, Washington, D. 
C. 2oo36.

GARDEN HOME

Solar I Home debuts in Talisman 

How far in the future is the self-sufficient, solar- powered home? 
The answer is that it no longer is in the future. It has arrived, in part at least, in 
Talisman 
Estates near New Braun­ fels, where Comal Solar 
Homes is introducing the 
Solar I Home. 
Prepared 

This home, engineered by G. F. Gorman of Co­ mal Solar Homes, is, by builder’s choice, not fully 
{lowered by the sun. But, by the buyer's choice, it can be converted to full, self-sufficient solar power even without structural alterations. It was built to suit the buyer's desires. 

As it is now, this spa­ cious. all-brick home containing 1.65o sq. ft. of living area plus a 6oo sq. ft. double garage can house a family of five who would pay less than 
Va of normal utility costs! 

Nothing experimental was used to achieve this modern-day wonder. 
Everything it features has been tested success­ fully in other parts of the country. And ifs offered at a modest price: 
$55,ooo. 

The home operates with solar power on all but light fixtures, range, oven and the buyer’s refrigerator. Most so­ called “ solar-assisted” homes use the sun’s power for only the water heating system, but, with this home, Comal Solar 
Homes has gone far beyond that and assures the buyer that he or she can opt for more to the point of full solar power throughout the home. 
Normal utilities are available as a back-up system. 
But tbe quantity of so­ lar power is not all this energy-saving home fea­ tures. The Solar Home I may draw from the sun’s unlimited power, but Co­ mal Solar Homes is concerned with helping 
Mother Nature do her thing with the greatest of ease by providing her with the best man-made insulative products. 
Special insulation here is added to standard in­ sulation, i.e., one-inch urathane wrapped with asphalt. This feature goes not only into walls and ceilings but even se­ parates the home from its firm, reinforced foun­ dation! The home is di­ vided into three sections, each insulated separately from one another for hampering cold, heat and even sound. 
Placement and kinds of windows also add to the energy-saving devices this home boasts. There actually are two separate window systems — out­ side, solar gray windows are sealed into structure to prevent infiltration of unwanted air, yet they can be opened for fresh air. They are arranged in a hot-cold opposing man­ ner to maintain air flow. 

The home also has special steel-encased doors which also feature urathane and seal tightly w hen closes. 

Even the fireplace of this home helps Mother 
Nature do her thing for the family. It is designed to use outside air for combustion of wood, and even that is controllable as it was with the effi­ cient cookstove used in the past. Ecology enters the picture with the out­ side ash dump. Heatila- tors, normally powered, in the fireplace utilize power fans to move addi­ tional warm air through the house; a glass fire screen seals when closed; and the opening at its chimney prevents con­ densation build-up. 
There’s more for 
Mother Nature: a new 
Kohler water-saving plumbing is used for the 
12o-gallon hot water tank unit with two small pumps which, together, use less energy than two 
1oo-watt light bulbs. This unit is guaranteed for five years, but, under normal usage, could last for another 15. Note, too, that hot water heaters, even under normal fami­ ly usage, constitute about 
2o per cent of what ap­ pears on a monthly elec­ tric bill. 
The attic ventilators are thermostatically con­ trolled to prevent heat build-up in the Summer and have eave vents to provide free flow of air. 
The air conditioning system here is more than ample for the entire liv­ ing area of the home. It’s a Pjj-ton unit with 18,726 
BT Us. 
The Solar I system is engineered fur today and 

 the future. The following contractors contributed a major effort in the con­ struction of this 
“ breakthrough” home: 
F’aul Crawford (New 
Braunfels), special foun­ dations; Robert Biggen, special framing; Don 
Bolt Insulation Co., spe­ cial insulation and vapor barrier insulation; Cole­ man Electric Co., special electric wiring and power controls; Hang Decorat­ ing Center, color coor­ dination; Williams Heat­ ing and Air Conditioning, economy-designed heat­ ing and air conditioning; 
V’oges Plumbing Co., special plumbing make­ up and solar installation by distributors of Sola- tron Solar Panels and 
Equipment; and Alenco, 

 special windows. Realtor is Easy Hall Realty, New 
Braunfels. 

The home, quite con­ ventional in its appear­ ance, does prove that a solar-fueled home need not be an architectural monstrosity for the sake of lower utility bills. In fact, it can even be as handsome as this one. 
Talisman Estates is reached most easily by exiting from N.E. IU 35 onto Walnut (Hwy. 46 
N.E.), proceeding north 
6M2 miles, turning right onto Bear Creek Road, right again where Talis­ man 
Estates sign is seen, right onto Talisman 
Road itself and then left to Amulet and the new 
.Solar I Home.

COMPOED FROM WIRE SERVICES 
W A SHINGTON 
- 
T he 
H ouse 
F rid a y overwhelmingly voted to pass tough legislation to control coal strip m ining and to reclaim the moonscape of abandoned ininplands across the country. 
The vote to send the bill to the Senate was 241 to 
64. 
Before p a ssa g e , the House d efeated by a shouted voice vote a move to exem pt som e strip m ines from sev eral strin g en t sta n d a rd s for restoring the land after gouging eoal seam s from beneath the surface. 
Earlier, by a 17o-149 vote, the House approved a ban on strip m ining in environm entally fragile w estern valleys. Adoption of this ad m in istra ­ tion-backed am endm ent made a tough bill even tougher.

I 
WASHINGTOm — Two private study groups 
_ suggest the w orld’s energy future is m ore opti- 

 i m istic than it was portrayed by the CIA. 
The CIA re p o rt fo recastin g w orldw ide oil shortages in tin* 19811s and greatly increased prices has been cited by President C arter to support his proposed energy conservation pro­ gram . 
One group. Stanford Research Institute*. Palo 
Alto, Calif., said that high energy costs already have brought g re a te r efficiency in worldwide energy use. 
Another group. National Economic Research 
A ssociates, New York City, issued a 1o-page appraisal of the CIA study which said tho CIA took the m ost pessim istic view of every part of the energy situation. 
Energy program hit 

CHICAGO — R epublican chairm an Bill Brock 
I has called P resid en t C arter’s energy program a ripoff of the m iddle class and an attack on the family autom obile. 
“ Mr. C a rte r's energy program looks suspi- 

 j ciously like a back-door way of raising enough taxes to pay for m ore governm ent program s and 
I still balance the budget,” Brock said. 
Brock p red icted the proposed tax hike on gasoline probably will be used lo finance new social p ro g ram s instead of being rebated to energy-conserving fam ilies. 
U.S. will listen 

WASHINGTON —■ The United S tates would listen with interest to any Soviet arm s proposal, but still intends to base its position on the com prehensive package rejected by Moscow, an adm inistration official says. 
“ We consider the package to be an integrated one and it is difficult to see how the pieces might fit together if they are pulled out and put in another fram ew o rk ,” said State D epartm ent spokesman nodding Carter. 
Budget blueprint OKd 

WASHINGTON — A new b udget b lu ep rin t designed to bring together D em ocrats divided over defense spending and avoid a tie-up of funding legislation was approved by the House 
Budget C om m ittee. 
The com m ittee, which initially recom m ended trim m ing P resid en t C arter’s proposed defense spending in the fiscal year beginning Oct. I by 
'$2.3 billion, agreed on restoring $3oo million. 
Ballistic tests on ride 

PETROS, Term. — Two ballistics experts will begin tests next week to determ ine w hether a rifle purchased by Jam es Earl Ray was used to kill Dr. M artin Luther King Jr. nine years ago, 
Ray’s attorney says. 
“ At present, they do not know w hether they have the m u rd er w eapon,” said Jack Kershaw, most recent attorney for Ray, who is serving 99 years at B rushy M ountain State Prison here for m urdering King. 
Four House investigators, led by com m ittee counsel R obert L ehner spent six hours in ter­ viewing Ray in their fourth visit Friday. 
$2 million bail set 

PHOENIX, A ri/. — A form er union organizer and his son w ere ordered held in lieu of $1 million bond each on federal charges of kidnaping and m urdering Las Vegas labor leader Al Brarnlet. 
Thomas B urke Hanley, 61, and his son, G ram by 
Andrew Hanley, 39, both of Las Vegas, were arraigned by a federal m agistrate and ordered held for Nevada authorities. 
Brarnlet, longtim e head of the 23,ooo-member 
C ulinary W o rk ers Union in Las V egas and president of the Nevada AFL-CIO, was abducted from M eCarran International A irport Feb. 24. 
Young to IJ.N. m eeting 

UNITED NATlOmS — U.S. A m bassador An- 
I drew Young says he will attend a U.N. conference in M ozambique next month called to back free­ dom m ovem ents in Rhodesia and South-W est 
Africa. 
Young said he expects to stay in the Mozam­ bique capital throughout the International Con­ ference in Support of the Peoples of Zim babwe 
(R hodesia) and N am ibia (South-W est A frica) 
May 16-21. 
The United S tates m ay be the only m ajor 
W estern nation to attend the affair w here South 
Africa as well as Rhodesia is sure to com e in for vigorous attack. 
Oil slick off Florida 
MIAMI — An oil slick 6o miles long is drifting off the white beaches of the Florida Keys where 
Coast Guard c u tters arc standing by to see if it would drift tow ard shore. 
Friday night, the slick was as close as two miles from som e reefs hut was barely moving. 
The Coast G u a rd ’s A tlantic and G ulf Coast strike team s w ere en route to the keys with special containm ent equipm ent, including b ar­ rier booms that could be used to contain the* oil. 
Farter, Suarez m eet 

WASHINGTON — President C arter m et Friday with Spanish P re m ie r Adolfo Suarez and ex­ pressed confidence in Spain’s ability to m eet the challenge of establishing dem ocratic rule. 
Following a W hile House m eeting lasting more than an hour with the Spanish leader. C arter said the move toward dem ocracy in Spain “ has been billiard, m uch m ore successful than we had hoped.” 
Benzene exposure out 

WASHINGTON — The gov ernm ent has ordered sharp lim its on w orker exposure to benzene in some 1.26o factories after a new' study linked the common industrial chemical with leukem ia, a blood cancer. 
The Labor D epartm ent’s Occupational Safety and Health A dm inistration said the em ergency order will affect about 156.(NHI w orkers, largely in the petroleum , chem ical, printing, rubber and paint industries. . 
The em ergency order was only the sixth such rule issued by the adm inistration in its six-year history.

By DAVID HENDRICKS 
P resid en t C arter’s proposals for energy* con­ servation and increased use of coal are correct and should he supported, a Shell Oil Co. vice president said Friday night. 
Speaking* to about 15o people at St. M ary’s 
U niversity, Dr. Klaus L. Mai of Houston outlined what he saw were steps, mostly political, to lead us out of certain energY shortages. 
Dr. Mai stressed th at because energy shortages are a worldwide problem , nations are becoming interdependent for survival. 
He said the world m ust reduce its dependence on oil from the Organization of Petroleum Ex­ porting Countries. 
N ations should strive to solve th eir energy needs from a mix of sources to free the ruse of oil for essential purposes only, Dr. Mal said. 
He added that OPEC has a vested interest in seeing the energy problem solved in this way because it realizes that its own oil reserves are finite. 
Split 

The recent split am ong OPEC countries over ag reem en t for the price of oil indicates different goals am ong OPEC nations for their new wealth, 
Dr. Xai explained. 
However, O PEC ’s power within the world trade m arket rem ains high. 
“ The em bargo (by OPEC) in 1973-74 woke us all up to how vulnerable we a re ,” Dr. Mai said. 
To becom e better prepared for the* future en ­ ergy situation. Dr. Mai said, the United States m ust control its double digit inflation, cooperate with W estern European nations, find talent to get human solutions for economic problem s and help find a peaceful settlem ent for the M iddle East. 
He said the world may be running out of oil but not energy supplies. T here are I trillion tons of coal in the world, he added. 
That, plus an orderly developm ent of alterna­ tive energy sources will supply the needed en ­ ergy, he said. 
“ We m ust halt the debate and get moving with it now.” he urged. 
Dr. M ai’s talk was sponsored by the St. M ary's 
Institute of International and Public Affairs.

One m an was dead F riday following a shoot-out with th ree police officers during an incident reportedly begun over a disagreem ent about a eat. 
Police said the man fired a shot a t two of the officers before being w ounded. None of the policem en w ere injured, reports said. 
T he v ictim , Luis M artinez, 27, of 1(551 S. 
A m anda St., was prounounced dead at Green 
Hospital at 12:5o a.m . 
The officers were originally called by the m an’s sister. M rs. Lucy Mize, 44, of the sam e address, who told them at a neighbor’s residence her brother had shot at one of lier cats after it 
“ m eow ed,” police said. 
After arguing with her brother, the woman ran across the street and telephoned police from a neighbor’s house, police said. 
W hile talking with the woman, the first two officers to arriv e heard two shots com ing from across the street. A m an standing outside Mrs. 
Mize’s residence fired at the two officers, reports said. 
The policemen returned the fire, and the m an, ap p aren tly w ounded, stag g ered into the re si­ dence tow ard the rear door. A third officer, who had arriv ed by this tim e, fired a single shotgun blast through the back door, police said. 
O fficers said the victim , with a cocked .22 pistol in his right hand, was found slum ped on the floor by the door. Ile had been shot in the shoulder and chest, police said.

U.S. Rep. Bol) Krueger Friday lauded Housing, 
K dueation and W elfare S ecretary Joseph A. 
(’a lifa n o ’s sig n in g of S ectio n 5o4 of th e 
Rehabilitation Act of 1o7.1 

The regulations require that a person cannot he discrim inated against under any program or activity receiving federal assistance because of his handicap, 

“ I am glad that the secretary has chosen to im plem ent these regulations,” K rueger said. “ I am hopeful this will he the beginning of many new opportunities for the disabled to participate more fully in our society.” 

“ C ertainly the stand taken by our ad m inistra­ tion on this issue is consistent with its posture on human rig h ts,” Krueger said.

Rebates on efficient cars could begin Sunday 

W A SH IN G TO N ( A P ) 
- 
A n yon e b u y in g a 
Small, efficient car after 
Saturday w ill get a cash rebate if that section of 
President 
Carter’s energy plan gets through 
C on gress, C a r te r ’s top energy adviser said friday. 
.lam es R. S ch lesin g er told r e p o r te r s the proposed rebates on fuel efficient c a r s w ould be r e tr o a c tiv e to M ay I, 
1977, regardless of when 
C on gress p a s s e s th e legislation. 
The aim , S ch lesin g er 

 sa id , is to avoid e n c o u r a g in g p e o p le to hold off buying sm aller cars until Congress acts. 
However, the proposed ta x es p e n a liz in g p u r­ chasers of “ gasguzzlers” which deliver few m iles per g a llo n , would take effect only after 
Con­ g r e s s a d o p ts it, S c h le ­ sin ger said , b eca u se it would be too difficult — and perhaps illegal — to go back and collect the tax from people who had p u r ch a se d th e s e c a r s earlier. 
T he p ro p osed C arter 

' * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * 4 
[ L 
* * * * * * * * * * 
* 
* 
* 
* 

* 
* 
• L i t t i O t k a a 

 rebates for fuel-efficient ca r s m e a n s the d r iv e r who buys a new car g et­ tin g 19 to 2o m ile s per g a llo n a fter S a tu rd a y could expect a rebate of about $47 if the plan is ap proved by C o n g ress. 
The purchaser of a car getting 28 to 29 m iles per g a llo n would g e t b a ck about $321 and the p ur­ c h a s e r of a r e a lly efficient car delivering 39 miles per gallon or m ore w ould c la im a 
$473 rebate. 

Schlesinger explained details of Carter's energy program after the P r e ­ sident sent his legislative proposals to Congress. 

The program was also explained in a 1o3-page book issued by the White 
H ouse r e v ie w in g th e proposals announced by 
Carter on April 2o. 

Proposed rebates on fuel efficient cars would be retroactive to May J, 1977, regardless o f when 
Congress passes the leglislation 

Asked about th e p o s­ sibility of future gasoline ration in g, S c h le s in g e r said ration books printed up during the A rab oil em bargo of 1973-74 are still in storage but added the administration has no intention of im posing ra­ tio n in g , a lth o u g h it rem a in s a 
“ fa llb a c k measure” which could be used in an emergency. 

S ch lesin ger also said there is no plan to ask gasoline stations to close one day each week as was done during the embargo. 
In stead , S c h le s in g e r said. Carter’s plan would a llow in d iv id u a ls and 

 companies to decide how much energy to use and for w h at p u r p o se s . It would try to en cou rage energy saving and a shift from oil and natural gas toward coal and nuclear power by increasing pe­ troleum p rices d irectly and through new taxes. 
Schlesinger said Carter already has authority to create a new category of newly-discovered oil and to let producers price it at the w orld m a rk et p rice, a ro u n d $13.5o a barrel, plus inflation. 
He sa id C arter w ill propose that new regula­ tion within a few weeks to e n c o u r a g e e x p lo r a tio n for new oil sources. 

S c h le sin g e r said that p rice should be a m p le incentive to the oil com ­ panies. 
C arter’s prop osals to add further federal taxes to lower-priced oil and to oil and gas used by elec­ tric u tilities and in d u s­ tr ie s w ill re q u ir e c o n ­ gressional legislation. 
3 “ We b e lie v e th is is a m in im al p la n ” to cop e w ith the expected gap in the 198os between inter­ national oil demand and e x p e c te d p ro d u ctio n c a p a c ity , S c h le s in g e r said. 
“ We are sta rtin g not one m in u te too s o o n ,’’ 
Schlesinger said. 
But he left the d oor 

 open for n e g o tia tio n s w ith 
C o n g r e ss o v er sp ecific m e a s u r e s, s a y ­ in g, “ It is p o s s ib le as d is c u s s io n s w ith C on ­ gress proceed that there may be adjustm ents.” 
The proposed en e r g y ta x e s , and a p ro p o sed standby tax on gasoline, would bt returned to the public under 
Carter’s plan. 
S c h le s in g e r sa id rebates would be made to h o m e o w n er s w ho heat with fuel oil, com pensat­ in g th em for new oil taxes on a dollar for dol­ lar basis. 
T hat m o n e y , S c h le ­ singer said, would com e 
“ off the top” of the taxes collected. 
T he rest, he sa id , would be divided up and returned equally to every 
A m e r ic a n , e ith e r th rou gh in c o m e tax credits or through direct 

 payments by way of the welfare system to those who do not file tax returns. 
He sa id th e r e b a te s could be taken either by r e d u c in g in c o m e tax withholding or by claim ­ ing a credit when the re­ turn is filed. 
Schlesinger estim ated the proposed taxes would total about $72 b illion through 1985. He said the 
T reasury m ight end up with a profit of perhaps 
$7 billion at most by 1985. 
Carter included in his energy legislation pack­ a ge a le t te r to the 
Speaker of the House and the President of the Sen­ ate saying, “ I recognize that th e m e a s u r e s p rop osed w ill im p o se b u rd en s on all A m e r ­ icans, and that many of these m e a s u r e s w ill be highly controversial.” 
He assured them that 

 he and his administration would work closely with 
C ongress toward e n a c t ­ m en t of the N a tio n a l 
A n er g y Act w h ich in ­ cludes his proposals. 
The energy book issued b y the 
W hite 
H o u se s h o w s that 
C a rter p r o p o se s to m a in ta in growth in the Gross N a­ tional P rod u ct ( G N P ), the common indicator of econom ic activity, at an annual rate of about 5 per cent. 
It sa y s C arter’s plan hopes to reduce e n erg y use to about 2 per cent a y e a r by im p r o v in g e f ­ ficiency of energy use. In th e p a st, e n e r g y c o n ­ su m ption has grow n at about the sa m e rate as the GNP. 
T he book a lso s a y s consumers, workers, and b u s in e s s e s all w o u ld b e n e fit from v a r io u s aspects of the plan.

One hit too many 
UMPIRE SEPARATES Royals, Rangers as both benches em p tie d w h en Texas pitcher B ert Blyleven hit Kansas City b a tte r D arrell P o rter 

AP WIREPHOTO 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 

NEW YORK — Pitcher Bert Blyleven of the Texas Rangers has been suspended for three days and fined $5oo for deliber­ ately throwing at Darrell Porter in a game at Kansas City 
Wednesday night, American League President Lee MacPhail announced Friday. 
The suspension is effective immediately, meaning Blyleven 

 will m iss this weekend’s series at Chicago. 
“The action was taken after checking umpires’ reports and talking to Blyleven and representatives of the clubs involved,” a spokesman for MacPhail said. 

Blyleven admitted he deliberately threw at Porter, appar­ ently in retaliation for Texas’ Juan Beniquez being knocked 

 down one-half inning earlier. Beniquez had hit his first home run in two years earlier in the game. Porter is the Kansas City catcher. 

“ I didn’t throw at him hard,” Blyleven said after the game, 
‘‘and I didn’t throw at his head the way they did. I threw at his thigh and I got him right there.”

Celtics, Rockets roll on 

Series tied, 3-3 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
BOSTON — The defending champion Boston Celtics, led by the sharpshooting of Jo Jo White and John Havlicek and the ten­ acious play of foul-plagued Dave 
Cowens, kept alive hopes for another National Basketball As­ sociation title Friday night with a 113-1o8 victory over the Phila­ delphia 76ers. 

In squaring the best-of-seven show­ down 3-3, the Celtics moved the E as­ tern division semifinal playoffs back to 
Philadelphia for a seventh gam e Sun­ day. 
White scored 4o points and Havlicek 
25 as each went the entire 48 minutes in th e fie rc e ly played g a m e before a packed crowd of 15,o4o at Boston Gar­ den. 
Cowens, who picked up his fifth per­ sonal foul with the second half only 5:19 old, m anaged to rem ain alive and go the rest of the way playing a key role in the final two minutes. 
Boston, bidding for a second conse­ cutive NBA championship and an un­ precedented 14th in history, led 27-23 a fte r one period as W hite hit for I! 
.points.

Cheryl Robinson is pregnant. 

What’s so unusual about that? 

Well, Cheryl and her husband, 
Jay, will be bowling in the professional mixed doubles in 
Spectacular ’77 at Wonder Bowl next week.

“ She is going to try and bowl until her seventh m onth.” 
Cheryl is four months pregnant.

Houston leads, 3-2 

JAY ROBINSON 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
HOUSTON - The Houston 
Rockets hit 16 of 19 free throws in a 4o-point third quarter and rallied behind Calvin Murphy’s 
4o points Friday night to beat 
Washington 123-115 in their Na­ tional Basketball Association 
Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series. 

Buoyed by their free throw' shooting, the Rockets took a 14-point lead early in the fourth quarter, but had to hold off a late Bullet rally when the Bullets cut Houston’s lead to four points with 
3o seconds to play. 
But Murphy hit two free throws with 
19 seconds to play to give Houston the cushion it needed. 
M urphy’s 4o points tied him for se­ cond place among leading single-game s c o re rs in the playoffs this season. 
M oses M alone ad d ed 25 p o in ts for 
Houston and Rudy Tomjanovich added 
19. Elvin Hayes led Washington with 
3o, Mitch Kupchak had 2o and Phil 

Chenier added 19. 
The victory gives the Rockets a 3-2 lead in the best-of-seven series, which resum es Sunday at Landover, Md. 
The Rockets, who did not score any free throws until the final two minutes of the first half, rallied from a 55-52 halftime deficit in the third quarter to take a lead they never lost. 
The Rockets, the NBA Central Di­ vision cham pions, caught up at 73-73 with four minutes to play in the third quarter on two free throws by Murphy. 
Early in the fourth quarter, the Rock­ ets had ballooned their lead to 14 points at 98-84, their biggest lead of the gam e. 
The Bullets, who face elimination if they lose Sunday, made another run at the Rockets when Houston went four minutes without scoring starting with 
7:45 left in the gam e.

Dodgers stumble 

By CLIFFORD BROYLES 
OF THE EXPRESS-NEWS STAFF 

Amarillo won its second four-hour mar­ athon from San Antonio in three days, nipping the Dodgers, 6-4, in 13 innings 
Friday night. 

The Gold Sox snapped a 4-all tie in the four hour and two m inute gam e by scoring twice off hardluek loser B arry Biggerstaff. 
R u n -sco rin g singles by P aul O ’Neill and ILF. 
Drake brought an end to the bat­ tle, which was delayed 27 minutes by rain in the seventh inning. 
It was the rain delay which ap­ parently took away the D odgers’ momenutum . 
T h e D o d g e rs w ere b re e z in g along with a 3-1 lead before play 

 a waas stopped with one out in the top of the seventh at 9:o2 p.m. 

').? 
D ave P a tte rs o n , who allow ed only four hits and one run in the first seven innings, was relieved after giving up an eighth inning single to Bobby Mitchell and a walk to Kurt Witt- mayer. 
M a n a g e r Don “ D u c k y ” L e Jo h n c a lle d on right-hander Kevin Keefe, who promptly gave up a two-run double to Ivan Murrell, tying the gam e at 
3-all. 
Biggerstaff was then summ oned to pitch to Bro­ derick Perkins, who slashed an opposite field double 

Littler, 
Bums tie 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
HOUSTON — Veteran Gene Littler fired nine “3s,” including an eagle on the 16th hole, for a 65 that lifted him into a tie with 
George Burns for the second-round lead 
Friday in the $2oo,ooo Houston Open Golf 
Tournament. 

The usually placid, unemotional Littler tossed his putter into the air after holing a 6o-foot putt for the eagle that put him seven under par for the day. 
The 46-year-old veteran had to have those heroics to take a sh a re of the top spot with Burns, who matched Littler’s 135 total, nine under par for two

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday April 3o I 977 
Astros win 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 

PITTSBURGH — Floyd Bannister, top pick in baseball’s free agent draft last June, gained his first major league pitching victory and Joe Ferguson hit two home runs to lead the Houston an 11-3 triumph over the Pittsburgh Pirates Friday 
Astros to night. 
Reds hot 
CINCINNATI (AP) — Woodie Fry­ man and Rawly Eastwick combined for a seven-hitter and George Foster singled in the winning run as the 
Cincinnati 
Reds extended their winning streak to four games with a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs Friday- night. 
Fryman, the oldest starter in the 
National League, won his first game since opening day. The 37-year-old left-hander settled down after a shakey start to even his record at 2-2. 
Eastwick was summoned with two outs in the ninth after George Mitter- wald doubled. He was greeted by Larry 
Biittner’s pinch hit single, then retired 
Ivan Bejesus on a fly to post his fourth save. 
Bill Buckner drove in both Chicago runs with a double and sacrifice fly. 

Bannister, a product of Arizona State 
University, allowed ll hits but pitched the full nine innings in his first major league start. He had been o-1 in two relief appearances this season.

Saturday’s semifinals of the TOIL state tennis championships with triumphs 
Friday afternoon.
