Nastase prevails 

BUCHAREST, Roman­ ia (AP) — Hie Nastase whipped Bernard Boileau in straight sets Friday as 
Romania took a 2-o lead over Belgium in the first day of their Davis Cup tennis qualification match. 
Nastase won easily on scores of 6-1, 6-4, 6-1. 
In the other singles match, Dumitru Haradau beat Jean-Pierre Richer 
6-1, 6-3, 6-3. 

Cycle victory 

B EN ID O R M ,. Spain 
(A P) — A Dutchman, 
Fedor den Hertog, won 
(he third leg of the 32nd 
Tour of Spain cycling race on Friday, eight se­ conds ahead of overall leader Freddy Maertens of Belgium. 

Texas nips 
White Sox 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 

CHICAGO — Right-hander Doyle Alexander scattered five hits I and Sandy Alomar hit his first home run of the season before Bert 
Campaneris scored the winning run on a wild pitch by Steve Storied 
Friday night to give the Texas Rangers a 2-1 victory over the 
Chicago White Sox. 
Trailing 1-o going into the sixth in­ ning, the Rangers tied it when Alomar, filling in for injured rookie Bump Wills at second base, led off with a homer to- tie the game. Campaneris then (Iou-* bled, moved to third on a pair of walks and scored when Stone unloaded 'his wild pitch. 
Alexander boosted his record to 34 and didn’t allow a hit after Jorge Orta homered with two outs in the fifth, retiring the last 13 batters in succes­ sion. 
Stone suffered his third loss against one victory. 

T EXA S 

D O N ALFANO of Am arillo hustles back to first as Dodger 
M ark Hance aw aits throw p h o t o by r o n j o n e s 
Dodgers 

Continued from Page IE 

 just fair down the left field line, scoring Murell w ith the go-ahead run. 
The Dodgers sent the game into extra innings as 
Marv Webb led off the bottom of the eighth with a line-drive home run to left. 
San .Antonio loaded the bases later in the inning on singles by Mark Hance, Jeff Leonard and Ted Farr with one out hut failed to score. 
It was only the second victory in five games in the series for the Gold Sox. The first win was 12-1o in 12 innings. 
Amarillo relief pitchers Mark Lee, Bill Joseph and 
Marty French blanked San Antonio on five hits over the last six innings. 
French, who picked up his first decision of the season, entered the game with the bases loaded and one out in the lith and put down the final eight 
Dodgers in order to pick up the victory. 
The Dodgers tied the game at 1-1 in the second on an RBI double by Mike Rushde, which scored Leon­ ard after the first of his four singles. 
San Antonio took the lead in the third with two runs, the first scoring on a fielder’s choice grounder by Hance. Leonard singled home Ron Washington w ith the inning’s second run. 
Amarillo scored first when Billy Hallstrom hit the first pitch of the game for a double. He took third on a passed ball and scored on Mitchell’s grounder. 
DODGER DOPE: Dodger first baseman Don 
Cardoza suffered an injury to his left eye during batting practice Friday. He was taken to the hospital for emergency treatment. The injury was diagnosed as a bruised inner eye. Dodger officials said Cardoza would not travel with the team to El Paso until he had been checked by an eye surgeon. If no further damage is found, he will join the team in El Paso. 
Cardoza, the team’s leading hitter, suffered the freak injury when he swung at a ball during batting practice. The ball hit the edge of the plate and bounced up, striking his eye. 
The Dodgers open a 1o-game road trip Saturday night in El Paso. 
P eed advances 

MUNICH (AP) — Victor Peed of Paraguay beat 
Yugoslavia’s Nikki Pilie to reach the semifinals of the $75,ooo Bavarian Grand Prix tennis tournament 
Friday. 
Jose Iligueras of Spain, Dick Crealey of Australia and Zeljko Franulovic of Yugslovia also reached the final four. 
Peed won his match 6-3, 7-5, which enables him to face Crealey, who crushed Colombia’s Ivan Molina 
6-3, 6-1, in Saturday’s semifinal. 
Bad S.A. day 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS-NEWS 

KINGSVILLE — San Antonio schools drew a blank in state qualifying at the Class AA Region IV Track 
Meet Friday night at Texas A&I. 
Only new record established was set by Mike 
Whitwell of Cotulla, who leaped 6-6 over the high- jump bar.

Yanks roll 

NEW YORK (AP) - Relief pitcher 
Ron Guidry, a last-minute replace­ ment for missing Mike Torrez, fired eight shutout innings and Thurman 
Munson slammed a two-run homer as the New York Yankees beat Seattle 3-o 
Friday night in their first-ever meet­ ing with the expansion Mariners. 
It was the second major league start for the 26-year-old left-hander, whose strikeout pitching bailed him out of a one-out, bases-Joaded jam in the first inning. 
The Mariners never got another runner beyond first until the ninth in ing when one-out singles by Juan 
Bernhardt and Bill Stein chased 
Guidry. Sparky Lyle replaced Guidry with runners at first and third and retired Dan Meyer on a popup and 
Ruppert Jones on a grounder to end the game. 
Guidry, 2-o, struck out eight and held the Mariners to seven hits in 8 1-3 innings. His first five outs were re­ corded via strikeouts.

Red So x , 7 4 

BOSTON (AP) — Three home runs, including a three-run shot by Carlton 
Fisk, powered the Boston Red Sox to a 
7-4 victory over Oakland Friday night. 
The two teams belted a total of six home runs, but the Red Sox had more men on base as they beat Dock Ellis, 
1-2, making his first appearance since being acquired from the New York 
Yankees Wednesday.

R o yals, 6-1 

KANSAS CITY (A P) - Darrell 
Porter singled twice to drive in three runs and Jim Colborn notched his fourth victory as Kansas City spoiled 
Toronto’s debut in Royals Stadium with a 6-1 victory over the expansion 
Blue Jays Friday night. 
Bob Bailor's lead-off double, a fly ball and a wild pitch gave the Blue 
Jays a 1-o lead in the first inning and 
Bill Singer, o-4, made it stand it up until the fourth.

An^el s, 3-2 

BALTIMORE (AP) - Don Baylor's lead-off home run in the lith powered the California Angels to a 3-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles Friday night as unbeaten Frank Tanana cap­ tured his fourth victory in a row. 
A one-out homer in the ninth by Joe 
Rudi, giving him a record-tying 27 runs batted in for April, had saved 
Tanana from losing a classic pitching duel with Jim Palmer. Reliever Dyar 
Miller, who came on in the lith, took the loss.

Brew ers, 6-5 

MILWAUKEE (AP) - Cecil Cooper hit his third home run of the year in the seventh inning to lift the Milwaukee 
Brewers to a 6-5 victory over the 
Cleveland Indians Friday night. 
, 
The Brewers jumped out to a 2-o lead in the first inning on singles by Von 
Joshua, Robin Yount and Cooper and an infield out by Sal Bando. 
After Larvell Blanks’ sacrifice fly in the fourth scored Cleveland’s first run, the Brewers broke loose for three runs in the bottom of the inning off Indian starter and loser Pat Dobson, o-3. Sixte 
Lezcano ripped a double to right- center and scored on Jim Wohlford’s single. Wohlford stole second and came home on Charlie Moore’s single. 
Joshua chased Dobson with a double to right, scoring Moore.

T ige rs, 6-5 

BLOOMINGTON (AP) - Rookie se­ cond baseman Rob Wilfong booted a routine ground ball with two out in the 
1oth inning, allowing Ron LeFlore to score the winning run as the Detroit 
Tigers nipped the Minnesota Twins 6-5 
Friday night. 
LeFlore had beaten out an infield hit and stole second before Wilfong’s error on a ground ball hit by Rusty Staub. 
Reliever Steve Foucault, 1-1, pitched 
4 1-3 innings to pick up his first victory as a Tiger. John Hiller pitched the loth inning for the Tigers to collect his third save of the season.

C ard s, 5-2 

ST. LOUIS (AP) — Hits by Hector 
C’ruz and Ted Simmons highlighted a four-run St. Louis first inning, sending the Cardinals to a 5-2 victory over the error-plagued Atlanta Braves Friday night. 
The victim of the early Cardinal uprising was Atlanta knuckleball 
Phil Niekro, o-4, who was touched for three hits and plagued by two errors in the rally.

U.S. Cup team falls 

GENE LITTLER watches, reacts to 6o-foot eagle putt Friday 

AP WIREPHOTO 

BUENOS AIRES (AP) 
— Ricardo Cano upset 
Dick Stockton and Guil­ lermo Vilas crushed 
Brian Gottfried in the opening singles matches 
Friday to give Argentina a 2-o lead over the United 
States in the American 
Zone final of the Davis 
Cup tennis tournament. 
Cano beat Stockton 3-6, 
6-4, 8-6, 6-4 while Vilas downed Gottfried 6-4, 6-o, 
6 -2 . 
This is only the third time that the United 
States and Argentina have met in Davis Cup play and the first time that Argentina has man­ aged to beat the United 
States. The United States beat Argentine 5-o in both 
1931 and 1958. 
The opening games of the best-of-five series were held under sunny skies and temperatues in the mid-8os on the slow red clay courts. 
The 7,ooo fans cheered the Argentines on with chants, beating of drums and blowing of horns. 
There was so much noise that court officials re­ peatedly pleaded with the fans for quiet. 
In the first match, the 
26-year-old Cano battled back from a first-set de­ feat to give Argentina an early lead. 
Stockton played a baseline game, rushing the net only at the right moment. 
But Stockton lost some of his fluency in the se­ cond set and made se­ veral errors as Cano won. 
The 26-year-old from 
Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 
Littler shares lead 

Continued from Page IE 

 rounds over the 6.997-yard Woodlands Country Club course. 
The husky Burns, who compiled a spectacular amateur record before joining the pro tour three years ago, played his second round in four-under-par 
68 and hasn’t made a bogey in the tournament. 
“ I ’m going to be very low key from here on in.” said Burns, who blew a chance to win his first pro title in this tournament a year ago. ‘‘I don't want to get too excited.” 
George Knudson, a 39-year-old veteran from Can­ ada, was third at 137 after a 68 that included a double bogey seven. 
Chi Chi Rodriguez, who said “ I’ve got my game back—all of a sudden I think I can play good golf again,” Doug Tcwell and Leonard Thompson were next at 138. Rodriguez had a 66, which included an eagle two on the ninth hole. He called it “ my best round since I won the Tam O’Shanter in 1964.” 
Thompson, who said he had benefitted from a series of lessons from Arnold Palmer at Palmer’s Bay Hill 
Club in Florida, hot a 68 and Tewell had a 67. 
Canny Wadkins, who scored nine birdies on his 

 way to a 68, and Dave Eichelberger, with a 67, were at 139. 
Mark Hayes, who shared the first-round lead with 
Burns, blew to a 76 in the warm, windy weather and was well back at 143. 
Jack Nicklaus, only two strokes off after the first 
18 holes, took a fat 75 and was even par at 144. Arnold 
Palmer, with a 74, and Lee Trevino, with a 77, were at 146. Defending champion Lee Elder, who took advantage of Burns collapse over the last nine holes a year ago, shot a 7o and was at 143. 
Burns, a powerful, 215-pound former Maryland football player, missed only one green in his solid effort. He chipped to within six feet and made the putt to save par there. 
Two of his birdies came on par fives. He chipped to within tap-in distance on one of them and holed an eight-footer on the other. He also scored from 15 feet on the par three eighth and birdied the 13th from about the same distance. 
Littler, winner of 28 tour titles and a playoff loser at Tucson early this season, had an even better effort. He, too, escaped without a bogey, missed one fairway by about a foot, and missed one green by about the same distance. 

Trinity wins 

Scores 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS NEWS 
FORT WORTH — Trinity, despite losing the number one singles match, blasted TCU, 7-2, in a dual tennis match Friday afternoon. 
Randy Crawford, newly crowned 
Southwest Conference singles cham­ pion, topped Tony Giammalva, 6-3, 3-6, 
6-3, in the feature singles fray. Eddie 
Reese, playing in the number five match, lost to TCU’s David Kelly, 7-6, 
6 -2 . 
Ben McKown defeated Tut Bartzen 
Jr ., 6-3, 5-7, 6-3; Erick Iskersky breezed by Rick Meyers, 6-1. 6-3; Larry 

Gottfried, still hampered with some pulled muscles, defeated Tom Mott, 
6-4, 6-3; and Dave Benson topped Jim 
Allin, 6-3, 6-4. 
In doubles, Giammalva and Gott­ fried defeated Meyers and Mott, 6-4, 
6-4; McKown and Iskersky handled 
Crawford and Bartzen, 6-o, 5-7, 6-1; and 
Reese and Benson downed Allin and 
Kelly, 7-6, 6-7, 7-5. 
The victory makes the . second- ranked Tigers 24-3. Trinity winds up its 1977 dual match season Saturday with a 1:3o p.m. match against South­ ern Methodist. 
Stap prevails 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS NEWS 

BATON ROUGE — Trinity’s Sandy 
Jap won an abbreviated number one ingles match to pace the Tiger ladies o a 7-2 tennis dual match victory over louisiana State University Friday af- ernoon at LSU Tennis Stadium. 
Stap defeated Ebie Taylor 6-3 in the irst set and was ahead 2-1 in the econd when Taylor sprained her ankle nd had to retire. 

Snakes play 

The St. M ary’s Rattlers can clinch a tie for the Big State Con­ ference baseball championship Sa­ turday by sweeping a doubleheader from Texas Lutheran in Seguin. 
Gametime is I p.m. 
The Rattlers are 1o-1 in BSC play while Southwestern has a 5-3 re­ cord. Should Southwestern also lose either game of its doubleheader at 
St. Edward’s, the Snakes could sew up the title outright.

May 18-22. The Tiger women were supposed to play Tulane Saturday, but

Taiwan golfer captures lead 

NAGOYA, .Japan (AP) — Hsu Sheng 
San of Taiwan fired a one-under-par 69 
Friday for a 36-hole total of 137 and the lead midway through the $2oo,o6o 
Chunichi Crown international invita­ tional golf tournament. 
The 35-year-old Taiwanese pro held a three-stroke lead in the chase for a 
$4o,ooo first prize in the 72-hole event being played at the 6,728-yard, par-7o 
Nagoya Golf Club.

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS-NEWS 

RENO, Nev. — Joe Vito Buenrostro was eliminated from the ABC Masters double-elimination bowling tourna­ ment Friday. 
The San Antonio kegler lost to Cliff 
McNealy of San Lorenzo, Calif., 
843-8o2, then fell to Dave Diomedi of 
Dot riot, 844-721.

 became visibly nervous after the Argentinan’s second-set victory and after that made more mistakes. 
The Americans pro­ tested two baseline calls, but the judges upheld the calls. 
After the matches, the 
American team retired to its hotel for a crucial strategy meeting. 
“ I told the boys that tomorrow we have to win or it’s all over,” the non-playing American 

 team captain, tony Tra- bert, said after the meet­ ing in his room of the plush Sheraton Hotel in downtown Buenos Aires. 

“ During the talk I con­ centrated on my doubles pair, telling them that 
I ’m more worried about their game tomorrow than the .singles Sun­ day,” Trabert added. 
“ First we have to win tomorrow and then we have to worry about the other matches.”

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEWS— Saturday April 3o I 977 
Stepping Stone a biggie 

L O U IS V IL L E , 
Ky. 
(A P ) — Coined Silver preps for what would be owner C.V. Whitney’s 
13th Kentucky Derby when the colt opposes five other 3-year-olds Sa­ turday in the one-mile 
Stepping Stone Purse on opening day at Churchill 
Downs. 
Whitney has had 15 
Derby starters and the closest he has come to 

 winning was in 1947 when 
Phalanx finished second, beaten a head by Jet Pi­ lot. Gleaming Sword, last in a 14-horse field in 1968, was the last 
Derby starter for Whitney, who also owned the last filly to run in the famed race—Silver Spoon, who finished fifth in 1959. 
Coined Silver won a di­ vision of the Elorida 
Derby by I Vfc lengths over 

H. A. HUGHES, JR. 

FOR MEETING THE 
REQ U IREM EN TS OF THE 
NATIONAL 
QUALITY AWARD 

The N O A is presented in recognition of exceptional clientel service. 
American-Amicable takes pride in announcing this prestigious personal achievement. 
/Im eric an Amicable 
I lf I INSUHANCl COMPANY 

 t m enhir QHiets • A m m an Amictblt Building • Wien Tints 
San Antonio Branth Office: 18o4 NJ. loop 41o Phone 828-6336 
X I 

Nearly On Time March 7, finished sixth in the Fla­ mingo won by Seattle 
Slew March 26 and was third in the 11-16 mile 
Calumet Purse April 19 at Keeneland. 
Others entered for the 
Stepping Stone, which this year will be run at one mile instead of seven furlongs, are Nostalgia, 
Papelote, Best Person, 
Imbiber and Senator 
Baffler. All but Senator 
Baffler are nominated for the May 7 Derby. 
Nostalgia, winner of the Hawthorne Juvenile and second in the Rem­ sen last year, finished seventh in the Calumet 
Purse. But trainer Del 
Carroll feels the colt didn’t like the Keeneland racing surface. 
Papelote finished fourth in the April 23 
Wood Memorial won by 
Seattle Slew, while Best 
Person, a big colt who did not race as a 
2-year-old, has two wins, three seconds and two thirds in seven starts this year. 
Three-year-old fillies also will be featured on opening day at the 
Downs.

Buck permit plan might be expanded 

Buck deer permits will be required in Webb County again this season. There will be no change in the issuance rate. 
Landowners will receive one permit for 23o acres of land, with at least one permit issued per tract regardless of size. 

Officials of another county, Medina, are reported to be giving serious con­ sideration to embracing the buck per­ mit system for the 1978 season. 
Medina County commissioners re­ duced the bag limit in Medina last season to one buck per hunter in an effort to limit the kill. This, as expect­ ed, was only partially successful. 

The buck permit system is perhaps the most drastic method of reducing the kill of bucks in an area, but reduce the kid it does if harvest figures in 
Webb County were accurate. 

“ No doubt the weather reduced the overall kill in Webb,” reports Fielding 
Harwell of the Parks and Wildlife De­ partment. 
“ Nevertheless, buck permits redistributed the harvest with regard to ranch size.” 
There is no question that the permit system limits the kill on small tracts of land. And that reduction is precisely what wildlife biologists and some county officials want to do. 
Decrease on sm all tracts 

The kill on ranches 2,5oo acres in size and smaller decreased from 1,259 bucks in 1975 to 465 bucks in 1976 in 
Webb County, Harwell said. This is a decrease of 63 per cent on ranches up to that size. 
This involved a big majority — 72.3 per cent — of the Webb County lan­ downers, he pointed out, but only about 
IO per cent of the deer range in the county. 
Ranches of 1o,ooo acres or more ac­ counted for 1,71o bucks in 1975. The kill on these large tracts in 1976 dropped only 17 per cent, to 1,417 bucks. 

This decline was attributed to the poor hunting conditions, Harwell said, because generally the number of buck permits available equalled the number of bucks killed in previous seasons when permits were not required. 

“ While a certain portion of the de­ cline in harvest on small ranches can be attributed to the weather, it is ap­ parent the harvest was affected by the limited availability of permits,” Har­ well said. 
Anyone who advocates the buck per­ mit system leaves himself open to cri­ ticism that the system favors large ranches and severely penalizes ow ners of small tracts. 

In favor of the deer 

This is, in fact, true. But the reason is not to benefit the owner of large ranches; the reason is to benefit the deer. 
Bucks in some areas of the state are overhunted. This is the case on many small tracts of land, especially in out­ lying subdivisions, where there is little control over either the number of hunters or bucks killed. 
The buck permit system cannot help but reduce the number of bucks avai­ lable to hunters and, in the long run, increase the price of deer hunting in 
Texas, but it might be necessary in some areas to maintain a healthy, huntable herd. 

★ ★ ★ 
Parks and Wildlife Commissioners have accepted a donation of the 
4,753-acre Bar O Ranch In Medina and 
Bandera Counties for a state park. 

Under terms of the agreement,, the donor, Mrs. John F. Merrick, bas con­ veyed a 2/7ths undivided interest in the ranch to the department. The depart­ ment has secured a lease agreement for use of the remaining interest which will be conveyed to the state over a period of years. 

Development of the site as a park will follow completion of a master plan. 

★ ★ ★ 
The May meeting of the San Antonio 
Audubon Society will be held Tuesday at 6:3o p.m. in the San Antonio Garden 
Center. Dr. Paul Robertson will speak on the future of wildlife in Latin 
America.

Pistol team picked 

Five members of the 
9oth U.S. Army Reserve 
Command’s pistol team have been named on the 
Army Reserve squad which will represent 
Fifth Army in the All- 
Army Championships at 
Fort Benning, Ga., May 
22-27. 
They are GWO Hubert 
D. Denson, Capt. Jon R. 
Fory and Capt. Lloyd L. 
Leech, all of San Antonio; 
Spec. 
5 
Michael 
J. 
Turner of Austin and 
Capt. Thomas W. Moore of Baton Rouge, La. 
Also selected to the squad to shoot at Fort 
Benning is Staff Sgt. Mi­ chael A. Hart of San An­ tonio. 
GWO Denson won the 
Individual 
National 
Match Course Center 
Fire, Individual Slow 
Fire Service and Indivi­ dual Time Fire Service at Fort Riley, while Capt. 
Moore won the Individual 
Rapid Fire Service.

W heatley’s Elm o Thornton (14.o) and 
Houston's Burney Allen (14.4). 
Fox T ech ’s Leon B an ks takes the second best half m ile into the finals with a 1:56.o, but he m ust beware of two of the best 88o men in Texas in

22o at 21.9. 
Ronnie D risdale of H ighlands w as the lone San Antonian qualifying in the century with a 9.9 effort.

(22.5) squeezed into the finals after tho video tap machine had to be consulted to pick places. McCollum’s Tom Vera 
. ran fast enough to qualify, hut was disqualified for running out of his lane. 
Churchill’s Rick Neely led the way for the Alamo City in the 44o with a tim e of 5o.1. Neely was joined by qua­ lifiers Paul Rodriguez of Jefferson and 
Camundo Salas of McCollum.

M id way, but Southwest and South San 
West had som e great individual per­ formances.

Tivy’s weightman M arco Fifer had a dism al day collecting fourth and fifth, respectively, in the discus and the shot put. 
Rose stars 

DES MOINES. Iowa (A P) - Nick 
Rose took 13 seconds off his own record in a special 5.ooo-meter race but drew second billing to a throw-in from Ok­ lahoma as the 68th Drake Relays got under way Friday. 
Randy Wilson evidently hadn’t read the script that said he w as .just sup­ posed to fill out the field for the high-powered 8oo-meter invitational. 
Wilson burst ahead of Am erican record-holder R ick W ohlhuter and 
Drake Relay’s record-holder Mike Boit at the tape for an upset victory. 
A first-day record crowd of 15,5oo saw seven records fall, and a m ark e sta b lish e d in a new even t. The 
18,ooo-seat Drake Stadium had long been a sellout for Saturday’s finals.

Tornado digs in 

DALLAS (AP) — Coach Al M iller of the North Am erican 
Soccer League’s Dallas Tornado believes that when you are winning you shouldn’t tem pt fate. 
And that explains why Miller has no intention of tam pering with his defensive line Saturday when the Tornado hosts the 
San Jo se Earthquakes at Ownby Stadium . 
The Torando will be going after its fourth consecutive victory of the season. San Jo se com es to D allas with a 1-2 record.

Tourney time 

Action will begin at 8 a.m . Saturday at Alva Jo Fischer Com plex and at 
Roger Stokes Center in the Fifth An­ nual Men’s Fast Pitch Softball Tour­ nament sponsored by the City Recrea­ tion Department. 
Twenty-eight team s, IO from San 
Antonio, are entered in the double elimination meet which will end with the finals at 5 p.m . Sunday. 
Defending cham pion will be Hous­ ton’s Opco Kuehn team . 
Texas prevails 

WACO (AP) — University of Texas catcher Bobby Kearney hit a grand slam hom er in the fourth and first basem an Mickey 
Riechenbach added a two-run homer in the sixth to lead the 
Longhorns to a 1o-4 Southwest Conference victory Friday over the Baylor Bears. 
Baylor dug in with an early 3-o lead, but w as pushed aside when Texas scored seven runs in the fourth. 
Riechenbach doubled, Wendell Hibbett walked and Chris 
R aper was hit by a pitch to set up K earney’s grand slam . 
Texas is now 45-6 on the season and 17-5 in SWC play. 
Baylor’s record is 34-12 for the season and 13-9 for SWC gam es. 

 by Pan Am 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS-NEWS 
EDINBURG — Trinity pitchers Jay Moritz and D .J. Webb each hurled shutouts Friday night as the Tigers shocked Pan Ameri­ can, 4-o and 2-o,. “ knocking the Broncs out of the NCAA baseball playoffs for the first time in seven years. 

In the opener, Moritz walked eight and struck out just one, hut Pan Am cooperated by leaving ll) men on base. 
The victory for Moritz w as his third in eight decision this y ear. Pan A m ’s 
Glenn Cunningham (8-4) w as the loser. 
Trinity center fielder Ruben Lozano had a two-run sin gle in the seventh inning of the first g am e to put the 
T igers safely in front. F ran k O akes also chipped in two hits. All five of 
Trinity’s hits were singles. 
The Tigers got just four hits in the second gam e, hut m ade them count, registering three of them in the third inning. 
Jau n Kaufman singled, Lozano dou­ bled him home and O akes sin g led , drivin g in Lozano. The trium ph for 
Webb, who scattered six hits, was his first of the year after four losses.

Frogs to clash 

FO RT WORTH (A P) - New Texas 
Christian football coach F.A . Dry gives 
Horned Frog fans a preview of the 1977 team Saturday afternoon in the annual 
Purple-White intrasquad gam e. 
The team will be equally divided in a player draft by the staff. 
Dry said the scrim m age session is an important one in the duel between senior Jim m y Dan Elzner, junior Steve 
Bayuk and sophomore Don H arris for the No. I quarterbacking job.

Sign e d infielder-outtielder 
Lenny Randle 

Traded 
Jim Umbarger, who spent last season with the Texas Rangers, has been sent to the minor leagues by his new team, the 
Oakland A’s. Umbarger is going to San Jose of the Pacific Coast 
League.

CARRIZO SPRINGS - The Carrizo 
Springs W ildcats broke U v a ld e ’s 
26-game winning streak, 1-o, Fridav night. 

Senior right-hander Manuel Perales threw the shutout. Scattering three hits, striking out one and walking two. 
Ile got the Coyotes to hit a lot of bah on the ground. 

The Wildcats, who have won five of their own in succession, scored the game’s only run in the second inning when Philip Kolos singled, im as 
Ochoa sacrificed and P erales’ hit a grounder that went through the Uvalde shortstop for an error, scoring Kolos.

South of W onderland 
736-2856 

No-hitter by San Marcos 

Sophomore right-hander Pete Quin­ tero of the San Marcos Rattlers pitched a no-hitter in downing 
District 
32-AAAA leader Roosevelt, 4-1, Friday. 
The Roosevelt loss tightened up the race, as runnerup Churchill blanked 
Seguin, 2-o, and pulled within a game of the Rough Riders. Roosevelt is now 
9-3 and Churchill 8-4 with only two games left. 
In District 29-AAAA, both Laredo 
Martin and South San Antonio won games on the 1o-run rule to set up a pennant battle next Tuesday night at 
South San. 
Judson eliminated McCollum, 4-2. in the othergam e in District 29. 
No. Franked Jefferson pulled closer to the istriet 31-AAAA title with a 5-1 win over Edison, the Mustangs’ 19th straight win. 
All Jefferson has to do is win one of its last two games to annex the title.

Finland rolls 
VIENNA (AP) — Finland defeated 
Romania 4-2 in Vienna’s Stadthalle 
Friday for its second victory in the 
World lee Hockey Championships. 
After Finland had taken a 2-o lead in the first period, the Romanians pulled to within one and swarmed around the 
Finnish goal. But the Finns rode out the pressure and put the game out of reach by scoring two goals within a minute early in the final period. 
Finland’s goals were scored by Esa 
Peltonen, Jukka Porvari, Timo Sutin- en and Pertiti Koivulahti. 
The Romanians, promoted from the 
B Pool this year, have lost all six of their games

Judge chides 
Kuhn 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
ATLANTA — A federal judge chided Baseball Commissioner 
Bowie Kuhn on Friday for im­ posing different penalties on baseball club executives ac­ cused of violating the same player “ tampering” rules. 

But Kulm insisted from the witness stand that the circumstances were vastly different when he fined St. Louis 
Cardinals President August A. Busch 
•Jr. $5,o(1o in September and when he suspended Atlanta Braves Owner Ted 
Turner for one year in December. 
The testimony came during the final day of hearings on a suit by the Atlanta ball club challenging Turner’s su­ spension. 
Over 
The hearing ended Friday afternoon with U.S. District Court Judge Newell 
Edenfield taking the matter under ad­ visement. He gave attorneys until May 
9 to submit proposed conclusions of law. 
The brash Atlanta club owner, who 
Thursday threatened to present an op­ posing attorney with a “ knuckle sand­ wich,’’ was more subdued at the con­ clusion of the case. 
Turner, a millionaire sportsman w ho also owns controlling interest in the 
National Basketball Association’s At­ lanta Hawks, refused to comment about the case, but said it has already changed his impulsive style of owner­ ship. 
“ It’s hard to be quite as enthusiastic with all the problems that exist that I didn’t know about (when he purchased the club in early 197H,” Turner said. 
But he added: “ That’s not going to stop me from being enthusiastic.’’ 
Charge 
Turner was accused of violating free-agent draft rules by mentioning salary terms before baseball’s Nov. 4 re-entry draft. Besides being suspend­ ed, Turner’s team also was forced to forfeit its first-round choice in the amateur draft in June. 
At one point Friday, Edenfield re­ ferred to Kulm as a “ benevolent de­ spot’’ and later wondered “ about the fairness of your benevolency.” 

San Antonio EXPRESS-NEW5— Saturday April 3o I 977 

Lots o f expecting 

TED TURNER arrive s for F riday hearing 

Constrasting the penalties Kuhn handed out to the two club owners, 
Edenfield remarked, “ You say that’s being a benevolent despot?” 
Kuhn replied, “ I'd hesitate to put it in those words,” but said Turner’s cocktail party remarks that he would outbid the San Francisco Giants for the services of outfielder Gary Matthews were more serious than Busch’s com­ ments that he would ask his board for 
$2 million to $3 million to bid for free agents in the Nov. 4 draft. 
Edenfield asked Kuhn if he were familiar with “ the justified furor in the federal courts about disparate sentences? Half of the problems in our jails are created by disparate sen­ tence, where one place provides pro­ bation and in another place the sen­ tence is 5-1o years. That generates trouble. 
“ I suggest to you that but for dis­ parate sentences (in the tampering cases) you wouldn’t be here,” said 
Edenfield. 
Kuhn said Busch’s comments came after he had issued the first of several directives admonishing club owners not to negotiate with free agents before the draft, while Turner’s followed the issuance of an entire series of direc­ tives. 
Guilty 
In addition, the Braves had been found guilty earlier in the season of attempting to tamper with Matthews, and the club dismissed the executive involved, he said. 
He said Turner’s was “ an aggravat­ ed case, a reckless ignoring of the dir­ ectives with full knowledge...(the 
Braves) were misbehaving.” 
Kuhn said he felt it imperative to impose severe sanctions against vio­ lating the tampering rules because the 

AP WIREPHOTO 
1976 season was the first in which free agents were available to the open market under a new collective bar­ gaining agreement signed by the players and clubs. 
Under the agreement, players who serve out their option year with a club and do not sign a new contract are eligible to sign contracts with others clubs which compete for negotiation rights with those free agents during the re-entry draft. 
Club owners were nervous about how the new system would work out and whether it would affect the “ stability of the game, the competitive balance, the financial integrity and the integri­ ty, itself, of the game,” said Kuhn, 
He admitted under questioning from 
Edenfield that Turner’s comments about outbidding the Giants for 
Matthews’ services did not upset the free-agent draft, but said the system is still new and such comments could have an adverse effect on it. 
Clear 
Edenfield also made it clear he was concerned with Kuhn’s decision be­ cause it deprived Turner of his pro­ perty. 
On cross-examination by Turner’s attorneys, Kuhn was asked if he had considered the fact that Turner’s re­ mark to Giants owner Bob Lurie came in a cocktail party setting and that 
Turner has since described it as being intended facetiously. 
“ I ’m aware that was true but you have to put that in the context of the baseball business,” said Kuhn. “ Ines­ capably, there is a good bit of business carried on by people who have been drinking. But if I made special rules for people who had been drinking and for people who had not been drinking, this business would be a shambles.” 

Continued from page IE 

 have been quite well. It takes me a longer time to get warmed up, but once 
I get warmed up everything is all right.” 
Jay and Cheryl hope fate has it that they will be paired should both qualify for the finals. 
“ We would really enjoy it if we hap­ pened to be paired,” Jay said. “ We certainly would like to be paired, it would be quite an experience and, of course, we would have a good time. If either of us has to strike out in the 1oth in the qua­ lifying round to be paired, we will do it. 
“ The only time we’ve bowled together was in Los Angeles in 
1974 in a semi-pro tournament, we wer­ en’t married at the time. We won that tournament. 
That 
PAGE could be a good omen for this tourna­ ment, if we’re paired. 

“ The other time we bowled together was in the AME Grand Prix in Detriot last December,” Jay added. “ We weren’t partners but we bowled to­ gether — she finished 1oth, and I fin­ ished 17th." 

The Robinsons will take time out from painting and repairing their newly-bought house in Van Nuys, Ca­ lif., to come to San Antonio. The

“ If I recall correctly, the people were very friendly and the lanes con­ ditions were great at Wonder Bowl,” said Cheryl, who, as Miss Korn insky, bowled an exhibition with Dick Ritger last year at Wonder Bowl. “ I’m really looking forward for the tournament.” 
Ja y is quite impressed with the 
Spectacular. 
’

The second annual Irene Hot! man Memorial Golf Tournament is scheduled Friday at Bracken­ ridge. Mrs. Hoffman, known as 
"Jh e Duchess ", was the founder of the San Antonio Women s Golf 
A sso ciatio n in 1932. G eorg e 
Hoffman, Irene's husband who redesigned the Bracken rid g e course, will present the winner of the tournament with a trophy..

CHICAGO (AP) — A $4 million da­ mage suit against Muhammad Ali was dismissed Friday by a federal judge, who said there was “ mutual abandon­ m ent" of the contract for a match betw een the heavyw eight boxing champion and Duane Bobick. 
Last November, Ali signed a $225,(WM) contract with Madison Square Garden 
Boxing Inc., to fight Bobick in New 
York in February. 
AH had announced earlier he was retiring from the ring. But he said he agreed to the fight because he was 
“ pressed for money as a result of his alimony obligations.” 
Teddy B re n n e r, G arden m a tc h ­ m a k e r, had first contacted A li’s manager, Herbert Muhammad, about the fight. “ M uham mad refused to make any commitment for Ali but told 
Brenner that the decision to fight or not to fight' was Ali’s,” said Judge 
John Powers Crowley of U.S. District 
Court. 
When Ali signed the contract, he was paid $125,ooo for training expenses. 
The money was returned in January after Ali contended “ that he didn’t have the capacity to enter into the agreem ent without the approval of 
Muhammad,” the judge said.

CLIFF W ILEY of Kansas breaks the string in the

Ring series shuts down 

NEW YORK (AP) - The recent investigations of the U.S. Boxing 
Cham pionships, prom oted by Don 
King for ABC-TV, have forced another boxing series off the air. 
World Television Cham pions, a weekly ‘series originated by m atch­ maker Don Elbaum and shown in most major m arkets on an independent network put together by WTC Presi­ dent Hank Schwartz, has suspended its telecasts indefinitely. 
The to u rn am en t, scheduled to 

 stretch over 25 weeks, will continue, and Schwartz hopes to resum e the telecasts in September. 
“ We have canceled our telecasts for time being because of the bad press boxing has been getting,” Schwartz said Friday. “ Boxing as a sport in general has been painted in a rather bad light. 

“ Our advertisers have adopted a wait and see attitude. We believe it will clear up in a few weeks, and as of now 

 we are planning to pick up the TV with our last five championship fights, starting in late September.” 
Schwartz said viewer and sponsor response to the WTC tournament has been good, but the investigations of the troubled U.S. Boxing Championships have put the entire sport in a bad light. 

“ There are some rotten apples in the barrel that have to be culled out,” 
Schwartz said. “ It’s unfortunate that the good get hurt along with the bad.” 

NEW YORK (AP) - 
Don King has reinstated the three assistants he suspended over a week ago amidst controversy concerning the U.S. Box­ ing Championships, the tournament sponsored by 
King which was halted by 
ABC Television earlier this month. 
Boxing experts Paddy 
Flood and Al Braverman, w ho serve Don King Pro­ ductions Inc. as indepen­ dent con su ltan ts, and public relations assistant 
Gordon Peterson were rein stated F rid a y by 
King a fte r being s u ­ spended from th e ir duties last week. 
“ I deeply apologize to my three friends for my thou ghtless, hasty ac tion,” King said. “ Where 
I have castigated those who have pre-judged me in recent weeks, I now realize that I have com­ mitted the same grievous wrong to Paddy, Al and 
Gordon by my failure to judge a man. innocent until proven guilty.”

Motoring 

Saturday April 3o 1977 

M O T O R T O W N C O R P . e m p lo y e e x p e r t ly in stalls the distinctive brushed alum inum ta rg a b a n d on the sp orty 1 9 7 7 A M C H ornet A M X 
Customizing firm, ^ 
C make AMX eye-catcher 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS-NEWS 
STURTEVANT, Wis. - American Mo­ tors’ popular new Hornet AMX is the eye-catching result of a joint effort by the automaker and Motortown Corp., a leader in car customizing on a mass-produetion basis. 
The AMX is a derivative of the Hornet hatchback model. 

Bodies are produced at AMC’s massive auto-building complex in nearby Kenosha and brought to Motortown’s facility here for the addition of a package which completely changes the appearance of the car. 
Targeted primarily for the young, per­ formance-oriented buyer, the AMX in­ cludes such factory-installed items as rally instrumentation with tachometer, painted bumpers, floor console, sports steering wheel, styled road wheels with 
AUTOMOTIVE BUIPtAT 

DR78 x 14 black radial tires, front sway bar, four-speed manual transmission and a 258 cubic inch six-cylinder engine or optional 3o4 V-8. 
Al Motortown. workers add a brushed aluminum targa band with special insig­ nia over the center of the roofline. A hinged louver panel is installed over the baculite. An air dam is installed under the front of the AMX and fender flares are attached to the front and rear wheel openings. 
Motortown also adds such items as black rubber body side scuff moldings, 
AMX body side and interior graphics, black outer door frames and a blacked-out rear central panel. 
As many as 8o Hornet AMX’s have been customized by Motortown in a single day since production got under way last fall. 
Mike 
Mulroy, 
Motortown plant manager, said his company has done 

~AU toM gTiV t fejSPULT 

Smith Chem ilet spans 62 years 

 customizing work for all four U.S. auto manufacturers since the firm was estab­ lished in 1975. 
He said Motortown picks models from each of the Big Four car makers and ex-' periments with a variety of custom ap­ plications at its prototype shop in Dear­ born, Midi. 
When satisfied that it has significantly enhanced the appearance of a model, 
Motortown goes to the manufacturer with its custom design proposal. 

In the case of the Hornet AMX, Ameri­ can Motors was impressed with Motor­ town’s basic design and production began after some refinements by AMC de­ signers. 
The Hornet AMX became an overnight success in the marketplace and produc­ tion schedules were adjusted upward to meet the demand. 

Ask to speak to Mr. Roy Smith at 
Smith Motor Co., 1221 Broadway, and you will be asked, “Which Roy 
Smith please?” 
You see there are currently three gen­ erations of Smiths active in the business. 
Roy Smith started in the Chevrolet bu­ siness in 1915. At 91 he is still very much on the scene and part of Smith Motor Co. 
His son Roy C. Smith joined the firm in 
1939 and is still active. 
The third generation is represented by 
Roy F. Smith, grandson of the founder. 
When the elder Smith began selling motor cars, he worked for Jack W. Neal hardware, implements and vehicles. 
When the Chevrolet came on the mar­ ket, a company was formed with Jack W. 
Neal, Jack C. Neal and Roy Smith to sell the automobiles. 
Relationship disliked 

In 1922, the Neals decided they did not like the relationship with the Chevrolet people and did not want anything more to do with selling their cars. 
Smith decided there was a future in selling Chevrolets so he took on the dea­ lership. 
At that time you could buy a new Chev­ rolet for $535. Smith said there was no warranty on the cars back then. 
He moved the business to a building on 
Alamo Street, and set about making a success of selling cars. Times were pretty good, but people were still not coming in to buy — you had to go out and sell the cars. 
Smith managed to average selling one car a day by going out and talking to people wherever he could find them. 
It was not unusual for him to make his sales pitch while walking beside a farmer plowing a field. 
“ The first thing they would tell me is that they didn’t want to buy a car. Well, that would just make me work all the harder, and I usually sold them in the end,” Smith said. 
Few good mechanics 
Good mechanics were almost non-exis- tant. 
Smith recalled one time when a customer had a complaint about his car, they had to rebuild the rear end and the transmission. When the ear was road tested, it was discovered they had put it back together wrong — it had three speeds in reverse and only one forward. 
It is hard to realize today, but Smith said his biggest problem was that most people who bought cars did not know how to drive. Salesman also had to teach the buyer to drive. 
There were very few trade-ins to fool with; most people came in and paid cash. 
There were no automobile finance com­ panies back then and the banks were very reluctant to make loans for cars. 

 rn i rn dmmm"k Ip 

« rSS* 

ROY SMITH 
. . . founder 
ROY C. SMITH 
. . . president 
ROY F. SMITH 
. . . treasurer 

AUTOMOTIVE DUMAY 

Looking back over all of his years in the automobile business, Smith said the most significant improvements were the elec­ tric starter, the spiral ring gear and pin­ ion in the rear axle. 
Always part of car 
To the current generation the starter was always a part of the car. But without it, certainly, the car could never have been driven by most women. And a lot of other people would have found crank starting not worth the trouble. 
By the time young Roy C. Smith started in the business, the company had sur­ vived the worst part of the great depres­ sion, and the country was about to become engaged in World War II. 

Roy C. was just learning the ropes when he had to take time out from business and serve his country during the war. 
The elder Smith said the war years were difficult ones because there were no new ears to sell. He kept the business going by buying and selling used cars and supplying parts and service. 
After the war the automobile business was very good, and in 195o Smith Motor 
Co. moved to its present location on 
Broadway. 
No move foreseen 
Roy C. likes the present location. He said Smith Motor Co. does not intend to move in the foreseeable future. He said the firm can continue to serve San An­ tonio fromits central location. 
“ You sec, everywhere you go Chevrolet has one downtown dealer to serve the central city — we are going to be that dealer in San Antonio. We have planned our expanion, and we like what we have; it works very well.” 
Roy C. said sales this year are the best he has ever seen. He thinks the auto­ mobile industry will survive government regulations, although he thinks the go- 

K iJf O M C T I X J D U M A C 

 vernment is trying to see how' far it can go in regulating people’s lives. 
“ Right now our small cars are not selling too well. The people are buying intermediates and big cars because that is what they want.” 
Involved completely 
His son Roy F. is now involved complex tely in the business. 
“ He tries to go too fast sometimes and I have to slow him down. But he started just like I did. out on the grease rack and has worked his way up through all of the departments,” said Roy C. 
About his grandfather Roy F. said, “ It© is still active in the business. He takes a walk around the dealership about twice a day. If he sees anything wrong he tells me about it — he still knows everything that. goes on." 
Roy F. joined the firm four years ago. 
Although he has worked in all of the de­ partments, he likes new car sales best. He said the other departments are interest­ ing, but they are secondary to new car sales, because new ear sales generate all of the other business. 
“ Marketing is a very big part of the business today, advertising plays a big role today,” he said. “ It’s not like it was in grandfather’s day when you could live on reputation You can hardly live on re­ putation anymore. 
“ The population is changing too fre­ quently. Reputation is important, but you have to reach the new people in town, and you do that with advertising.” 
Change with times 
Smith Motor Co. has seen a lot of changes in the car business, but it has been able to change with the times. 
When there arc three generations active in any type of business, the business must be doing things right, 
In the car sales business it is a really remarkable record.

Tile Peugeot 6o4 gives you the engineering of a Mercedes-Benz, the handling of a BMW the elegance of a Jaguar, and a level of comfort superior to all of them. 

Like its illustrious competition, the Peugeot 6o4 has a responsive six-cyfinder engine, fully independent suspension, distinguished styling, and meticulous attention to detail. 
But in addition, the Peugeot 6o4 offers outstanding comfort. With oversized shock absorbers. Targe coil springs, and anatomical seats that are actually tuned to the suspension. Finally, the 6o4's price starts at around $ 11.OOO PO E * Whic h may well be its most com forting 
I feature of all.

San Antonio E X P R E SS -N E W S — Saturday A p ril 3 o I 9 7 7 
P a g e 
5 -P 

Automotive supplier critical of air bags 

31Sp 
^ m 
V 
. C M S ' 

SPECIAL TO THt EXPRESS NEWS 

Most people applauded former Tran­ sportation Secretary William Coleman for organizing a 44o,ooo-car experimental program to test air bags. 

But Charles Ohly, executive vice presi­ dent for automotive operations of TRW, challenges the eost-benefits of this pro­ gram. 

TRW, a world-wide automotive supplier with sales of $1.3 billion, has a seatbelt manufacturing facility in Germany, as well as an operation in Michigan which last year did $15o million worth of business. 

When asked about Coleman’s air-bag 
• program, Ohly said, “ I would challenge 
'tho cost-effectiveness of such a program. 
I'd like to see a good trial on widespread use of seat belts. To me, for a fraction of 

 the cost, the results of the seat belts and shoulder harnesses have been quite good.” 

Mandatory program 

Ohly would like to see some of the states try out a mandatory seat-belt use pro­ gram. He said about 21 stall's have been studying compulsory usage. 

Regarding the promotion that s needed to get such a seat-belt program going, he said, “ I don’t see much going on frankly. 
I see all the headlines on air bags, anil the insurance people seem to tout air bags. I don’t understand why something as sim­ ple as a shoulder belt and seat harness isn t encouraged.” 

As to why the U.S., a world leader in automotive safety, isn’t doing anything 

.serious about mandatory seat-belt use,1 
Ohly continued, “ Maybe it’s our very de­ mocratic system — people in Washington like to do what’s popular. And it’s not j popular to tell somebody that they must do (his or they must do that. I think we I back away, whereas in some of these | other countries they just rap on the table and say ‘that’s it.'” 
Encouraged 
TRW has a substantial program under way in Germany to make seat belts more pleasant and easier lo use. Ohly said he was encouraged by the compulsory use of seat belts in Germany and in most other 
European countries because ifs proving lo be a very simple, direct way to reduce high casualty rates on the highways. 
Automotive Information Council reports 
Australia has compulsory belt laws and the results have been good. Usage is up and public acceptance has been excellent.

 number o f pickup trucks which are replicas o f the actua race support vehicles for sale through p a rticip a tin g
